name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the preparation of the European Council of 28 and 29 June 2018 (2018/2590(SDR)).

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, in June, leaders will take a strategic look at several important issues that will affect Europe in the coming years. A first topic is how, in today’s world, we as Europeans do more for our own security. The European Council will take stock of progress in a number of areas where we are deepening cooperation in security and defence.  The agreement we reached together on the European Defence Industrial Development Programme will allow the European Union to fund, for the first time, a programme on defence capabilities. We are also in favour of making headway on improving military mobility, and working to strengthen our resilience to chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear-related risks and our capabilities to address hybrid threats. The European Council will also assess progress in the field of civilian CSDP, and leaders will provide further guidance on PESCO and our important cooperation with NATO.  As you know, migration is also on the agenda. Much has been achieved over the past years in terms of strengthening our overall migration policy, with tangible results on the ground. There is broad agreement on most elements of our migration policy, including better protecting our external borders and controlling illegal migration. As the Presidency, we have worked diligently on the reform of the Common European Asylum System to help bridge differences in approaches and develop concrete solutions. Intensive negotiations have taken place in the Council on the various proposals of this package. The Dublin reform remains difficult, but in most other files good progress has been made. The European Council will now look at the broader picture. To this end, President Tusk is currently conducting consultations with his peers. The June European Council will also be the opportunity to spell out our vision for an innovative and digital Europe in the years ahead, following the leaders’ debate in Sofia. Technology-driven innovation is increasingly shaping our lives. The pace and scope of change that the next waves of innovation will bring are unprecedented.  To play an active part in this global transformation, we in Europe need to do better when it comes to the way we generate ideas, turn them into business and help businesses grow on the global stage. We need to deepen Europe’s innovation capability and nurture, in particular, breakthrough and disruptive innovation.  As we reinvent the way we do things, we should also stay true to ourselves and to our values. This is not only true with respect to innovation, but also in relation to our digital endeavours. By creating an environment where innovation can thrive while guaranteeing high standards for the protection of users, we will foster high levels of trust in technology. The next Multiannual Financial Framework is a key tool to shape our common future. The European Council will discuss the future handling of the proposals concerning the MFF, including the timeline.  Turning to jobs and growth, the European Council will conclude the European Semester for 2018. It will also take stock of the leaders’ discussion on taxation held in March under the Leaders’ Agenda process. The European Council will also have the opportunity to address international developments, including the latest trade issues. As you know, the European Council is also expected formally to adopt the decision on the composition of the European Parliament, on which you will be voting tomorrow. Finally, the European Council, in terms of Article 50, will meet on the next day to review the state of the negotiations with the United Kingdom. In the margins, the Euro Summit will meet in an inclusive format. It will discuss measures on the Banking Union and to further develop the European Stability Mechanism, and will provide additional guidance on the way forward.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before giving the floor to Vice-President Timmermans, I wanted to remind the Council that the European Parliament has been adopting a proposal for reform in Dublin for months. Following the results of the last Justice and Home Affairs Council, I believe that it is right to address and carefully examine the text approved by one of the co-legislators such as the European Parliament. I have stressed, at all Council meetings, the importance of addressing the Dublin issue and the importance of examining as a basic text that of the European Parliament, which combines both firmness and solidarity. I appeal to the Council not to underestimate or ignore the serious proposal which has received a great deal of support from this House for a reform in Dublin, which I believe has not been done by the Member States to date.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, it’s an honour to address this House, this time on behalf of President Juncker, who is returning from G7 duty in Canada. I think I would be remiss if I did not start with what happened in Charlevoix. I’m not one to declare that the rules-based international system so carefully built up after the Second World War is now collapsing before our very eyes. However, it is the first time since 1945 that an American President has not seen it as an American strategic interest to work hard to ensure a vibrant and unified Europe and a robust transatlantic relationship.  This means that the EU needs to take its destiny more into its own hands and we should be confident about our ability to do so, because our foundations are strong. Our Union is built upon Member States that voluntarily and democratically decided to link their destinies and shape the future together. The basis for the shared destiny is a tripod of democracy, the rule of law and the respect for human rights. This is how one creates unity between big and small, how one creates unity in full respect of our diversity. It is in turn our unity that gives us strength globally to pursue better and more sustainable standards for everyone; to defend global trading rules; to boldly address climate change; to protect our citizens against geopolitical and/or geoeconomic challenges, and to better grasp the opportunities that globalisation has to offer.  And so, this month’s European Council comes at an auspicious time, and it is a good opportunity to show political will, decisiveness and unity. But we should look beyond the daily Twitter feed and also keep our eyes on the ball with regard to the work that lies ahead of us. Last December, leaders agreed to come back to a number of issues in March. In March, they agreed to come back to the same issues in June. While important decisions take time, we cannot postpone decisions indefinitely. The situation in the Mediterranean is a stark reminder that we cannot wish problems away. No fence is high enough and no sea is wide enough to render our countries immune to the greatest pull factor there is – the freedom, the prosperity and the stability of our Union.  In recent months, under the guidance of the Bulgarian Presidency, the European Union has shown what is possible when we are united and committed to finding European solutions. We agreed, for instance, on the difficult issue of the Posted Workers Directive, thanks in large part to this House. Equal pay for equal work in the same place will now become a reality for all Europeans. We made substantial progress on our digital single market with regard to the abolition of roaming and on clarifying and strengthening audiovisual media services or telecoms rules.  With regard to Brexit too, the EU is united. Our goal is to ensure we, together with our British partners, do as little harm as possible to either side and to work together towards an orderly process in the interest of all citizens in the EU and in the United Kingdom.  The European Council of June will take stock on a number of issues, in particular the question of Ireland and Northern Ireland, as well as the future relationship between the UK and the EU. We still have three more weeks to go, and it is important to use this time to achieve real progress in the interests of all. Parliament, Council and Commission are working together to deliver.  In the next months, we also have to deliver on the legislative files we identified as our common priorities under the two joint declarations. From plastics to migration, from energy to transport, from the European Solidarity Corps to the European Citizens’ Initiative. We’ve promised this to the European citizens before the next elections. It will be our collective achievement. The joint declarations guide our work, so let’s stick to our commitments.  As we approach the June European Council, this then is the spirit and the approach that all leaders must take. United by our values, linked by our interests and concerted in our actions.  Das gilt auch für die Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion. Denn je stärker diese ist, umso mehr verleiht sie der Union als Ganzes Kraft, was sich wiederum positiv auf den Lebensstandard der Europäerinnen und Europäer auswirkt. Deshalb ist es unsere Pflicht, den Euro zu stärken. Die Kommission hat bereits im Dezember ein umfassendes Paket vorgelegt, um unserer Gemeinschaftswährung zusätzliche Stärke und Handlungsfähigkeit zu verleihen. Wir haben außerdem vor wenigen Wochen konkrete Haushaltsinstrumente vorgeschlagen, um Reformen zu fördern und Investitionen im Euro-Raum selbst in Zeiten asymmetrischer Schocks zu gewährleisten. Dass die Mitgliedstaaten die Vorschläge der Kommission diskutieren, ist ein erster wichtiger Schritt. Doch es reicht nicht, wenn wir lediglich feststellen, was notwendig und geboten ist. Wir haben zwar bereits Fortschritte gemacht und Lehren aus der Krise gezogen – sei es bei der Reduzierung notleidender Kredite im europäischen Bankensektor, beim Aufbau der Kapitalmarktunion oder bei der Einigung im ECOFIN-Rat im Mai, als wir Maßnahmen ergriffen haben, um die Risiken im Bankensektor weiter zu reduzieren. Das war ein wichtiger Schritt hin zur Vollendung der Bankenunion. Der Gipfel im Juni – die Leaders' Agenda – ist der Moment, die Ideen und den politischen Willen endlich auch in konkrete Entscheidungen und Taten umzusetzen. Wir müssen uns endlich darauf einigen, dass der Europäische Stabilitätsmechanismus die Letztsicherung für den einheitlichen Abwicklungsfonds übernehmen kann. Und dafür müssen wir endlich auch beim Einheitlichen Europäischen Einlagensicherungssystem weiterkommen, das nicht nur über Nacht aufgebaut werden kann, sondern für das Vorbereitungen, Vorbedingungen zu erfüllen sind. Gestatten Sie mir, auch den mehrjährigen Finanzrahmen zu erwähnen. Ich glaube, dass wir uns vor den nächsten Wahlen unbedingt einigen müssen. En ce qui concerne la gestion des migrations, la situation n’est en rien comparable à ce qu’elle était il y a trois ans, mais ici également, nous avons encore du travail à faire pour compléter la mise en place d’une politique migratoire fondée sur la responsabilité et la solidarité, tout en assurant une meilleure protection de nos frontières extérieures. Les négociations ont déjà bien avancé sur une bonne partie des éléments proposés par la Commission pour réformer notre régime d’asile européen commun, notamment sur l’harmonisation des conditions d’accueil et les conditions standard de protection ainsi que sur un cadre commun de réinstallation pour renforcer les voies d’entrées légales. Nous avons également accompli des progrès sur le renforcement d’Eurodac – la base de données de l’Union européenne contenant les empreintes digitales des demandeurs d’asile – et nous avons déjà un accord politique sur le renforcement de l’agent de l’Union européenne pour l’Asie. Le Parlement s’est engagé dans toutes ces négociations avec détermination et a réussi à améliorer la qualité du texte et je voudrais saluer les efforts considérables accomplis par la présidence bulgare dans ce domaine. Mais pour finaliser un accord sur l’ensemble de la réforme de notre politique d’asile, il faut maintenant trouver un compromis sur le mécanisme de Dublin et je veux soutenir, avec tout l’appui de la Commission, les propos du président du Parlement à cet égard. Là aussi, on peut noter des avancées, en particulier la création d’un volet préventif de ce mécanisme. Prévenir la crise future est aussi important que la gestion de la crise elle-même. Mais évidemment, il faut reconnaître et respecter les différentes positions et sensibilités qui existent dans nos pays sur ces questions très délicates. Il est temps de résoudre ce problème. Tous les éléments sont sur la table, il est temps d’agir, je suis en parfait accord avec le président du Parlement européen. Ainsi, la Commission attend des chefs d’État et de gouvernement qu’ils se penchent sérieusement sur la question de Dublin et esquissent les orientations nécessaires pour parvenir à des solutions équilibrées qui aient l’appui de tous et qui soient des solutions solides et durables fondées sur nos valeurs communes. Nous risquons non seulement de perdre nos valeurs mais aussi de porter atteinte à notre humanité même si nous ne trouvons pas des solutions qui permettent de voir des personnes en crise comme des êtres humains qui ont besoin de notre aide. (Applaudissements) Étant donné l’importance de ce défi – existentiel, je crois, pour l’Union européenne –, la Commission proposera cet après-midi un renforcement ambitieux et important des moyens financiers pour soutenir notre politique commune au cours des prochaines années.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for his excellent work. Today's debate will certainly be marked by uncertainty and instability in the light of the G7 summit. That is why I would like to start with the positive message: we are all reaching the reports from Singapore on our mobile phones. If Kim and Trump agree that there is a great opportunity for a nuclear-weapon-free Korea, for a Korean peninsula that is nuclear-weapon-free, then that is a great success, and we should be glad that these results are there. Diplomacy works, sanctions also work. But I hope that Washington will recognize that diplomacy is not only good when Donald Trump signs it. We have already achieved a very positive diplomatic result with the Iran agreement. At that time, Obama signed, and that was as good as the current result that we have for Korea. If we now look at the summit, at the European Council, there is perhaps a risk that we will again describe major objectives and, in the end, perhaps come back with few results. That is why I would like to focus on highlighting two specific points where we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats are now demanding clarity and results, and where there is also an opportunity to do so: the first is trade issues – an issue that concerns many who are currently worried about their jobs. Europe must give the European Commission full backing on this. Tariffs on aluminium and steel have been imposed for no reason. That is why united countermeasures, as the Commission has initiated, are the right way forward. We expect the Council to fully support this. And we also believe that the conversation is right. If Jean-Claude Juncker has now been given the task of going to Washington and talking about a world without tariffs, then that is the right approach. I would also like to add that the problem with America is also creating a number of opportunities for us Europeans at the moment. It is the case that we have seen in Canada that it is six to one. So we have many partners who are still advocating rules-based trading. We should talk to them, talk to them and, as soon as possible, with Japan, with Mexico, with whom Mercosur concludes the treaties that are now realistic. In retrospect, I would like to remind you once again that we have had a great deal of controversy here in Parliament on the issue of CETA – I would like to remind you of this once again – and we feel, in the current situation, how grateful we are that we are able to conclude such agreements, at least with Canada, with a country that is committed to our values. Ceta is still a model for the future shape of trade policy. Finally, a second point, namely the euro debate: here too, the debate is enough. I believe that we can now achieve results. The European Monetary Fund is within reach so that we can achieve independence from international structures in the future. The backstop is close. We will be able to involve parliaments more closely with the structures that are now being envisaged. In other words, this step should be taken, as should the step proposed by the Commission in December to move forward with the investment budget now. Following the reform aspect and the aspect of budgetary stabilisation, the focus is now on investment. We should make progress on this. That is why: act now, on these two points! The tailwind should give us the fact that we have great success in the euro. Since the beginning of the crisis, we have created ten million new jobs in the euro area and have growth of 2.5% – much stronger than the Americans and, by the way, the British friends. That is why the reform policy that we have been practising so far should give us a tailwind for this. I hope that the Council will no longer talk, but that these two points will be dealt with!

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this is the House of the European people and, having said that, I cannot avoid raising again and again the situation in the Mediterranean Sea. There is a boat in the middle of the sea. Many of those people – children, pregnant women – are in a disastrous situation, not for the first time and, unfortunately, perhaps not for the last time.  We have a general idea. Those who disembark in one of our countries disembark in the European Union. This is our principle. Article 80 of this Treaty speaks about responsibility and about solidarity. Yes, it is true that Italy has taken the lion’s share of the responsibility in the past, but – forgive me, dear colleagues, this is to Mr Salvini – if you need to demonstrate what you think is your strength at the expense of pregnant women and children, you have no idea how poor you are.  (Applause) This is a change in Italian politics which is by no means defendable.  And let us talk about the re—emergence of the Spanish people and the Spanish Government. Yes, Pedro Sanchez, thank you. You gave grace to the European Union again and what you did was marvellous. This is the new style of the Spanish people and of Spanish politics and we appreciate that. Thank you to the new government and all those who support it. But since this is not an isolated situation – and now we come to the Council – no, you don’t have time to postpone the issue of migration. No you cannot stay sleeping. No, there is no excuse for not doing anything and this is one of the major issues that have to be discussed in the next European Council. And this is also to Mr Kurz’s incoming Presidency. Mr Kurz, ask yourself whether you are happy. Are you still proud that you closed – this is one of your favourites – the Balkan route without any alternative? Are you still proud of your comradeship with Mr Orban, demonstrating it in each and every situation? No, we will not let him pass into this House of the People when he arrives in the second half of this year with a stance like that! This will not be the policy of my group, the Socialists and Democrats, and this will not be the policy of the European Parliament, dear friends. What we have to make clear ...  Und das bezieht sich auch auf meine Kolleginnen und Kollegen der Europäischen Volkspartei in Deutschland, lieber, verehrter Kollege Weber: Nein, das ist nicht drin! Wir können hier nicht pro-europäisch reden und zu Hause mit Orbán schäkern und die Europäische Union in einer zentralen Frage ohne Perspektive lassen. Das werden wir nicht tolerieren! Und das müssen wir auch an Frau Merkel adressieren: Nein, Frau Merkel, der Enthusiasmus, den Sie zeigen, der Enthusiasmus in Lösungen der Probleme – man kann nicht weiche Knie kriegen, nur weil Trump mit dem Handelskrieg droht. Der Wirtschaftsminister in Deutschland muss das kapieren: Das reicht nicht, was da geliefert wird! Und das gleiche gilt für unser Engagement, mit dem wir insgesamt die Europäische Union stark machen müssen. Auch Frau Merkel muss kapieren: Nur eine vereinte Europäische Union, nur eine starke Europäische Union wird in der Lage sein, unsere Gesellschaft in eine erfolgreiche Zukunft zu führen. Dafür steht meine Fraktion, dafür werden wir arbeiten. Und wir freuen uns auf die Diskussionen, die in diesem Haus zu dem Thema noch anstehen.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr. President, I will increase the number of languages used here so I will ask you to use the headphones, and also to symbolically extend the core of the European Union, I will speak English. Chairman! Of course, it is not new that, because of national political victories, the European Union and other Member States are often used as the enemy of the ring, and after these sweet victories the national champion is crowned. However, recently, this situation has come to a new intensity, and victories are useful both for the victories of migrant workers – when in reality only a few per cent of the labour market – and for the issue of migration and the revision of the Dublin Convention. Now, in the run-up to the Council meeting, I will actually touch only a few points from the European Council's agenda. Firstly, on migration, the Dublin review and quotas as part of them. In the three years since the European Commission came up with this quota proposal, I think it is clear to everyone that this system cannot and will not work in the future, because in fact there are only a few Member States of the European Union on the map of migrants and also of the smugglers' organisers, which are the destination for these migrants to get to. All other countries are either transit countries or those that are not on the map at all, such as, say, those countries that are too poor to get there ever. Let us say, in my country, Latvia, a hundred places for migration were built – good, arranged , – shelter base, which is usually filled well, if with one third. By meeting our voluntary quotas, people who accidentally get there disappear with papers or undocumented documents in the literal days. This means that such a system does not actually work, and we have still not found other solutions in three years. The second issue is the multiannual financial budget, which will also be talked about in the Council. I think it is extremely important to stress that the European Commission's proposal, despite the Brexit cash shortfall, nevertheless creates more opportunities overall in this financial part, while at the same time a very targeted reduction in cohesion policy depending on the Member State concerned. In this case, what message is it for generations that are the new generation in these countries? We are talking about the period from 2020 to 2027, which actually means 10 years for many younger Member States, this is a message for the younger generation: 'You have a worse future than the new ones today, and that means you have to go away to those countries that are wealthier because they will even subsidise jobs for youth employment'. It is not clear whether young people coming in from other countries or only local young people.  It should be remembered that in some countries the so-called universal income base is higher than the average wage in other Member States of the European Union, and in all this common sauce it is very difficult for us to address the citizens of the European Union that there are common values, as Mr Timmermans said, that there is a common understanding of European values. It is difficult and almost impossible to explain to the citizens of such countries, the countries of the European Union, that it is.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I have to say to you that if I hear Mr Weber and then Mr Bullmann afterwards, I ask myself whether there is a government in Berlin or have I missed something? I have not the impression that there is – in any way, on a number of issues – a common German position for the moment and that is one of the problems for the moment in the European Union, but that is not my item. Ms Panayotova, the next European Council can talk and talk and talk and discuss and write conclusions on whatever issue that you want, and there is a long list of issues – Brexit, the governance of the eurozone, the defence union, the Multiannual Financial Framework, the Trump and Kim Summit – you name it, but in my opinion – and Mr Bullmann has already said it – there is one item, one crisis, which I urge you not just to talk about this time, but to act on now, and it is this ongoing migration crisis in the Mediterranean Sea.  I think we all agree on this – you, the Commission, the whole Parliament, all the political groups – that what is happening there is a disgrace, it is a scandal, and already for years now. I am contradicting Mr Timmermans a little bit now when he says yes, it is not the same as in the past. No, it is not the same as in the past, but since the start of this mandate, Mr Timmermans, there will be more than 10 000 people who will have died in the Mediterranean Sea. And since the beginning of this year, there are 800 people, men, women and children, who have drowned in the Mediterranean Sea. And now it is the same with this boat – 600 people, seven pregnant women, pushed from country to country. It is a disgrace, it is a scandal.  I will not point my finger in this debate at one individual country, not at Malta, not at Italy. I do not think we have to point a finger at Mr Muscat and say it’s your fault, or at Mr Salvini even. I reject completely the ideas of Mr Salvini, but I think we have to point the finger not at you personally, so don’t take it personally, but at all of you, at the whole of the European Council which is not capable until this moment to take a position on this migration issue and on the reform of the Dublin system. It is a collective responsibility. I am always asking myself why we made the European Council an official institution of the European Union under the Lisbon Treaty. In the Lisbon Treaty we said, yes, the European Council has to become an official institution of the European Union, to take decisions, to steer the Union, and what we see today is exactly the opposite, the incapacity of the European Council to take a decision on this. So my question to you – I have only one simple question – is: when for God’s sake will the European Council take a decision on this migration issue, and when will you take responsibility?  I want also to urge you to do two things at the next European Council. I think there are two things you need to do. The first is to have this common position of Dublin; Mr Bullmann and others have already recalled this. But the second thing in my opinion is to do another thing, and that is to create as fast as possible, very urgently, what I call European reception centres in the transit countries so that we take our responsibility in these transit countries to give decent protection to these people, and that these people can ask in these reception centres for asylum, for protection, so that it is not necessary for them to jump into the arms and into the hands of these criminal gangs in Libya or in these gangs of human traffickers – because that is what needs doing at the moment.  And to media colleagues, the picture of the year – because everybody is talking today about what will be the picture of the year – will it be six European leaders humouring Mr Trump in Canada, or will the picture of the year be the handshake between Trump and Kim? I think, unfortunately, and to our disgrace, the picture of the year could be again another little Alan who is the victim of our bad policies on migration. I say to you Mr Tajani, I support you fully in what you said at the beginning of the debate. If the Council fails again at its next meeting, in my opinion we should really put the question if we have to invite Mr Tusk to our next meeting in July. Or more, I think we have to consider going to court under Article 265 of the Treaty. Article 265 of the Treaty will give the Commission and the European Parliament the possibility to go against the Council if the Council fails to act, which is the case here today.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the expectations for this summit were indeed rather high. A lot of things are to be decided at the summit. The eurozone reforms have been mentioned – and this would be high time because we have been having a kind of eurozone crisis since 2010, so it is not really early – and also Brexit. While this is a newer topic than 2010, it is also one with a very tight deadline just around the corner and a lot of problems to solve. Then, of course, there is the migration issue that has already been addressed by many colleagues. We all know that the current Dublin rules don’t work. We have been saying this for years here in Parliament. We have been making proposals for years about how to fix it and it hasn’t been getting better. We all know the pictures of overcrowded camps in Greece. We all know about the refugees living on the streets in Italy. We all know this constant blame game between different countries – whichever it is at the moment – and it is outrageous how this is going. It is always countries trying to say that they want the lowest number of refugees possible so the only thing they can ever do is close the borders, but that is not a policy that we can carry out as the European Union if we value anything of our own and if we stand at all for the human rights that we tell other countries that they should adhere to.  So Dublin urgently needs to be reformed. This Parliament has shown how it can be done. The thing about this Parliament is that we are not some sort of weird extra—territorial something parliament, but we are the same parties, the same countries, present here as are present in the Council and as are going to be present at the summit. So I wonder why it is that if we – same country, same parties – can come to an agreement, why can’t the Heads of State and Government do that? I really don’t see any reason, except for lack of political will and a lack of will to lead somewhere, to help people and to really go to the heart of the matter.  Without solidarity, our common European asylum policy is bound to fail, and Member States are already engaged in this vicious circle of deterrence and responsibility shifting. So yes, it is outrageous that Italy cannot follow the principle – the most basic humanitarian and sea law – but also, Malta has not wanted to open its port for years. We didn’t hear anything from France. So I’m really thankful to Spain, but this cannot be the only solution. We also see in other countries – Austria, Denmark, Germany – that everyone is closing their borders; everyone is settling on deterrence. So human rights have become a matter of campaigning in the European Union. We are doing politics – pretty much all parties are doing politics – on the back of those most vulnerable. I think that this is totally unacceptable in a European Union that is worth any of what Mr Timmermans mentioned before. It is also very interesting that the approaching Austrian Presidency has told the Bulgarian Presidency that ‘Dublin is dead’. That is probably also quite unprecedented.  On the eurozone reform – thank you for reminding us of that – it is urgent that we fix the problems there. The problems are known. There are solutions on the table and, while we Greens don’t agree with all the details of what Mr Macron has put forward, at least there is someone who has put proposals forward. So we should finally get somewhere and the German Government cannot hide any longer. They also need to get their act together, finally get real and offer something, because this is something that all Member States should understand. They should not hide behind what they call their national interests. Actually it is in their national interests to have a strong and functioning European Union and a strong and functioning eurozone. This is something that is in all of our interests. The world is turning less and less predictable. All the Member States should be so happy that they have a reliable and strong Union that they are part of and a strong partnership that they are part of, but they need to do something for it and they might even need to pay euro or two for it, but I think it is worth it.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the We are talking to the Commission and the current Presidency of the Council here in the European Parliament a few days before the next summit. All we can say is that it is now a ritualised form, that we meet here every time, then have a meeting again after the summit and state that we have not made any progress! I think this also has something to do with the way policy is present, both in the Member States and in the EU institutions. We take far too little account of what is happening in our societies, in the Member States, in the EU, and what is happening outside the EU. A lot of people are from outside the policy we offer. And we allow it, that, in the end, the whole problem, including that of the migration crisis, the asylum crisis, within the European Union, the inability to really develop common solidarity and feel responsible, leads us to the right, right-wing populists, right-wing extremists, nationalists, to roll out the red carpet and ultimately invite them to tell the people who live in poverty, to abuse them, to abuse their plight, to ultimately say that these societies are divided, and that we must oppose the idea of solidarity. I do not think that this can and must not remain the case. We have a shared responsibility here. And with regard to the ship, the Aquarius: Yes, thanks to Spain and also – as I had heard in the meantime – to the state government of Corsica to want to help here. But one thing is really clear: we cannot believe that we are actually able to develop a sustainable European Union policy that confronts the global problem of migration in the first place, with only spontaneous rescue operations. We can also – and I can see differences between us – but we cannot believe that, in the course of the Dublin negotiations, we believe that we are building a system of foreclosure, which also includes the blanket rejection of asylum seekers, of refugees from so-called 'safe third countries', for example.B from the Maghreb countries. We must also take note of the fact that the deals with Turkey and Libya remain very problematic. Mr Verhofstadt, you mentioned a number of figures a very few years ago. I would like to add one: since we have these deals, 3,000 people have drowned or died in the Mediterranean. This is also part of a realistic assessment of what we can do, what we need to do, what we are obliged to do. The Bulgarian Presidency has tried to draw up a proposal which I also do not think has been successful. I do not believe that it will work to say in a three-stage procedure that only in certain situations can other countries be expected to participate more or to provide greater financial benefits. The core problem will remain. Are the member states prepared to take in a minimum number of refugees together and to ensure that they act together and in solidarity with each other in crisis situations? That must be our point! That is what we are going to fight for! We are all calling for this! We need the solution now, not at some point! We cannot wait any longer for any government to have mercy on a ship. We have to create basic rules, and we should refrain from believing that if we build walls, then these walls are only directed outwards – they are also directed inwards. What we do not allow some of them to do is also restrict freedom in our European Union, in our Member States.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, one big problem facing the Council is, of course, Brexit and the big hole that it’s going to leave in the EU budget. But we’re not really any closer to leaving the European Union than we were the day after the referendum. Mrs May is a remainer who doesn’t really want to leave and, of course, as you found out, she couldn’t negotiate her way out of a wet paper bag. The whole process for the last two years has been about to delay and impede in the hope of eventually overturning the result of the referendum. This week the Commons votes on the Withdrawal Bill, and that’s entirely dependent upon this House voting on the Withdrawal Agreement later this year. Of course, you could vote against it. The whole thing then reverts to square one, like a game of political snakes and ladders. But it doesn’t have to be that way. Under the right leadership, Britain could leave the European Union quickly and decisively, and this is how it should be done. First of all, forget Article 50 – that’s your device, not ours. Parliament should repeal the European Communities Act of 1973 as a first step, and then we would have left under our law, not your law. We can offer you a free trade agreement with everything except the free movement of people, or trade on WTO terms. It’s going to be your choice anyway: take it or leave it, one way or the other. And we could easily reach an agreement on the reciprocal rights of citizens. Parliament can then repeal or amend all the EU-derived law in accordance with its own timescales and priorities, and I’m sure that can be done in a spirit of friendly cooperation with our good friends here in Europe. Her Majesty’s government shouldn’t be asking the European Union how it can leave; it should be telling you how it’s going to work. But, of course, that is never going to happen under Mrs May. Mrs May should go now and make way for a prime minister who actually wants to leave the European Union. That would be good for us, but it would actually be good for you as well.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, in Italy, after the speech, these are the deeds!  On Sunday, Italy's interior minister and deputy prime minister, our former colleague Matteo Salvini, took a strong first step. Sovereignly, on behalf of his country, he decided to ban access to Italian ports to a ship from Libya and won his tussle with the Maltese authorities. Chartered by a so-called humanitarian NGO, the ship was carrying more than 600 illegal migrants.  The smugglers' mafias that thrive on human trafficking, encouraged by the irresponsible rhetoric of some European leaders, led by Mrs Merkel, had promised these migrants a European Eldorado that does not exist, which no longer exists! The only solution to the migration challenge, the only truly humane, just and responsible solution, is the firmness of refusing this kind of permanent blackmail to human rights! Too much is too much! We can no longer take in "migrants." Basta! No way! Matteo Salvini thus applies the same method as Australia, which has allowed the complete drying up of the flow of illegal immigration to that country.  But then what are you waiting for? So what are you waiting for to finally hear from our peoples who are asking you to put an end, once and for all, to these totally anarchic migratory flows? There is an urgent need to protect our national borders and to implement genuine European cooperation to effectively defend external borders, drawing on the actions of Hungary yesterday and Italy today. The means, whether legislative, technological, financial or human, we have them! What we are missing, what you are missing, is real political will.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, the June European Council should be an opportunity to make strides towards the United Kingdom’s amicable and orderly exit from the European Union. Those who claim it is a last-chance saloon for a deal on the border limit what can be achieved. They fail to realise that agreeing future trade and avoiding friction on the border go hand in hand.  Yet, Mr Barnier continues to disrespect the integrity of the United Kingdom. The United Kingdom Government’s proposal on the backstop would apply to the entire United Kingdom. The Commission response has been to revert to the annexation of Northern Ireland as part of specific customs or regulatory arrangements. Let me be clear once again in this House: not only is this damaging to the economy of Northern Ireland, it is a position that the Prime Minister has said no British Prime Minister could ever agree to. Furthermore, it is damaging to community relations in Northern Ireland.  If a Brexit border solution is to succeed, it must find peace with both communities, and that includes the unionist community as well. This reflects a practical reality and is in line with the consent principle of the Belfast Agreement. We want to see a sensible solution without the infection of a political dogma, but our relationship must be about respect and reflect the realities of open trade.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mrs Panayotova – I am addressing you as a representative of the Council, of course – having listened to the words of all the political groups, given also what is happening with the Aquarius affair, with the disputes between Italy and Malta, if the Council had resolved the problem of the Dublin reform, there would not be everything that is happening today. The selfishness of the Member States risks making the situation worse rather than improving it. In this way, we are not solving either the problem of immigration or the problem of Africa. As you know, the European Parliament has also adopted, in one of the most recent resolutions, a text which insists on having more investment in the next Community budget for Africa. The problem of immigration is the problem of problems. There's a big delay.  I would ask you, on behalf of parliament as a whole, to ensure that the next Council is not just a Council where the Dublin and migration issue is formally discussed. Half a billion European citizens need answers and these answers have unfortunately not arrived and are not coming. We will continue to make our voice heard until the immigration issue is resolved until the problem of the Dublin reform is resolved.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, Madam President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has asked. I can go on to say seamlessly what our President has just said: we need a breakthrough on two issues at the European Council, at the summit: this is the issue of asylum, and that is the deepening of economic and monetary union. On the subject of asylum, I can only say that we need common rules that control and limit immigration. We cannot leave it to the people smugglers to decide who can or cannot come to Europe. I very much hope that progress will now be made at the summit. I would like to use my speaking time to talk about the deepening of economic and monetary union. Let me perhaps begin by saying – looking back – that the fathers of the euro actually did a good job more than 25 years ago with the Maastricht Treaty and with the Stability and Growth Pact, that we have actually created a working, firm framework, that sensible rules and mechanisms have been developed to keep the euro stable. After the financial and economic crisis of 2007, this has been further developed. However, I believe that the framework that was set at that time still applies today, namely that the Member States are also responsible for their own finances. This means that we should not move on to a debt union, to a shift of risk or liability. I believe that we should stick to the fundamental values of economic and monetary union. For me, the most important thing is still that the rules of stability are respected. This is the best protection against crises. If I send this in advance, I believe, ladies and gentlemen, that you can understand that I can only gain something from the proposals to deepen economic and monetary union in individual areas. I think it is a good thing that we are creating a European Monetary Fund. But here, too, I think it is important that conditionality applies. Conditionality is the be-all and end-all for me. In other words, aid yes, but against structural reforms, otherwise it simply does not work. We must finally address the enormous reduction in the risks of the banks. I would simply like to encourage this once again and perhaps ask the Commission again why we are not finally starting to move away from the zero weighting of government bonds. So I still do not understand why we do not weight loans and government bonds in balance sheets according to their risk.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Madam President, the European Parliament is being very clear – the next European Council can no longer delay key decisions and must make very clear choices. The world is changing, it is so clear, and it is also clear that we need a strong Europe, a united Europe, to protect people. The solution is certainly not closing the borders, but neither is the solution to keep open borders without protecting people. We need to have a Europe which is open but protecting people.  This is the case when we organise the European border. Of course we need to ensure that we have a proper European asylum system to protect refugees who are looking for our help, but when we negotiate trade agreements we need to ensure we are open to the world but we need to protect our people and our standards.  If we want a Europe that protects, the next European Council must push the negotiations on the European budget also for a budget which will be there to protect people. I am concerned, on behalf of my group, that the current proposal on the Community budget does not ensure the proper level of economic and social vision of cohesion. This is too weak to ensure our unity. The same applies to the proposals to reform the eurozone, because we don’t have proposals to ensure strong investment to converge, to ensure that the social pillar is really applied everywhere. So this is missing, and we want to strengthen European unity on the internal front, with a united Europe, for us to be able to cope with external challenges. This is the solution the next European Council should adopt without any kind of hesitation.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab According to Eurostat data for 2016, the Union has adopted an average of 4.6 migrants per 1000 inhabitants. In Poland it was 5.5 – Ukrainians, Belarusians, Georgians and other nationalities. No agreement was obtained on a compulsory relocation mechanism in the Council. This Minister should not be included in the draft Council conclusions.  And one more thing, the construction of the Nord Stream I gas pipeline allowed Russia to annex Crimea. What can we do by building Nord Stream II?

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Madam President, we have been getting used to seeing the failures of summits lately. I regret it very much that the EU Heads of State have consistently failed to show leadership on asylum reforms, and only last week we saw President Trump crash the G7 Summit. Leadership should now be exercised and the tyranny of low expectations should be left behind. It is now high time for Heads of State to rise above national egoism and show citizens all over the EU that we can deliver substantial, meaningful reforms of the Dublin Regulation, for which I happen to be the rapporteur. I know that some Member States – and also Members of this House – are tempted to declare the Dublin reform process dead and suggest instead some form of externalisation of responsibilities in the field of asylum, pretending that we can wave a magic wand and send the asylum seekers to faraway camps, which would of course be an enormous error for the simple reason that it would never work. Even if you ignore the obvious moral issues, there are still practical and legal issues. It would be a waste of time.  Instead, what we need today are practical solutions, not castles in the sky. It is now high time for the Council to join the European Parliament at the Dublin Regulation negotiating table. I can promise you that this House – and I, myself – stand ready for discussions. No more excuses and delays. It is high time to deliver. We owe it to the citizens of Europe.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, I’m sure I was not alone in feeling a cold shiver down my spine when I saw that chilling photograph of the world leaders at the G7. For those of us who believe in a rules—based international system, Trump’s deliberately disruptive behaviour in Quebec and at the United Nations, the World Trade Organization and now in Singapore is deeply disturbing. Trump’s treatment of Canadian Prime Minister Trudeau was despicable but typical of his bullying style. He doesn’t want to be isolated in a room-ful of cooperative world leaders, he wants to corner them one by one, so that he can make America great again at their expense. If the UK does go ahead with leaving the EU at a time when the global rules—based system is being shredded by Trump faster than the promises made by Brexiteers, we face a very dangerous future. That’s why I will be marching twice in London in the next few months: first on 23 June to demand a people’s vote on the Brexit deal, and then again on 13 July to oppose the visit of President Trump to the UK. Those of us who believe in democracy and the rule of law know that Brexit and Trump are two sides of the same coin – a coordinated attack on the global system that has ensured peace and prosperity since the Second World War. Both must be confronted and both must be overcome.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, we have perfidious Albion. The British Foreign Minister believes that worrying about Ireland is a folly. If Boris Johnson has his way then the border in Ireland will be hardened and strengthened. Positive and constructive proposals accepted by the British Government in December are rejected by them within days. Fantasy proposals are put in place instead. Perfidious Albion. And to buy a bit more time for the coalition agreement by the British Government and their allies in the Democratic Unionist Party – the Jurassic Party – agreements are torn up, and rights are denied.  Enough is enough.  The whole of the EU and Europe knows what needs to be done, and it is up to the Dublin government and to all of the EU Council Member to stand up to perfidious Albion in June and not to be persuaded by the disgraceful Irish Times editorial of yesterday, or by the nonsense by Diane Dodds MEP. The DUP do not speak for the people of the North on Brexit. The British Government does not care, unfortunately, about the people of Ireland – north or south – having to salvage ourselves from the Brexit wreckage.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in view of the forthcoming European Council, my thoughts can only go to the situation in the Mediterranean, where the idea of reforming the common European asylum system is foundering, where the idea of reforming the Dublin Regulation, which is deeply unfair to cross-border countries, is foundering, where the idea of radically revising the European project and demonstrating that the Union exists in the European Union is foundering. We have cross-border countries, such as Italy, which continue to be left completely alone. In Italy, landings must take place, identifications and registrations must take place in Italy. Italy must take charge of the first reception. The Dublin Regulation begins: Italy must be responsible for examining the application for international protection.  What are other countries doing? The other countries suspend Schengen, the other countries reintroduce internal border controls in order to armor everyone in Italy. So what could be more distressing in this whole debate? It is pointing the finger at each other, without understanding that if we are concerned about feelings of hatred, if we are concerned about the explosion of the European Union project, then we must show that the European Union exists and that there is still a lot to be done.  (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Nicola DANTI
text: "blue card" question. I believe that the rhetoric has no end in this House. We have now heard the representative of the Italian Government – those who are now in power in Italy, those in this House who voted against the reform of the Dublin system, those who last week, together with their Minister Salvini, finally brought the Dublin reform to the Council – tell us that it is a problem of immigration in Italy.  Mr President, I would like to ask Mrs Ferrara what only the Intentions of the Italian Government will be next week? You sunk Dublin last week, do you plan to resurrect it this week? Shame!

name: Laura FERRARA
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I would like to thank Mr Danti and immediately return the shame to the sender, because I would be very ashamed of you not knowing what was the European Council's proposal that further penalised Italy and why the 5 Star Movement voted against the position instead of the European Parliament. A compromise solution that did not see automatic relocation of asylum seekers, but was a filtered relocation, filtered by security and application merit verification procedures.  Instead, we want automatic and compulsory relocation. So rest assured that we have very clear ideas, it is probably you who have not made them clear and you have demonstrated this with your years of government so far in Italy.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we should make a monument to The Minister of the Interior, Mr Salvini, and to the entire Italian Government for throwing a stone in the pond, given that it has finally provoked this debate and the invitation of our President – with whom I agree – for the Council finally to take a decision and to take the issue of immigration seriously. A monument because it has awakened this absent, inattentive and even hypocritical, hypocritical Europe because you are for the reception, but the welcome to be made in the homes of the Italians, and the Italians have regained their sovereignty with this government, which is neither racist nor xenophobic since it assists minors and pregnant women much better than that, that is, nothing, that you have done so far.  So let us not do the usual pateracchio in the next Council, but let us look at decision-making solutions so as not to leave any country like Italy in the tragedy of immigration, for example by examining the proposal that has been made – with which I agree – to set up reception centres outside europe's borders in order to ensure a filter of those who deserve to be accepted because they have the right to asylum and to reject that economic immigration which is not in Europe's interest and which is perhaps only of interest to major interests. of your friends...  (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Madam President, the unilateral increase in tariffs on steel and aluminum and President Trump's cover-up at the G7 finally bring you back to reality. Finally, we hear here that we must free ourselves from American tutelage, which has hither been considered by many to be very comfortable. But I will believe it when we finally leave NATO, whose existence is no longer justified. I will believe it especially when you give up free trade negotiated with the whole world to return to the principle of reciprocity included in the Havana Charter of 1948. As for your migration policy, I will believe it when the examination of asylum applications is done exclusively from the countries of origin and not in our countries, where all the measures taken so far have had the effect of a call for air for new flows of arrivals. Mr. Bullmann and other speakers talk about pregnant women and children wandering on a boat in the Mediterranean; it is not Mr Salvini who is responsible for this situation, but rather the words of Mrs Merkel and yours that make them risk their lives. As for the discourse on human rights, I will believe it when real political refugees, such as Edward Snowden or Julian Assange, are welcome in the European Union.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not want to dwell on the Mediterranean because we have the debate on this tomorrow, but I would just like to say that I am a little surprised when I seem to see so much enthusiasm in protecting the right to immigration, which is a sacrosanct right, but a great deal of reticence when someone wants to protect the primary right of every person to live in his homeland and not to emigrate. So here I get some suspicion.  Having said that, I really do think that the Council needs to think seriously about how it is doing on so many issues. We here in Parliament do a lot of work and we manage to find summaries, we manage to find solutions that often fail, those that drown, within the discussions of a Council that is stuck in the rigid positions of countries that cannot find a synthesis as well. I see so many things that don't work. We have worked so hard here on PNR. PNR which, however, even if it is updated, with the holes that are in the various countries, will be a blanket full of holes. We have worked to set up something that costs the taxpayer and that will be a blanket full of holes. The same is the same for interoperability between the various databases. There is no point in having so many databases, if they do not talk to each other and here too so much taxpayers' money that is perhaps not put to good use.  Security is the first issue for the citizens, but if we really want to combine it with our values, listen to what The President of Parliament, Mr Tajani, said earlier: implement the reform of the Dublin Regulation voted for by Parliament, improve the case, but do not take those indecent, indecent backward steps that humiliate the European Union and all its citizens.  You also mentioned civil protection. We have worked hard, with a busy agenda, as you know, to strengthen civil protection and give security to our citizens in this area too. It seems that the Council is not yet ready for negotiations. Once again, we work and you slow down. You can't afford it.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In recent years, there has hardly been a summit that would not have dealt with the issue of refugees and migration. This could, in principle, be seen as an indication of the importance of a solution to the problem for the Member States. If that were the case, however, every summit would have to be followed by a series of measures. Unfortunately, that is not the case. The unresolved problems become more and more from time to time. And once something happens, it is poorly communicated. All of this has created a sense of insecurity among the population, and many people feel abandoned by Europe. It seems that this state of affairs is not so wrong for some leaders, because the game of fear has long since become a successful political business model. In the long term, however, this jeopardises the very existence of the European project, and it is therefore necessary for the Heads of State or Government to finally overcome this intolerable state of paralysis and engage with us in constructive negotiations on the asylum package. If that does not happen again, then we should take legal action.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The next Council meeting should definitely deal with the euro crisis. We have been hearing for years from irresponsible politicians that the euro has been saved, that the euro is a success story. That's a lie! The citizens of Europe are being lied to here: the euro crisis is more than ever. We see this very clearly in the events in Italy, where we are right to oppose the fact that the euro is creating a corset that Italy is not up to. The euro is currently artificially kept alive by a european central bank's zero interest rate policy and bond purchases. This is a scam against savers. Savers are being scammed for their interest. In this Parliament, we are dealing very intensively and rightly with the fact that we want to spend a million here or there. In the so-called TARGET2 clearing system in euros, tens of billions of euros of guarantees are due every month, and no one deals with them. No decisions are made at all. That is not right. We must finally face up to this question and create exit scenarios so that countries can leave the euro in an orderly fashion.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Madam President, in the meeting of the Council at the end of the month, I hope that the Member States will take a more firm position on migration than they have done so far. Have they, for instance, the political will to effectively reform Dublin? We don’t need nice words with no real political content. What happened two days ago, against international law, with the boat in Italy and Malta is just the latest scandal in which the EU must intervene, if it still has the capacity of speaking on its own and wishes to be taken into account.  The reaction of Valencia or of Barcelona or of Corsica, offering themselves to receive those migrants in danger, is a good example of humanity and decent politics. I hope you will talk in your meeting about these things. I hope you will explicitly mention those who are not living up to their responsibilities and that you will mention those who feel responsible for the needs of others. Something is now clear and urgent. To talk about the future of Europe means to talk about the Europe of the future.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say that I agree with the UN envoy, Mr Cochetel: European solidarity should not be discussed when a ship of suffering migrants arrives; the priority is to give them the safest port now, not to do so is illegal.  At the same time, we must recognise that Italy remains the country that is the first to register arrivals and that no reform of this unfair rule is in sight. The blockade of the ships is the poisonous result of the negotiating blockade on Dublin IV and uses migrants as hostages. If the European Council seeks unanimity on Dublin, it will confirm that there is rot in the Union. I would like to say to my government: take on the reform of Parliament; it has flaws, it is true, but it is as advanced as possible. A large part of the Council wants to kill it, look at you from allies like Orban: it will not accept the redistribution of quotas, it is not a friend of the Italian Government.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: "It's like a Dutchman flying across the Mediterranean is distracting a ship off the coast of Libya. It cannot sail to the ports of the European Union for a long time, because no country in the Community wants to solve the alien problems of its own through the eyes. Like the Indian tamahauk in the air every day, an axe is shining a war of trade between America and the European Union. The so-called rule of law policy of dissatisfied countries means its "dissent" means getting louder. There are disagreements over the new Budget of the European Union after the 20th. All this will be discussed, discussed at the Council meeting, but again only discussed, photographed, and again before the next meeting. I believe that citizens of Lithuania and other European countries need not photographs, we need good, decisive solutions, not a debate.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Madam President, you lot had better wake up. The world is moving on while you still sit there and discuss the same old thing, month after month after month. Trump and Kim: let’s celebrate it. Austria, Italy, Hungary, Poland, Slovenia: they’re all moving on. Your regime has become more and more irrelevant. In London on Saturday, 20 000 people attended a rally to free political prisoner Tommy Robinson, and those 20 000 people supported Brexit. In May, another 10 000 people marched in support of free speech. They too support Brexit. 17.4 million people voted for Brexit. They still support Brexit. The majority of the people want the government to get on with Brexit. You people entertain UK remoaners – the modern—day devil, George Soros: a foreigner kicked out of his own country, an open—borders billionaire who openly fights democracy. He openly pays MEPs to dance to his tune. You’re all suffering from DDD – democracy deficit disorder – and that’s why we’re marching again in London on 23 June. We want our country back.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Ms Atkinson, you are going too fast.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Don’t cut me off.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Could I just ask – can you listen? Because I think we can both speak English, so we can be very clear. What I was trying to do was help you communicate. You are going far too fast for the interpreters.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Yes, but do you know, I’m not speaking to all of them in here; I’m speaking to the UK. I’m speaking to Mrs May. I wasn’t sent here to talk to any of you. I was sent here to defend the British people. Most of you understand English. English is the language of the world. English is the language of this Parliament.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Ok, let’s calm down. Could I ask you, Madam, to sit down, with respect, and could I just say to you, as somebody who speaks very clear English: in this Chamber we are all elected by citizens, and the one remark that I had some concern about was your opening line, where you said ‘You lot’. Because, as far as I am concerned, we are all elected by citizens to represent our citizens’ many points of view. Thank you for your contribution. Colleagues, please, there’s no need for this. Stay calm. Madam is leaving the Chamber. Thank you and good morning.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, a class war is being waged across the United Kingdom and Europe, a class war that pits the snobbish sect of the upper classes against the working and unemployed masses. A snobbish sect that thinks the lower classes are too thick, too dumb, too stupid, for voting for populists and Brexit. A snobbish sect that pits the young against the old, the rich against the poor, the university-educated against those that didn’t go to university. A snobbish sect that have bribed and cajoled academics to support the EU with grants and awards, that have bribed lobbyist think-tanks and corporations with EU funding and subsidies and provided politicians with money and positions. A snobbish sect that today will unleash their crony cohorts of politicians in the UK Parliament to overthrow the Brexit bill. Well I hope those crony MPs and MEPs enjoy their 50 pieces of euro silver as they dump on the face of democracy and seek to deny Brexit. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, it seems that Mr Woolfe and Ms Atkinson are speaking only to the UK, to Mrs May and to the British people. Why are you here within the European Parliament? You should have to go home to speak, because here you speak to the Europeans, you speak to all the European Union countries and people. Why don’t you go home? Probably, it might be time.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card answer. – Madam President, I will be going home at the end of March 2019, thanks to the 17.4 million people that decided Brexit was a brighter future for Britain outside of the European Union. But I also do speak for those people up there who understand that there is a class war going on in Europe as well. A class war that is seeking to deny those who have been voted in in Poland and Hungary, in Slovenia. Those people who have voted for those in Germany in the AfD; for those in Holland, those in France, those who seek a different future for Europe, not an […]orientated future… (Microphone suddenly cuts out) … that you, and many MEPs in this Chamber, support.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President-in-Office, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would first like to note how I am sorry for what is happening in the Mediterranean Sea. What we are seeing is absolutely unacceptable. They have not heard from me a condemnation of Italy or Malta because I believe that the countries - in particular Greece, Italy, Malta, Spain - have been very abandoned by the European Union in the handling of the migration issue and, therefore, this is a collective responsibility of the 28. We cannot let human beings die in the Mediterranean Sea, we have to resolve this issue once and for all. Secondly, I would like to draw attention to the need for the Council to signal the progress of the reform of the euro area in order to consolidate the euro project, in particular by making good progress with the banking union and moving forward with another set of reforms aimed essentially at enabling a budget for the euro area to make this currency a currency that is friendly to all the economies that are part of the single currency. I would also like to say that it is essential to be quite firm on the issue of Brexit and, in particular, on the issue of the Irish border. This is an essential point which will, moreover, have developments this week, even today in the British Parliament. Finally, since you've brought it up, allow me to talk about the financial outlook. It is unacceptable that there is a policy of cohesion and convergence in which a country like Lithuania loses 23% of the funds and a country like Finland receives 5, a country like Italy rises 6 and a country like Croatia loses 6. This is not convergence, this is not cohesion, this is the opposite of convergence and cohesion, this cannot be accepted.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Apologies to Mr Jurek: you had indicated during the speaking time, so you have the floor for a point of order.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Article 11(3) of the Rules of Procedure obliges us to respect members with respect for Members, but even more so to respect our constituents.  Mrs Atkinson pointed out, but Mr Frunzulică, reacting to the speech of our colleague Mr Woolfe, questioned the legitimacy of the Members representing the British voters who voted for Brexit. Today they are still the same citizens of the State of the European Union as anyone. If we deny them the right to representation, we deny the democratic character of the European Union. I therefore ask the President to respond to such anti-democratic statements, which are moreover disrespectful, to which we are obliged by the Rules of Procedure.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Jurek, thank you for your point. The question allowed the speaker, Mr Woolfe, to respond, and he did so in due time. So I think we had quite a frank exchange, but thank you for your point.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: –Madam President, we have reached such a low point in the management of migration in Europe that a human decision, solidarity, intelligent and in line with international law, as has been adopted by the President of the Government of Spain, Pedro Sánchez, is an exception that fills us with hope.  It is true, as other colleagues said, that in Italy, Spain, Greece and Malta we are alone in managing migration. That is true, but we tell Mr Salvini that cruelty to other human beings can never be a victory.  We need to make a coordinated policy, and we have been saying it in this Parliament for years. And we have to say to the Council, 'You do nothing.' Yes, they do one thing: give gasoline to xenophobes in Europe. The Council's inaction is turning xenophobia into a galloping incessant policy.  Do something. This Parliament has told you how to reform the Dublin Regulation. Do something, because this is being Europe's main problem: they are undermining the credibility of the project and giving wings to all xenophobes and anti-Europeans. Do something, and let us congratulate the Spanish Government on being able to connect with the sentiments of many solidarity Europeans.  (She refused to ask her a question under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Sander LOONES
text: Thank you, Madam President. A year and a half is a long time in European politics. A year and a half ago, Mr. Verhofstadt was negotiating with Mr. Beppe Grillo. He wanted the Italian Five Star Movement in his ALDE group. Meanwhile, love seems to have cooled a bit. A year and a half ago, it was just about spreading, spreading, spreading migrants, as if that were the solution to the asylum and migration crisis. In the meantime, we are also talking about something else, we are talking about stronger European borders, we are talking about push backs, we are talking about more and better reception in the region. Little by little, the insights come, common sense comes, one sees that this is the only way to control mass migration, to crack human traffickers, and to finally stop those drownings in the Mediterranean. That is the view, at least for the Member States, but unfortunately still far too little in this European Parliament. That's why the next six months will be so crucial. Austria will then preside over the European Council. I wish Mr. Kurz every success in pushing this realistic agenda further into the future.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Madam President, despite the occasional declarations of social Europe, jobs, the fight against unemployment, growth, the Commission and the Council faithfully follow the barren and deadlocked neoliberal policy of austerity and deregulation of industrial relations, the policies leading to the dissolution of the social state, the widening of social and regional disparities, poverty and militarisation.  Funds are constantly being cut from programmes to support sustainable development and social cohesion, permanent internal troika mechanisms are being financed in the Member States, the new special defence fund is being financed for the benefit of the profitability of military monopolies. New border barriers are also being funded along the way to fortress Europe. As a GUE Group we insist that in order to achieve growth and create new jobs we need an investment shift towards social investment and programmes, we need public long-term investments that create permanent and decent jobs, investment in the real economy to reindustrialise the areas in need, investments that promote social development and solidarity between peoples.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Brexit is one of the points today, and for me it is unchecked into the budget, which totally ignores the loss of revenue that occurs when Britain leaves this house. Instead, high fees should be levied from the remaining Member States and own income will be created in the form of customs duties and the like. For Sweden, an increase of SEK 15 billion is proposed. Let me be very clear when I now say that Swedish taxpayers are not interested in paying additional fees to this house. We demand that the EU take responsibility for taxpayers' money and we demand that you take into account the loss of income that occurs when the UK leaves. If this is not done, it is the Swedish Government's duty and responsibility to the Swedish people to demand a renegotiation of the agreement, since we are now mostly being used as a cash cow by the EU.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, in your intervention, you said that after Brexit we will have a smaller budget - and so it is - and you referred to the fact that the Member States, the citizens, should contribute more. Don't you think that the Commission could, through very coherent measures, find other resources to fill the budget on the Brexit exit? For example, VAT evasion and tax non-payment evasion in the internal market? Thanks.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: answer ("blue card"). Thank you for the question. No, I don't think so. As far as VAT and taxes are concerned, it is a clear and clear national competence; There's nothing to be on this house. And the EU should not even seek the possibility of having its own sources of income; The EU must relate to the money it receives through membership fees. As far as sweden's case is concerned, we have always been a net contributor. I do not believe that we are getting what we are going to do from that agreement and therefore it should be renegotiated.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I am pleased to say that for more than five months – with a sharp increase in popular support – a government has been working in Austria that is finally stopping the illegal migratory flows, fighting Islamism, fighting crime and stopping these migratory flows that have been heading towards Europe since 2015 from the Austrian side. Against this background, it is an excellent thing that a person from our party alliance, Matteo Salvini, is also working in Italy as Minister of the Interior. And Matteo Salvini is right to finally stop the more than 600 people on the Aquarius, this ship, and to deny them entry to Italy. The key can only be that the people who are flocking to Europe here receive help on the ground. And when ships try to get to Europe, to help people, to give them food, to give them medicines, but to bring them back home to the port of origin and there in their regions to give help and not to bring everyone to Europe. That is the wrong way to go.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, the European Union has become a tail of developments, which it follows rather than shapes. It is evidenced by the expected but poorly prepared conflict with the US at the G7 summit, its misguided and disastrous responses to Russia's annexation of Crimea, Turkey's handling of its blackmail with a weapon of illegal immigration, the treatment of Daesh resulting in an increase in terrorism.  To all this comes the underground blackmail of a non-existent politically, ethnically criminal, left-wing Greek government, which says to everyone 'yes', only to be kept in power.
