A blackmail on the part of the Union through Germany on the issue of the name of Skopje, promoted without counting that any ownership of the Greek name of Macedonia could trigger armed conflict and instability in the Balkans. If we want a united Europe, we should not rely on the 'divide and conquer' principle in the interests of certain countries, but on the needs and demands of our citizens.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam Chairman, there are many topics at the next summit, from Brexit, the multiannual financial framework, the defence union. But it still seems to me that the topic that will dominate this session is the topic of migration. Migration needs to interest us the most and I am convinced that no country can deal with this problem alone and therefore from this place I urge the European Council to finally embark on the adoption of the Dublin reform and asylum rules. Big problems, we've all seen, are emerging in Italy, but you have problems again and on the so-called Balkan route, you have problems through Bosnia and Herzegovina, where new migrations are happening and coming to Croatia's borders. You know that Croatia is a country with 1300 kilometers of the external border of the European Union, and at the same time we have a wire on the Hungarian border, on the Austrian border, on the Slovenian border. We don't think wire is the answer, so we need to solve this problem together through an asylum system. It also seems to me that Schengen is very shaken. If we put checks within the Schengen borders, then at the same time the whole Union is shaken. Therefore, I think the solution is that croatia finally gets political consent together with Romania and Bulgaria to enter the Schengen area and thus solve problems together. In any case migration will be the dominant topic, but much stronger engagement is expected on the part of the Council and that finally the Dublin rules are adopted in line with what Parliament has already adopted before.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I say to the Council, very heartfeltly: if you are not completely unconscious – and I say this also to the Commission – you have a duty, at the June summit, to give some concrete answers with regard to at least immigration, take a decision.  Do you want to give answers – and Parliament has put a stop to this with the reform of the Dublin Summit – or you want to wait for all populist governments, as in Italy, to stand up for themselves, to campaign permanently, regardless of a minimum of civilisation, a minimum of values, and take people's lives hostage in the Mediterranean. , how are they doing, or taking people 1,400 kilometers away? Look at the map: where is the ship's location at the port of Valencia? Is this possible? And whose responsibility is it too? They, of those who make this fake policy, these Pyrrhic victories, but it's also yours. If you continue not to look at reality, if you have not answered the appeals we have made, the parliamentary actions, the political actions that the previous Government and we Italian Parliamentarians did, you will succumb under this harshness, under those who use human beings as pressure, I would like to say as human bullets, with a gun pointed at Europe, that Europe in which we believe.  We will not succumb to this cultural and social drift. However, this Europe must get under way and the Council must do its part now, in June, and in the right direction.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Madam President, the Dublin reform should be forgotten. Distributing asylum seekers hasn’t worked and will not work. It only encourages more migration from sub-Saharan Africa and elsewhere.  Recently, Italy refused entry to an NGO boat full of migrants. That was the right thing to do. In the Mediterranean, we are seeing a repetition of what happened at land borders in 2015. First, one Member State finds the courage to do the right thing and close the border, next that Member State is heavily criticised by everyone else. Finally, other Member States do exactly the same thing.  Systematic pushbacks at external borders, better returns policy and strict adherence to the first safe country principle are the only realistic way forward. Our obsession with relocation only postpones decisions that are both necessary and inevitable.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, we consciously believe in the European Union. We believe in the strength, the potential, the values of the European Union and we believe that without the European Union Europe has no future, neither the peoples nor the member countries of the European Union have a future. We believe that the European Union is the present and the future of all of us, which is why we are defending it with all our might. But a prerequisite for continuing to have a strong, strong, united, credible European Union is that the European Union itself respects its principles and values. Quite rightly, the European Union has imposed sanctions on countries that do not apply the principles, values and rules of the European Union. At the same time, however, since 2005 it has been financing with billions of euros a country that violates all the principles of international and European law, a country that does not recognise a member country of the European Union, the Republic of Cyprus, a country that today we are talking about violates human rights, threatens Member States of the European Union, Greece and Cyprus, while recently threatening Austria and the whole of Europe with religious war. And we continue to reward her. In this way, however, the European Union is effectively losing its credibility, its strength, its principles and its values. Dear friend, Vice-President of the European Commission, Mr Timmermans, you have also experienced Turkish intransigence and provocation in Crans-Montana, where you quite rightly defended the positions of the President of the Republic of Cyprus Nicos Anastasiades that in Cyprus the European acquis should be applied, the troops should be withdrawn, guarantees and invasive rights abolished. Can the European Union continue to tolerate turkey's attitude and behaviour? The same question I would like to ask the European Council, which must finally assume its responsibility and ensure that the European Union respects its principles and values by applying the laws and rules for all countries.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Madam President, all European Councils are important, but the one in June has a special character. This is the last opportunity to demonstrate that Europe refuses to remain paralyzed in the face of the migration issue. It is a question of credibility for the 28, it is their responsibility. The subject on which the Council must get out of the rut is the revision of the Dublin Regulation, everyone agreed today.  We have done that in Parliament, when there are many more of us and sometimes much more diverse, so it is not an impossible mission. But for that to happen, heads of state must stop covering their faces. Migration will not stop overnight, and they are obliged to find a shared solution, otherwise what will happen is quite simple: each Member State close to a migration route will continue to spend its energy pushing people across the border or at sea, without finding or even looking for , moreover - structural response. In this context, it is quite clear that the European elections in 2019 will be the scene of a hysterical political exploitation of the subject of immigration, to the detriment of all others, and in a way, I am sorry, this is also what happened today.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her How private, how protected is our communication? The confidentiality of communications is a fundamental right, and with the so-called – other topic – ePrivacy regulation, this should finally also apply in the digital environment. Parliament has been ready for launch since autumn 2017, but member states in the Council are on the brakes, even after the Cambridge Analytica revelations and millions of data abuses. A date last Friday again did not produce any results. The Council is influenced by the large corporations and thus prevents clear regulations for platforms such as Facebook. Privacy and fundamental rights for citizens do not seem to be important to the Council. That is why I am making a clear appeal to governments: before you get involved in ever-new legislation, you will finally deliver results on ePrivacy, the protection of communication and, ultimately, democracy!

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: – Madam President, today the lives of more than 600 people are at risk: children , more than 120 unaccompanied minors – women and men who knock on Europe's doors fleeing war and hunger. And, in the face of this reality, the attitude of the Italian Government, refusing to rescue, shows the darkest face in Europe: the one that looks the other way, the one that makes populism and xenophobia a danger to Europe. Mr Salvini will have to be reminded that, no matter how much victory he sings, there is something he cannot recover and it is decency and dignity. But there is a space for hope, and the Government of Spain offers to welcome these people, fulfilling international commitments and responding to a humanitarian crisis. This gains the moral authority to demand more European policy in the Council in this regard. Some people feel patriotic for wrapping themselves in a flag. Today we are many more who are proud of the country, pride of a solidarity Spain that serves those who need it most.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Madam President, there are only three weeks to go to the next European Council, but there is no sign that the British will be at all ready for the discussion that will take place there on Brexit. Two years after the referendum, it does not even have a starting position for the negotiations as regards a key issue such as what kind of customs arrangements we might have for a future. It has now promised a white paper to set out its vision for the future, which will only be published after the European Council, well after two years after the referendum.  Only yesterday, Theresa May was forced to plead with her own Conservative MPs not to vote against her in the key votes that will take place today in the British House of Commons and tomorrow. She is desperately trying to avoid defeat at the hands of her own MPs. Personally, I hope enough of them will put country before career, patriotism before party and Britain before a bad Brexit.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear governments, you have had the Dublin reform on the table for two years, it is shameful that you still do not agree on internal solidarity. Your selfishness is holding the Union hostage. On 28 June in the Council, take the example of this Parliament which, after lengthy negotiations, voted by an historic majority to remove the criterion of the first country of access and replace it with automatic relocation which obliges all European countries to play their part.  Financial solidarity is not enough and we will not agree to negotiate the dossiers you want, without changing Dublin. Your inertia has opened the door to nationalist and fascist resurgence in our countries. Mr Macron, Chancellor Merkel, if you do not want your Europeanism to be just a façade, support our proposal to the Council, which is the only truly European. Mr Orban, you cannot just want the benefits of being part of the Union without ever sharing responsibility. And the Italian Government will stop being cowardly: the battle is being fought in the Council and not on the skin of the people at sea. It is time to give substance to solidarity. Time has run out and I would remind you that you have all signed treaties which involve the principle of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Change of subject: the Council will also deal with the Western Balkans, and we should make it clear once again from here: we believe that it is time to act. A new wind is blowing in Macedonia – the treaty with Bulgaria has shown it – and we should be appreciative of what the Tsipras government and the Zaev government are making serious efforts to resolve the name issue. There has been significant progress in Albania, and when it comes to the rule of law, things are developing much better here than elsewhere, including in the EU. It is now up to us to keep our word. Open the negotiations with these two countries! Open new chapters with Serbia and Montenegro! And remember this summer that Kosovo has fulfilled its conditions to obtain visa-free travel. At the same time, we need to reform the EU – we all know that. But you can do it in parallel, because the start of negotiations does not mean that you get in automatically and that it will be very short. The Council must now prove that we are serious, that we want the people of the Western Balkans. They deserve it. In any case, a Balkan summit every 15 years is not enough.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union's problem is the slowness in deciding. The Member States must be aware of this and agree to always vote by majority vote, when this is already possible, and they must use the bridging clause, that is, the transition to majority voting in all matters for which the unanimity rule applies today. Otherwise it will never be possible to decide, and we need a Europe capable of taking decisions. There are many issues. First of all, almost all my fellow Members have mentioned the new Dublin Regulation. Secondly, we need a decision on own resources, which are not sufficient – the Commission's proposal, which was opposed, is not enough – and on an appropriate level for the Union's budget. We need a decision on a package of policies for the euro area and, finally, we would like to know, and I am asking Vice-President Timmermans in particular, how and how we can achieve the roadmap on the future of the Union as fully as possible.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a great modern thinker, Antonio Gramsci, in 1930 from prison, describing what was happening in Italy and Europe, wrote that, when the old world dies and the new world is late to appear, it is precisely in this chiaroscuro that monsters are born. And that is a bit of what is happening, and not by chance, in this old continent of ours, and we are noticing enough of it.  I am concerned about the blindness of the European ruling class, I am concerned about the indifference of European politics, I am concerned about the disarming normality of the Council's action in the face of these extraordinary changes.  Dear Representative of the Council, Aquarius is simply the tip of the iceberg to which the European Titanic is pointing. There is not much time to change course, and not doing so will historically make you responsible for this dangerous European drift.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Madam President, Vice-President, Madam Representative of the Council, the European Parliament respects the existence of the European Council, in fact, but I have the impression that the reciprocal is not always true. In view of the stakes of this European Council, I am still surprised that Mr Donald Tusk never considers it useful to come and exchange with parliamentary representation. Because in what context are we? We have just experienced a G7 where President Trump seems to ignore transatlantic solidarity or even good transatlantic cooperation. We are in a context where Mrs Theresa May, after taking over as head of a government organising Brexit, is unable to say what she wants for her country's future. All this places a huge responsibility on the European future when this Council will have to deal with both migration issues, the issue of eurozone reform and the defence issue. We would therefore like to know how Mr Tusk intends to propose a roadmap on the future of the European Union in order to obtain a good agreement in relation to these three indispensable elements, so that each of our fellow citizens can continue to have confidence in the European Union and do not turn his back on it, as we have just seen in Italy.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, the Council has several topics on its agenda, but I believe that it should, above all, address the issue of tackling migration. If we really want to stop the rise of populism and the rise of extremism in the Member States. I would therefore like to ask, the EP has out-voted for a minority who disagreed with the LIBE report on the common asylum system, dublin IV. I would like to ask where the Council is going, whether the Council also intends to vote on this issue by a qualified majority. If the Council also intends to over-vote on those who disagree and are still in the minority on this issue and want a position that is consensual, that is not coercive and that tackles the issue of migration so that there is flexible solidarity.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the new Italian Government has closed its ports and has not allowed a ship, the Aquarius, with 630 people on board, including pregnant women and children, to dock, speculating politically on the skin of the last and the defenceless. I would like to thank Spain and its new Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez very much for his gesture.  But Italy has been left alone for too long to cope with the flow of migrants from the rest of the Member States, gathering only fine words. The increase in the funds allocated to immigration in the next budget will also serve no purpose under these conditions. More and more often we hear that Europe is to blame, that Europe must do something, that Europe has left the Mediterranean countries alone, but we know that this is not the case. It is the Member States which, out of political interests, paralyse the Europe of Schuman, Adenauer and De Gasperi. This Parliament has been approved by the Dublin reform for months. The Council must respond immediately and concretely, because in the meantime human beings are dying and populist forces are advancing.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the latest developments on the Aquarius ship have shown that the European Council must act immediately to deal with the increased migratory flows. And that means that Dublin III, which has turned Greece and Italy into a vast repository of souls, must be abolished here and now.  Greece cannot afford other refugees and illegal immigrants. The Aegean islands and Evros have been flooded by thousands of illegal immigrants. But until the European Council decides to act, Greece must activate Article 72 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union on grounds of public order and security and suspend the operation of Dublin III, as well as the functioning of the Schengen Agreement, in order to finally stop Greece being a magnet for the thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants whom Erdogan and the slave traders are channelling into our country.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, the European Council and the States must respond to the calls for solidarity of the vast majority of European citizens, who do not accept that we let people die at sea. The Spanish Government has decided to receive the 'Aquarius', and the Basque lehendakari has offered to welcome 10% of these persons in the Basque Country for dignity and respect for fundamental rights.  The Basque Country is a small country. Solidarity welcomed the Basques when we sought protection or wanted to overcome poverty, and we owe it to those who now need the same thing. Therefore, when the first quota allocations were made, the Basque Country has already organized an operational and effective interinstitutional response to take our share. It has not been able to take advantage until today because our Member State had simply failed to fulfil its obligations in this area.  Mrs Panayotova: there are ways to solve this problem, you just have to mobilize them. There is a lack of political decision and courage to confront xenophobia and anti-Europeanism with humanity and solidarity. Mr Timmermans: opening up European borders is a global decision, but welcoming and integrating migrants is a challenge that local and regional communities respond to. When do you think this level should be fully integrated into the design of the immigration solution?  (The president withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Union demonstrates its true nature. Migrants sinking into the Mediterranean, boats at risk with pregnant women and children, are in the cold inhumaneness of those who choose to criminalize humanitarian organizations involved in search and rescue operations. Resources are lacking for cohesion, to support investment in the countries that need it most, to support employment with rights and to combat inequalities and asymmetries, but as the next European Council will demonstrate, there is no shortage of resources for the European military industrial complex, to crack down on migration and migrants, there is no shortage of resources to further inflate the profits of multinationals of major European powers , and the so-called structural reforms are not lacking. Another way of saying: withdrawal of rights and privatization of the social functions of the State.  The announced reform of the euro is but another way of tightening the ties that hinder the sovereign development of peoples. Defeating the EU to save Europe is a demand with enhanced timeliness.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, the meeting ahead is very important. A year before the European elections, it is important to be able to promote all the issues that we have discussed in recent years and which are essential for the future of Europe.   We have made good progress in some sectors, such as the EU's defence and security sectors. More money has now also been proposed for this in the financial framework, and we know that many measures in this area have progressed very positively. It is necessary for Europe to take more responsibility for its own defence, and security is one of the most important areas in which we need to make progress.  Instead, I hope that the forthcoming summit will also talk very seriously about the European value base, that is, that when we join the Union, we will all be committed to Europe and to defending common democratic values. Now some Member States are slipping away worryingly from these. This issue must now also be raised seriously at the Summit of Heads of State or Government.  It is very good that, in future, funding from the Member States will also be committed to the rule of law. It is very important for the future of Europe.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I must tell you that I agree with everything you have specified here. The European Union is at a crossroads. You have presented that, for the first time since 1945, we have an American president who ignores the relationship with the European Union. You also told the Council that it must be decided. We agree here.  The problem is that if the Council puts on the agenda - and I have been very careful about what the Council representative has presented to us - so many topics and all very important, I do not think that any decision can be taken. And it's important to make decisions.  You have announced that certain things have been postponed. Members, representatives of the Member States must take into account the interest of the European Union if we are to have it again, if we are to have no Eurosceptics, not national interests. And I think this is the key to success in the regulations we take. Because, yes, we're here reaching a consensus and we're 751. I do not understand how 28 states, 27 states cannot reach a consensus on an interest of the Union, the internal market, our trade, the protection of workers and everything we have discussed here today.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Mr President, here I respectfully address Council. I for one have had enough of meaningless speeches about addressing the immigration issue during Council summits – but then you do nothing. Frustration is understandable, and I place the blame on those Member States who want to do nothing about the immigration issue. No Member State – except two, Malta and Ireland – fulfilled their allocation of quotas from Italy and Greece. With all due respect, where are the others? What solidarity do you believe in? I commend Spain’s decision to step in in the MV Aquarius situation, but that ended only this particular situation. Because boat crossings from Libya will not stop, particularly in the summer, and they will most likely increase. So let’s see how interested the Member States are in actually addressing this issue and not continuing to put it on the back burner, because so far they have not been prioritising this at all, and instead they preferred to pass the buck from one to the other.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Timmermans, the Group President, Mr Weber and Mr Verhofstadt, listed long lists of problems facing the Union, which should be discussed at the European Council. There was talk of immigration, of the euro, of trade, but no one spoke – perhaps with the exception of our colleague Anna Fotygi – of Nord Stream 2 and of an aggressive energy policy towards at least a quarter of the countries in the east of the European Union. When the Americans denounced the Iran nuclear deal, European companies began to worry about whether they should not take into account the positions of the United States government. The European Union, on the other hand, talks a lot about solidarity, and it cannot in the slightest persuade German companies to respect the policies of our unfortunately rather fictitious sanctions.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, Europe is adrift because it is a ship that represents shame, it is a boat that leads to the indifference of power. I want to tell the Council and the Commission to show humanity by listening to the xenophobic and racist stooes of this Parliament. Do you want to be complicit in these dehumanized policies? Do you want to be accomplices of states that look the other way while 600 human beings can die in the middle of the sea? Pregnant women and children who could be our children? Do we want to be a cemetery at sea?  Speed up the Dublin Regulation. We need common rules for asylum seekers. It is necessary to give a humanitarian order in Europe to save lives. It is so difficult to understand it when this chamber is full of xenophobes and racists who have no humanity - and that has to be said! And we must help precisely for humanitarian reasons, to avert a catastrophe and to give Europe a minimum of dignity, a minimum of dignity!

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Ladies and gentlemen, first of all with regard to the discussion around European Union/NATO cooperation and the directions for further defence work, I would like to stress that the strategic partnership between the European Union and NATO is fundamental to meeting the security challenges and that the actions of these two organisations should be more complementary in terms of security in order to better cope with the unprecedented and multifaceted new challenges in this area, in the east and the south. Finally, I would like to reiterate, with regard to the aspects of employment, growth and competitiveness, the commitment to strengthen efforts in order to bring the Single Market Strategy, the Digital Single Market Strategy, the Capital Market Action Plan and the Energy Union to a successful end to the current legislative cycle. The European Union must continue to work towards the completion of a sustainable and equitable single market adapted to the digital age and facilitating European competitiveness, innovation, sustainability and cohesion, as this is quite important for the countries of Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very I am a little surprised by this debate. Given that Chinese policy and its clear strategic, political and economic interests are pushing us further back, Putin's war policy, Mr Trump's behavior, the right is talking about the dissolution of the European Union, and the left has no concept either. At this European Council, we need decisions on how to proceed with distribution policy, how we can achieve the right of asylum, how we can achieve a decent Africa policy and that we have to pay for all this with money; that we get a clear regulation here. And we also need a more resilient European Economic and Monetary Union. These are tasks that we must solve in the reform programme in order to deal with the issues and, at the same time, to be able to win back our citizens for this Europe. And those who do not follow this line, right and far left, must know that they are selling their own peoples to the Americans, to the Russians, and to the Chinese.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, it is expected that this time the European Council will not take any substantive decisions. After all, we are used to approaching serious issues not pragmatically, but with a philosophical disposition and wishful thinking. It does the same with the serious issue of illegal immigration. Instead of taking decisions and measures to stop the ongoing flows mainly to Italy and Greece, it is apathyly monitoring the situation, seeing some states closing their borders and letting the countries of entry deal with the problem on their own. Now most countries in the European Union blame Italy for doing the obvious to protect the country. But three days ago, when Erdogan denounced the agreement with Greece on the return of some illegal immigrants, no one reacted. Who has the right to turn Greece into a vast camp of impoverished, illegal immigrants? And if at some point Greece takes action and closes its borders, then what happens? Will Greece be accused of being xenophobic?

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, there’s a lot of talk about borders this morning in this debate, and – rightly so – around migration. I want to talk about a border that isn’t a border, much closer to my home in the Republic of Ireland, as it borders invisibly with Northern Ireland. I have to say that, while I welcome a paper from the United Kingdom on their proposals for a temporary customs arrangement, it is, to say the least of it, insufficient and incomplete, and I am really troubled that time is marching on. But we have to have faith in politics, and we will watch the UK House of Commons with great interest this week. I listened very carefully to the exchanges on Ms Dodds, and can I say to her very directly: there is no disrespect to her position; there is no annexation of Northern Ireland; and indeed to Martina Anderson, both of whom have left this Chamber: could they please sit down in an assembly in Northern Ireland and properly represent the people of Northern Ireland, so that their voices can be heard in this vital debate?

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I have been listening very carefully to the debate on migration, and having dealt with this issue over the last four years, I try to formulate for myself why it has been impossible to find a solution so far at the European level. I think the answer lies in the concept of moral hazard. There is a lack of confidence between the Member States that the other state will do what they agreed to do to find a solution. Indeed, Italy and Greece for a very long time complained and said ‘you’re leaving us alone; we need to find a solution; Dublin doesn’t work; we’re swamped; we’re overwhelmed by the numbers of refugees arriving’. And then for too long they got the answer ‘that’s Dublin, deal with it. It’s your task’.  And then of course, we arrived at a situation of waving through, and this led to a lot of suspicion in other Member States: they’re not doing their job; they’re waving through refugees in large numbers. So there is no state that can claim to be completely innocent in the situation we have found ourselves now.  I also believe there is some criticism possible if people in Italy keep saying ‘we were left completely alone; we were completely abandoned’. Yes, for a long time that was true, but I find it difficult to explain that when I go to Germany. Look at the numbers of refugees that were taken in in Germany. Look at the number of refugees that were taken in in Sweden. An incredibly vast problem is now the integration of these refugees in many countries. As long as we keep refusing the idea that we have a collective problem that can only be tackled with collective solutions, we will not find a solution. As long as Member States just stick to their own solution and say ‘we are the only ones who are right’ and as long as the rest of the Union does not do what we do, we will not find a solution. And we will fail collectively.  Given the size of the migration challenge the world faces, not just Europe, given the developments in Africa, do you really think that building walls and fences and refusing to accept ships is going to bring a solution? Will that stop the pressure? Do you really think that if we do not stick together on this, individual Member States will be able to reach agreements with the states of origin to take back their migrants if they do not have the right to asylum? Do you really think that, individually, we can create a prospect for Africa that will allow young Africans to see a future in their own countries instead of feeling the need to come to Europe? Do you really think that if we take away a bit of the humanity of people on ships and say these are just migrants, that we will continue our policy on the basis of our values and human rights? Don’t you agree that by denying other people’s humanity, we take away part of our own humanity? Doesn’t that kill us morally if we continue like that? I am not saying everyone who wants to come to Europe should be welcomed, but I am saying we need to put an end to the dying in the Mediterranean. This can only be done if Europe collectively devises stronger protection of our external borders; if we finally devise a common European asylum policy; if we finally make headway in having agreements with the countries of origin so that they take back the citizens; if we finally have a realistic plan of investment in Africa so that Africa develops in a way that makes people want to stay in Africa; and if we finally come to terms with the fact that in a time of crisis, and one or two or three of our Member States are overwhelmed, they should be able to count on the solidarity of all Member States. The only way we will find a sustainable solution for the migration issue – which will not go away, whatever we do – is if we do all these things at the same time. According to your political preferences, you have a preference for one or other of the solutions, but none of you can close your eyes to the fact that you can only deal with it if all these solutions are part of our approach. And if we do not do this as Europeans, who else will? Member States will not be able to do it on their own, whatever their policies are. Let me end on one point. We are at a risk, in this time of turbulence and huge challenges, of falling into the trap of entering into Faustian deals. To handle the migration issue, perhaps we should not have as much of the rule of law or the respect for human rights as is good for us. Please, please, stay away from that Faustian deal, because you will lose on all scores. What is the price of unity of the European Union? Should the price of unity of the European Union be ‘let’s not make a point of the rule of law and human rights just so we can have unity’? I can guarantee you if respect for the rule of law and human rights is no longer a quintessential element of our Union, we will lose human rights, the rule of law and the European Union. That is a price that is far too high to pay.  (Applause)

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I am here today to intervene on the state of play of the preparations for the European Council and to listen to your proposals, ideas, comments and remarks. I will bring all of them to the attention of the President of the European Council. I would like to thank the President of the European Parliament, Mr Tajani, for his remarks with regard to the important input made by the European Parliament in the discussion on the Common European Asylum System, in particular on the Dublin Regulation. I will bring his message to the attention of President Tusk. You will also have heard that President Tajani will have the opportunity to express the views of the European Parliament to the Heads of State and Government at the opening of the European Council. Tomorrow, we will have a further opportunity to discuss the humanitarian emergencies in the Mediterranean and solidarity in the European Union. All of you underlined that reform of the asylum system needs to strike the right balance between responsibility and solidarity. I can assure you that the Presidency also shares your sense of urgency. I would like to share with you that the Bulgarian Presidency has taken as its point of departure not only the conclusions of the European Council of October 2017, which tasked us with seeking consensus and with looking for ways to keep the right balance between responsibility and solidarity in order to ensure resilience to future crises, but also the results of the negotiations under the previous Presidencies, which called for a comprehensive approach to the whole area of asylum reform.  Based on this, we have built into the Dublin Regulation a new approach and a new crisis mechanism for managing the migration and asylum systems in the Union when under pressure. It tries to strike a balance between responsibility and solidarity by including clear criteria for determining the responsibility for asylum applicants which don’t shift or seize easily. The amended rules make the procedure more efficient so that pull factors and secondary movements are effectively prevented. We believe that the text of the Dublin Regulation, resulting from the discussions led by our Presidency in the last five months, offers a good and fair basis for striking the requested balance between responsibility and solidarity. The process is now being led by the President of the European Council, and it will be up to him and the leaders to look for further compromises that will help reach a consensus in view of the meeting of the Heads of State and Government at the end of June. I am confident that the Council will make every effort to find a solution and an agreement on a mandate for negotiations with the Parliament, as we all agree that Dublin III needs to be revised.  In terms of the trade questions, I would like to say that the European Union is sending a strong message on its ambition for an open, rule-based trading system, and all trade and external relations are on the agenda. But I cannot prejudge the outcome of the leaders’ discussion. In terms of the eurozone and the completion of the banking union, we also cannot prejudge what the leaders will decide at the June Euro summit, but I would like to say that the Presidency worked hard so that the Council could finally agree on a general approach on the banking package last month. The Council certainly looks forward to working with the Parliament to bring this file to implementation, hopefully still in the coming months. Progress on the banking package gives me reason to be optimistic that the leaders can, later this month, reach concrete results around the issue of the common backstop to the Single Resolution Fund, likely in the context of the broader and not yet finalised work on the European Stability Mechanism. Progress on the European Deposit Insurance Scheme will take more time, but it has not been ruled out that the political discussions could still start in the coming months.  In terms of Brexit, I would like to say that unity among our institutions is paramount, and we value the contributions that the European Parliament is making through its resolutions. We expect this to continue until the end of the negotiations. We attach the utmost importance to safeguarding the rights of European Union citizens in the United Kingdom and vice versa, and to those citizens being able to effectively enforce their rights. The UK has given credible guarantees to this effect, as now translated in the text of the Withdrawal Agreement. It remains to ensure that this is implemented in a faithful and enforceable way.  There are actually many other important issues on the table for the leaders in June, and it would be really naive to expect that they can all be solved easily and rapidly. Some will require further time and effort, but it’s important to continue to build common ground. In accordance with well—established practice, President Tusk will be in plenary on 3 July 2018 for an open debate with you on the progress achieved on those topics, for, in the face of global turbulence, we should make sure not only that we remain united in dealing with the immediate consequences of instability, but that we – the three institutions together – also continue to work to shape the course of the years ahead in the interests of our citizens.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. In order to prepare for the European Council, it is important to me that we focus on the most important points. Europe is surrounded by crises and problems. This makes it all the more important that we do not describe major objectives at the European Council, but work in a concentrated manner on important points. We are on the way to a trade war. We need a clear European line here. In my view, the Commission's united countermeasures are the right way forward, and this must be confirmed by the Council. We need to focus on the core tasks. At the moment, it is not time for visions, but for pragmatic and solidarity-based solutions.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – What do you prefer to eat: a small portion prepared by prestigious chef bosses, from fresh natural ingredients, or a huge bowl of junk food? Where do you prefer to live: in a house designed by a brilliant architect or in a Tower of Babel erected by a lot of unskilled workers? In short: do we want quality or quantity? Do we want a better Union or a greater Union? At this historic moment, the answer is one! We need to go back to what unites us without compromise and leave the divergent issues to the later. I strongly support the idea of the European Parliament sending a clear message to the Council: decisions on the future of the Union must be taken by consensus! Any important decision taken by qualified majority weakens unity, increases inequalities and corruption, undermines democracy and compromises our future.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the question with request for an oral reply to the Commission on the package on economic and monetary union, by Roberto Gualtieri, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (000047/2018 – B8-0027/2018) (2018/2724(RSP)).

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this debate of ours is taking place at a decisive stage for the future of Europe and the euro area. We acknowledge that the Commission has put on the table a wide range of proposals outlining the pillars of a more complete economic and monetary union that is better able to generate growth, employment, cohesion and shock resistance. We note, however, that some of these proposals define more of the instruments that we need to be fully implemented and that remain critical. The most important proposal is undoubtedly the introduction of a macroeconomic stabilisation instrument, through an investment protection fund, during the adverse phases of the cycle. This is a decisive function because the absorption of asymmetric shocks cannot be effectively carried out by monetary policy or by national budgets. If we had already had this instrument during the crisis, we would probably have spared the second recession and all its economic, social and political consequences.  To those who talk about moral hazard, we point out that, on the contrary, this instrument would provide an incentive for responsible budgetary policies and the correction of macroeconomic imbalances. It is therefore a good thing that there is a proposal, even if it appears to be inadequate in terms of size, and an unemployment benefit would be a more effective and transparent automatic stabiliser. In line with the recommendations of this Parliament, it is also the programme of support for reforms. Here it is important that the concept of structural reforms is adapted to the real challenges of today's world, which do not require a devaluation of work and price competitiveness, but a capacity for innovation and development that is also based on a cohesive society.  As far as crisis management is concerned, the proposal to strengthen the European Stability Mechanism, which makes it independent of the International Monetary Fund and expands the range of instruments at its disposal, starting with the backstop proposal for the Bank Resolution Fund, is positive. On this point, however, I would like to express parliament's frustration at the obvious intention of the Member States not to follow the Commission's proposal to integrate the Fund into the legal framework of the Union. I would like to make it clear once and for all that the justification used for this choice, namely that otherwise the power of control of the national parliaments would be reduced, is not true, it is one. From this point of view, nothing would change if we followed the path proposed by the Commission. As has already been said many times, the European Parliament would not use its right of consent to alter the institutional balance of a body that uses the resources of the Member States.  Finally, I would like to advise some Member States to avoid wording on mechanisms for restructuring sovereign debts that are not only counterproductive to financial stability but would also result in the necessary unanimity for the reform of the ESM. With regard to the allocation of budgetary policy monitoring tasks to the new fund, I repeat that it would not only be wrong, but would clearly violate the European Treaties, and it is not, quite rightly, in the Commission's proposal.  The Commission's package also includes the incorporation of Article 3 of the Fiscal Compact into European legislation. I have to say here that the Commission has missed an opportunity. We must simplify and improve our budgetary rules, and this would require, firstly, a different treatment of investment expenditure and the avoiding of procyclical mechanisms. It is clear that the proposal presented on the Fiscal Compact will not go far and that a long way must be done to adapt our budgetary rules to the challenges of the times. Finally, it should be reiterated to everyone, including in this Parliament, that without a mechanism that ensures the same level of deposit protection, not only banking union but also monetary union itself is incomplete.  Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Parliament will seek to improve the Commission's proposals and ensure consistency between them and the MFF. We hope that a minimalist concept will not prevail among the Member States, which would risk not making us make full use of the decisive window of opportunity represented by this last term of office.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me thank you for this timely oral question on the deepening of our economic and monetary union. Democratic accountability is one of the key principles on which this work is based, and I am happy to be here to respond and to hear your views. A well—functioning EMU is at the core of EU integration. Our economic and monetary union is more resilient now than it was before the crisis, but the work is not yet complete. A more integrated and performing euro area is needed to bring increased stability and prosperity to all Europeans. Reconciling very different views on these matters is sometimes difficult, but we are making some progress. The general approach on the 2016 banking package at the May Ecofin is a major milestone that lays the basis for further progress on the banking union, including on the risk-sharing side. We hope that at the June Summit it will be possible to take the concrete decisions which are expected, notably regarding the completion of the banking union and further development of the European Stability Mechanism. We would like to see agreement on key principles and clear milestones for future work. Coming more specifically to Mr Gualtieri’s questions on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON): with regard to the integration of the ESM into the EU legal framework, regrettably the Council has not yet started legislative negotiations on the Commission’s proposal, as several Member States are not in favour of anchoring the ESM in EU law. However, there is general support for the goal of converting the ESM into the European Monetary Fund. Discussions on related issues, such as the role of the ESM as a backstop for a Single Resolution Fund or the new ESM instruments, are taking place in an intergovernmental format. The Commission’s position is that integration of the ESM into the EU legal framework is important to allow full accountability and democratic and judicial oversight of ESM activities, to promote the interests of the whole Union and to ensure swift and timely ESM actions under the well—defined framework. The Commission also considers that any reforms of the ESM should not undermine the institutional prerogatives set out in the Treaties, in particular when it comes to fiscal and economic surveillance. We also remain convinced that the incorporation of ESM into the Union framework can be done by means of Article 352 of the Treaty. We also maintain that Article 126(14) is an appropriate legal basis for the directive transposing into Union law the key provisions as set out in the fiscal compact. This legal basis has also been used in the past to introduce comparable fiscal rules and obligations. As regards the involvement of the European Parliament, let me recall that we put the community method at the centre of the EMU package precisely to increase transparency and accountability. The Community method would increase the European Parliament’s and the national parliaments’ oversight of EU economic governance. The Commission attaches great importance to the views of the European Parliament. In preparing our proposals we have taken into consideration the recent own—initiative reports on the budgetary capacity of the eurozone; the Böge-Berès report on the possible evolutions and adjustments of the current institutional set up of the European Union; the Verhofstadt report; and, on improving the functioning of the European Union, building on the potential of the Lisbon Treaty, the Brok-Bresso report. We look forward to the input from the European Parliament in a formal legislative process and remain fully available to hold regular exchanges of views and debate on these topics. A first exchange of views took place in the ECON Committee on 27 March with Commissioner Moscovici and myself. Finally, let me say a few words on the two EMU-related proposals, which we adopted on 31 May in the context of the next Multiannual Financial Framework. The European Investment Stabilisation Function will help Member States to absorb large asymmetric shocks by helping to protect public investment levels. It will work through a provision of loans of up to EUR 30 billion, guaranteed by the EU budget, and grants to cover the related interest costs. To receive this support, Member States will have to comply with strict eligibility criteria based on sound fiscal and macroeconomic policies. The Reform Support Programme will provide financial and technical support to the structural reforms. A budget of EUR 25 billion will be divided among three instruments: a reform delivery tool providing financial support for agreed reform packages (EUR 22 billion), a technical support instrument continuing the successful experience with the current Structural Reform Support Programme (EUR 840 million), and a convergence facility to offer dedicated financial and technical support to those non-euro-area Member States that take demonstrable steps towards adopting the euro (EUR 2.16 billion). The package will complement other EU programmes and funds in support of jobs and growth, notably the Structural and Cohesion Funds and the new Invest EU Fund. An important theme of our MFF proposal is a stronger link between the EU budget and the European Semester, which is a framework for economic policy coordination. It is now time to decide and to live up to our commitments to reform the EMU. Our end goal is to achieve better living and social standards for all Europeans. That is what matters in the end. I count on your support in this process.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I must inform you that at half past one noon there are votes, so it is not possible to take any indication of catch the eye or use blue cards in this debate because we have a very long list of speakers.

name: Brian HAYES
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I very much welcome this debate ahead of the June Summit on the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) package. Despite all of the pain of the financial and sovereign debt crisis, Europe has come back strongly. We are living through a jobs-rich recovery. That success is based on prudent budgeting, new investment, structural reforms and a commitment to stick to the rules of the fiscal compact. Firstly, it is absolutely useless dreaming up new ideas if we’re not delivering on what we said we would do already. Let us deliver on our existing commitments. Secondly, if you’re a small, big or medium-sized country, the rules apply to everyone. And thirdly, whatever change is proposed, it must be an inclusive format. That means, from our perspective, no euro-area parliament, no railroading of small or indeed any Member States. So where do we go from now? I see five areas of potential improvement. I think we need to complete the Banking Union, to deliver on the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS). That means risk-sharing and risk reduction must go hand in hand. It means a credible resolution of the NPL problem. Secondly, Europe must be open for business, which means more trade deals, delivering on the potential of the single market economy and freeing the EU economy of protectionism. We also need a functioning capital markets union for new finance, alongside Juncker’s / the EFSI plan. Turning the ESM into a fully-fledged European Monetary Fund makes sense, but it needs to be accountable to this Parliament. We also need to be prepared to reform and turn the European budget – the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) – into an instrument of innovation and growth. Could we do the impossible, colleagues? That is, agree a better budget by the time of the next European Parliament elections. We need to – it would send out a powerful signal from this House, were we to obtain that agreement. Finally, I hope that once and for all, the idea of having an EU finance minister is dropped. It is a crazy proposal. It sends out the wrong message to national parliaments, to EU citizens. It does not have national public support. It is a weapon of euroscepticism. It is time that it was finally discarded from the technocratic dreamworld from where it came.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, in this debate that we have been having for a long time, I regret that, at its core, the debate on the renewal of the multi-year financial framework is a debate that is being launched, which will lead at some point, even though we do not fundamentally agree on the future of a euro area budget. However, there is a link between the two and it is clear when Mrs Merkel tells us: 'We will discuss the eurozone budget after discussing the multi-year financial framework'. So what will be left to organize the parallel path of these two tools? My second point is about the stabilisation function and how the European Commission has put a proposal to that effect on the table. The fact that you recognize that this function must be fulfilled, the fact that you put a proposal on the table, is obviously welcome, but recognise that when we call your proposal an embryo, we are almost below reality, because those in this Chamber and elsewhere are still trying to learn from the conduct of business by the IMF who do not listen sufficiently to the IMF, which is listening sufficiently to the IMF, which is from this point of view, tells us that we need a real automatic stabiliser, as we also said in the Berès-B-ge report you quoted. My third thought is on the transformation of the European Stability Mechanism into a European Monetary Fund. We urge you not to use this terminology, it must be a European stabilisation fund. The monetary fund cannot be shifted within the European Union. We support the Commission to ensure that this does not lead to the detracting of your budgetary competences and we are also at your side to advocate for the Community method to be fully implemented in this area. In substance, I would very much regret that this European Council is not moving forward together and is a radical step towards the transformation of the ESM into a European Monetary Fund, and that it is ridiculous when it comes to this much-needed stabilisation function.

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Thank you, Mr President. Today we are debating the introduction of an EMF, a European Monetary Fund, the European version of the IMF. That fund could help Member States that are in bad papers. An interesting idea in itself, but it is not clear what exactly is meant by that EMF, how that will be completed. Will that be an EMF according to the strict version of Mr Schäuble, the former German finance minister, or will that be the more lax interpretation of the European Commission? If I look at the origins of that idea of the EMF, you end up in 2010 with an op-ed in The Economist written by Daniel Gross and Thomas Meyer. The European Commission then proceeded with the idea of an EMF. What is interesting is that six months ago, in December 2017, Gross and Meyer wrote an update of their paper assessing and analysing the European Commission's proposals. And what's their conclusion? They wanted a European Monetary Fund that would provide more fiscal discipline and stronger debt management. When I look at the Commission's proposals, it seems to be seeking yet another solidarity mechanism, when we know that transfers encourage irresponsible behaviour rather than taking more responsibility. Gross and Meyer also saw the EMF as a non-political institution that can judge neutrally and economically. They also want to talk about an exit scenario from the euro, which is not a taboo. Both proposals are again not supported by the European Commission. In summary: The Commission threatens to encourage irresponsibility. And suddenly she is surprised that the northern Member States do not want to play along, that the northern Member States want to hold the reins and want an intergovernmental solution. It is clear what needs to be done. It is time for the Commission to change tack.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, just a couple of ideas in two minutes. On the European Monetary Fund, I think double accountability will have to be introduced. National parliaments should continue to be in charge of accounting for their programmes and actions from the IMF, but so should the European Parliament. How can we explain to our voters that the European Parliament – the institution that wants to represent democracy in the EU – does not have a say over the conditions in bailouts? This anomaly needs to be addressed – otherwise, if MEPs cannot decide on Europe-wide important issues, why should people go to vote in the next European elections? By excluding the European Parliament from crucial decisions, the ground is ready for the next generation of eurosceptics. The second idea: on the other hand, it is important that the fiscal compact is implemented through EU law. I think it is a good moment to check how its application has worked in different Member States, and how we can improve it. For example, in the case of Spain, the central government has arbitrarily put a much more stringent deficit objective to regional governments than to the central government. This has been a way to force cuts in welfare state and social policies. Similarly, many local governments in Spain with very low debt are not allowed by the central government to use the cash they have in the banks for investments on social policies. So control of excessive spending should not be a new excuse for recentralisation.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, it will be almost 150 years since Germany is unified and it has been reunited for 30 years. This political union had been preceded by a customs and monetary union and, since then, Germany has not been economically homogeneous. But no one doubts its durability. So what makes Germany stand together? Politically, of course, a common language and institutions; economically, it is a single market governed by widely shared fiscal and social rules.  This federal tax feeds into a federal budget of more than 10% of GDP, which, together with federal social security, are extremely robust mechanisms of economic solidarity. In addition, there is even a system of direct budget transfers between regions, so that, to date, three regions contribute more to the federation than they receive, and the other thirteen are the other. I take Germany as an example because it is both the Member State to which the Economic and Monetary Union benefits the most and one of those where resistance to any change in the structure of the euro is strongest. Germany's history shows us above all how economic and monetary union should evolve if it is to avoid disintegrating. We have built a single market and then a single currency backed by a federal central bank, but in this market and in the face of the rest of the world, Member States are barely regulated in fiscal, social and commercial competition and the only economic redistribution mechanism we have is the very modest budget of the European Union, which represents 1% of GDP. Is it any wonder that this package produces divergence rather than convergence? To believe that the euro has a future in this context is a denial of reality. If we want to give it a future, the solutions are known: banking union, including the common deposit guarantee; a much more robust common budget with its own revenues, typically a fraction of corporate tax or CO2 price; Finally, in the absence of social and fiscal unification, we must at least abandon competition in favour of cooperation. Without this, the return to national currencies will be inevitable. Some, including in this room, want it, either because they believe that the political will to carry out the necessary reforms will never exist, or because they believe that the nation-state is the only space where democratic sovereignty can be exercised. That is not our choice. We are convinced that the end of the single currency would lead the European Union in its wake into a spiral of decomposition, which would leave the Member States as pawns in the face of multinationals, in a situation where the Trumps, Putins or Xis of this world would be happy to rise against each other to our common detriment. We Europeans will soon be 5% of the world's population. Whether we like it or not, our unity is the condition of our sovereignty, political and fiscal sovereignty, social and economic sovereignty. So I ask you: is Donald Trump going to be the catalyst for this awareness? We hope so, but we do not see the signs yet. On the contrary, we still see too many Member States presenting the issue in a moral light: the virtuous states of the north should not subsidise the fishing states of the south. To these, I would like to point out that Germany, the country in which this moralizing discourse is omnipresent, Mr President, is also the home of Deutsche Bank, one of the most rotten banks on the planet and a car industry that has knowingly deceived citizens for decades. No one, no country, has a monopoly on virtue or vice! The survival of the euro is a matter of shared interest, let us hope that those who will have to decide will become aware of it in time.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, the euro has been an element of the destruction of our economy for Portugal. Since Portugal entered the euro, its public debt has gone from 55 to 130% of GDP. Real wages have dropped by 20%, 500,000 young people have had to leave the country looking for work abroad and the question we are asfacing is why does the European Union insist on maintaining and deepening monetary economic union with the European Monetary Fund and this proposal for pseudo-budgetary capacity in the euro area?  The answer is simple: the euro has always represented and represents a key political tool for imposing structural reforms on Member States by forcing countries such as Portugal to privatise their public services and strategic enterprises.  It is obvious to us that the euro has not lived up to development promises and has defrauded expectations and for us it is obvious that Portugal must free itself from the constraints of the euro, regain its monetary sovereignty in order to be able to choose its own development model.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, almost twenty years have passed since the introduction of the single currency and we have not yet created the mechanisms for real sharing and mutual support between Member States in the event of a crisis. The solution presented in recent years has been the devaluation of wages and rights in the south of Europe, punishing Italian, Greek, Spanish, Portuguese and French citizens with reforms that are often harmful and unfair, while the current account surplus in Germany continues to violate the rules of the Six Pack unhindered, and I address Commissioner Dombrovskis on this. The stability and sustainability of the eurozone is tied to the creation of an optimal currency area. We therefore need instruments such as Eurobonds and tax transfers, not german-sponsored fake solidarity mechanisms on the troika model. All eurozone leaders must choose whether to follow German ideological imposition and bring the eurozone to collapse in the next economic crisis that will arise, or to equip itself with real European and effective instruments.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that when we talk about the eurozone we must start from two elements. The first fundamental element is an analysis and reduction of the macroeconomic imbalances and asymmetries that have been caused by the crazy policies pursued in recent years and are destroying Europe. The second point is a serious reflection on the change in the socio-economic model on which the eurozone is based today. It is a crazy model, based solely on exports and the reduction of domestic costs, and it is a model that is creating destruction and that depends too much on the decisions of foreign countries, as the war on tariffs is demonstrating at the moment.  Italy will not sink out of the folly of following the wrong macroeconomic instrument. Italy will reject any reform proposal that does not start from the desire to reduce these imbalances. No to the European Monetary Fund. Italian citizens will no longer put a euro and will no longer send a euro to Brussels to receive it back in time of need with conditionalities imposed.  The last point I want to highlight is enough with the false narrative that today someone in Europe is paying for Italy. Italy, since its participation in the European institutions, has always given much more than it has received from Brussels. We will no longer accept moralism from those who are trying to lecture us today by not having in mind the data that are there for everyone to look at. Italy will reject any conditionality attached to new eurozone-related funds.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, at a time when the SYRIZA-ANEL government, with substantial agreement between the other urban parties despite their meaningless communication differences, is voting in the Greek Parliament on a fourth long-term memorandum, re-marrying the people, re-supporting the chapter, the debate here in the European Parliament on deepening monetary union proves that the long-term memoranda are not a Greek specificity, but a generalised strategy of capital coordinated by the European Union.  The ESM is being developed into the European Monetary Fund of equal barbarity. The single economic governance, the Financial Pact, the European Semester, the Euro Pact, i.e. iron rules for monitoring the unpopular policy of governments, are incorporated into Community law and national legislation. The aim is for the people to consent to the lasting memoranda, to put their backs with bloody sacrifices to the profits of monopolies. Monopolies, the European Union, civil governments and memoranda are identical. For the peoples a clear exit from them means organisation, counter-attack, decommitment from the European Union, discharge from their memoranda and power.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, the euro is one of the symbols of the European Union. It is an important economic tool, supporting the efficiency of the single market and reducing costs for people and for businesses. I am glad that, despite the fact that some people wrongly blame Europe for mistakes that have nothing to do with the currency, support of the euro among Europeans is strong – actually, probably the strongest it has been since its introduction.  The Monetary Union, as well as the EU, is a work in progress. That’s why the Commission has proposed that the Package be released in December. This forms a very good basis for the debate on how to improve the European Monetary Union (EMU) and the EU. But this package is by no way a replacement for responsible and good economic policy in the Member States: we can only achieve a successful, stable and growing Europe with such reforms.  Not all parts of the package have the same importance and same urgency. Let me mention just two that I consider the most important. The first is the European Monetary Fund: I believe that this proposal is a hectic way of creating the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism (ESFM)/European Stability Mechanism (ESM), and it can incorporate other policies into the framework of this huge amount of money that is used for supporting and strengthening European policy. I guess this is a good proposal.  The second one is completion of ongoing initiatives, especially in the area of the banking union. I’m talking about single backstop and completion of the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS). I believe that a compromise can be found, and I hope it will be found soon.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to thank the Commissioner for quoting mr Brok's report, but we would like to understand the democratically necessary reform of the euro area, what it is. We are pleased with the quotation, but where is the end of parliament's responsibility – Parliament has the power of codecision – on all matters relating to the euro area. Needless to say, the European Parliament is the Parliament of the euro, if the powers with regard to the euro are not given to it. To those Members who have mentioned Germany's trade surplus, I would like to remind you that Italy also has a commercial surplus, so there is no point in trying to use these arguments. The real arguments that I believe we must use are those of why the citizens of Europe are increasingly wary of the single currency. I believe that it is because the single currency is essentially presented as a cage, and it must not be a cage, that it must create opportunities, especially for young Europeans.  We certainly need a budget for the euro area, but we need a budget that helps young Europeans to be strong and competitive in a world where the European Union increasingly needs to be competitive. So not so much to carry out austerity-type reforms, but to make reforms that really give our citizens opportunities to strongly counter the competitively difficult situation that Europe knows today compared to the rest of the world.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, once again the Commission has produced lengthy texts on the smoothing of cyclical fluctuations without providing a politically realistic and economically viable model for the European Economic and Monetary Union.  Transferring debts and payment liabilities to countries that are better off with the euro will not solve the fundamental problems of the euro area, such as growing differences in competitiveness. According to Professor Hans-Werner Sinn, leaving the euro is the only way to prevent them from being torn apart. It is also the only way to prevent the uncontrolled break-up of the euro. The European Central Bank must not own more than a third of the bonds of an individual country, which is almost full for Germany. In the next recession, the European Central Bank will be powerless. As the columnist Wolfgang Münchau has pointed out, every country should be prepared for the break-up of the euro.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: Thank you, Mr President. Thank you, Commissioner. The European Commission is being hard-hit. And the Commission is moving forward with full speed, whereas Italy wants to pull us back in time. Proposals have been launched at a rapid pace to create new European pots, or to put your debts directly to the neighbours. And sometimes it seems as if this House has only two gears: either full speed ahead or the brake. But as far as I'm concerned, there's a third. And that's the option where we stick to the agreements we've made with each other. That is the option where we make our economies resilient, and we remain a large economic bloc of the world. That is the option, as far as I am concerned, where we do not send each other the bill, but where we trade with each other. Making appointments is actually very easy. But only if we stick to those agreements, then, as far as I am concerned, there is the room to share those risks in confidence. As far as I am concerned, that is the order: making agreements, keeping to the agreements, sowing trust and reaping prosperity.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report The euro zone is in danger of falling apart because of its design flaws, which at the same time favour the rise of nationalist forces. Finally, the European Commission is also positioning itself on the future of the euro zone. On its own, the proposals before us do not tackle the root of the problem; they are more like a tinkering with the symptoms. The euro zone will fall apart if it does not reduce trade deficits. And a major problem is the German export surplus. First of all, however, this does not mean saving and cutting in the rest of Europe, which means that we in Germany need higher wages. We also need public investment in the eu's future viability. But the future is not made through investments in the military and with PESCO, it is made by investing in heads and concrete. Instead, let us save ourselves these neoliberal concrete heads and their destructive austerity policies and spend better money on a modern economic and social structure that takes account of digitalisation and modern technologies as well as investments in education, research and health!

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, when it comes to economic and monetary union, let us not hide our faces: the Commission proposes, but Germany has it. Mr Macron, Mr Merkel's vassal, has already made half a dozen speeches on the virtues of federalist Europe and the European Commission proposed on 6 December its package of measures on deepening EMU. Since then, Macron and Juncker have been feverishly awaiting the response of the Pythia of Berlin, Angela Merkel, and this response confirms my worst economic fears about the future European Monetary Fund. This German version of the EMF, designed by The European Union and Goldman Sachs, represented by Mr Kukies, will become the budgetary watchdog for the euro area. Beware of Member States that do not respect the German budgetary discipline of this new ECB budget, independent of elected governments. Merkel wants the EMF to be empowered to trigger the automatic restructuring of a member state's sovereign debt and for the EMF to have more budgetary control over that state. It is therefore the end of financial independence and the potential guardianship of a nation. Needless to say, I will fight this financial totalitarianism of the European Union politically. We will ensure that this worsening of the economic governance of the euro area never sees the light of day in France. No to austerity against Europeans!

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work A euro summit is due at the end of June, which will set the course for key issues of deepening economic and monetary union and stabilising the euro area. In particular, it concerns the transformation of the European Stability Mechanism into a European Monetary Fund and additional financial instruments to promote investment and innovation, as well as a common backstop for bank resolution. For us, however, it is also a question of democratic legitimacy, that is, the appropriate participation of the European Parliament and national parliaments in connection with these financial instruments. The German chancellor made concrete proposals on this last week, and leading commentators agree that much more than what Merkel brought to the debate will not be decided by the heads of state and government at the end of June.
