These proposals are three modified financial instruments: firstly, a short-term credit line from the new European Monetary Fund for Member States that have run into difficulties due to external circumstances, secondly, an investment budget; and thirdly, an additional budget for implementing structural reforms. The Commission will love these proposals. I would just ask you, Commissioner Dombrovskis, to comply with the principle of democratic legitimacy and accountability and for the national parliaments ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Today is a special day for Austria: 24 years ago, in a referendum by a two-thirds majority, the Austrians said 'yes' to membership of the European Union, thereby making it clear that our future is closely linked to the future of the European Union and that we are actively participating in every step of integration. We said 'yes' a few years after Maastricht. Maastricht created the euro, our common currency as a political project that unites and does not divide. And we knew very well that we currently have only one common currency, but the only common currency that does not have a common budget, fiscal, economic and fiscal policy. And we knew that we had to work on this common budget, fiscal, economic, social and fiscal policy in order to stabilise the euro and create a strong common currency in the internal market. We are not finished with it yet, but we have to pick up speed. The lessons: we need to create the completion of key instruments for common risk containment and shoulders, as well as greater proportionality: Banking Union, Capital Markets Union. We must carry out institutional reforms and create the European Stability Mechanism into a European Monetary Fund under Community law. And we need a euro budget within the framework of the new EU budget and on the basis of own resources.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, the Commission has come with a proposal on fiscal capacity for the eurozone which we really want discussed at the next euro summit. Finally, the eurozone, which is the only monetary zone without a budget, recognised that we do indeed need a budget in order to have a future in the eurozone. However, what should be the objectives of this budget? There should be not only stability, but also growth and upward economic and social convergence. From this viewpoint, we need to go beyond the Commission’s proposals, because if we want to support convergence, we should be clearly in favour of reforms, growth, increasing the sustainability of our social welfare systems, and coupling reforms with investments. Something is missing in this instrument.  Secondly, the instrument to support investment is necessary not only to protect against shocks, but also to make sure that Member States undertaking deep rebalances of the budgets can maintain a decent level of social investment, which is not the case so far. We need to go beyond, because if we do not improve these proposals, and we have combined these with co-financing being reduced for structural funds, we can already predict that divergences will continue in the eurozone.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the euro area has led to a build-up of wealth in the hard core countries and to a huge economic bleeding of the countries of the European region. It filled the European South with armies of the poor and unemployed and with oversized trade surpluses in Germany. It is therefore necessary not only to abandon austerity and violent fiscal adjustment, but also to change the structure of the euro area and to abolish the draconian stability pact. The European Central Bank must become the last lender of the Member States while providing for the issue of Eurobonds. In addition, the European System of Central Banks must operate decentralised and the Member States of the European Union, and in particular the euro area, must regain their monetary sovereignty so that national central banks can pursue an independent monetary policy up to the level of the share rate of each national central bank in the share capital of the European Central Bank.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Every time we discuss European economic and monetary union, we seem to be falling into serious oblivion. No one wants to remember the swamp we were in after the Bretton Woods system broke down. Each currency has its underlying value in productivity. We are not getting away from the demand for increasing and growing productivity. Any post in this house that denies this, denies reality, but it is not new. So we have created a system – the Commission was perhaps a little over-optimistic when you read Robert Mandell's 1961 article and thought that was the solution. When the Commission comes out today with new proposals on how to improve this system, we should be grateful and critical. But we should remember that productivity, the underlying productivity, is in any case the starting point.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis, what you are proposing – and as it gnaws and restricts them even further and postpones them by the Council – is too little too late, because the persistence of neoliberal policies and the refusal of the necessary changes in the content of policy and structures feed the growing inequalities, social and regional, and inflate the sails of the extreme right. You saw it in the room. We need a shift in growth, a deepening of European integration, a strong European budget, a strengthening of democratic accountability, a European Monetary Fund accountable to the European Parliament, a European deposit guarantee system, which without it there is no banking integration. The refusal of these changes by neoliberal dogmatism and by the national egotism of the right-wing German government harms development, European unification and only benefits the extreme right.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Today we are talking about the European Monetary Fund (EMF), which the Commission and a number of other notorious redistributors want to create. You can turn and turn it around as you like: you have no legal basis for the EMF in EU law. In 2010, however, this was still a sensation when the European Union had no or even contra law. At that time, you broke the non-assistance clause in passing. Today, in the year 10 of the banking and currency crisis, observers have obviously become accustomed to the illegal behaviour for a long time. That is sad. Your proposal for an EMF also violates the German Basic Law, as the Centre for European Policy clearly analysed last week. In urgent cases, money cannot be granted without the Bundestag. Stop sticking to the fiction that government bonds cannot fail and states cannot go bankrupt! Stop your meaningful and unsuccessful bail-outs! Because a currency that must be saved all the time is not a functioning currency. It does not work, neither for either. Admit this and finally draw the only consequences!

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, recent weeks have shown us all continuing high volatility on the markets. This means that markets are nervous, and this means that risks still persist. The question is: what is the origin of this nervousness? It is without any doubt due to recent political developments. That is why the key question for me is: who is stronger in Europe – populism or our currency? We have to make sure that our common currency, on which the prosperity of 500 million citizens in Europe is based, is stronger than populism, which wants to harm the euro. The question is: what do we have to do? We have to strengthen the euro to prevent the next crisis, because managing a crisis is always politically difficult, it is harmful for the people and it is expensive. The better way is, of course, to prevent the next crisis. Therefore, Vice-President Dombrovskis, my questions are: when we are looking to the European Stability Mechanism and eventually reflecting upon developing it into a European monetary fund, what goal do you foresee for a possible European monetary fund in preventing the next financial crisis? My next question is: could you clarify how a European monetary fund would be based on the EU legal framework? What role do you foresee for the European Parliament after the possible creation of the EMF? But also before, while we decide on the creation of the EMF: what role do you foresee for Parliament to ensure democratic legitimacy for that creation?

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the recent market turbulence caused by the Italian political crisis has shown once again that it would be a mistake, and a serious mistake, to postpone an ambitious reform of economic and monetary union. And we all know what this reform of the euro should be. A European monetary fund worthy of that name, a new budgetary capacity, a complete banking union and more democratic economic governance with the strengthening of the European Parliament and respect for national parliaments. The June summit is therefore the time for truth. So what we want to know, Commissioner Dombrovskis, is whether we can count on the Commission until the last minute to be on the right side in defence of an ambitious reform of the euro, which will not continue to postpone to tomorrow what needs to be done today.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Dombrovskis, you wrote in your reflection paper last year that our Economic and Monetary Union is not sufficiently capable of halting or reversing the social and economic divergence between the euro countries resulting from the crisis. Yes, that is the problem! That is what we are talking about here too. And it is proud to say that employment is on the rise. Anyone who knows the figures knows that this additional employment is precarious, that more work is being done, but for less money. I also hear that Germany benefits most from the euro. Let me say what it is like: for us, the euro is undervalued, we export too much, too cheaply, and we import too little, we give away wealth. And what is the consequence? We have a trillion claims against central banks that are not solvent. That is the reality. You are absolutely right: the moralising tone of the Federal Government is also on my nerves.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: – Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis Vice-President, you have asked Parliament for Parliament's support for a euro which is in the service of the citizens. Look, of all those who believe in Europe, in my constituency, which is all of Spain, or here in Parliament, of all those who understand that there is no future in a divided Europe —among other things, because it will be much more dependent on the follies of a Trump, for example — of all of them, you have the support. But the construction of this single currency has to be based on two pivots: structural reforms, no doubt — we must not pretend that we have achieved perfection — and solidarity. For example, in my country, I hope that we would come to the structural reform of our delusional system of regions, which never allows us to meet the deficit. But solidarity involves mutualization of risks, without ambages, and means ending the EDIS very soon. And we don't have time to wait. In June, europe has to be kicked first to create a single currency with much more decision and much more urgency.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr President, 16 years ago, the euro was introduced in 12 countries of the European Union. No more the franc, the mark, the peseta, the guilder. One and the same currency, one monetary policy, one exchange rate policy. It was and still is a historical project. But it was and is also a project that is not yet finished. Monetary union can only work in conjunction with a fiscal and political Union. The economic policies of the Member States must be aligned. Everyone must control their public debt. We knew that, and yet we looked the other way for years, until the financial crisis of 2008. The construction of the euro area, which was and in fact still is still not fully finished. And the sun is shining, ladies and gentlemen. That's why we need to fix our house today. The European Union has a hand in carrying out repairs only in severe weather. But anyone with a little common sense knows that we need to take action now. Because now the sun is shining. There is economic growth, unemployment is falling and investment is rising again. But apparently good weather is not only enough to repair the roof. We really need to take the ladder, clamber on to the roof and get to work. That's why this call, ladies and gentlemen. The economic conditions are there, but we must show political courage. Let's take advantage of the good weather, because sooner or later the storm will rise again. Each of us must go home and explain why it is so important that we continue to work out this banking union, why the euro area is needed and why the budgetary rules are not a piece of paper, but are crucial for this project to succeed.

name: Jakob von WEIZSÄCKER
text: – Mr President, in order to succeed with a more sustainable architecture of the euro area, we need to observe four kinds of logic: the logic of sensible stabilising and preventative rules that are actually observed; the logic of fair insurance contracts concluded ex ante and paying out in times of economic shock, big European unemployment insurance or banking union; the logic of crisis management by strong institutions; and, last but not least, the logic of democracy. For the political sustainability of the common currency, it will be essential that rules, insurance contracts and strong crisis management capabilities strengthen democracy at the European and national level, rather than weaken it. In practice, this means proper accountability to the European Parliament, and it means that our architecture needs to be based on solid federalism by exception, not an attempt to micromanage policies of Member States at all times, which would only serve as a permanent support programme for populists and nationalist political parties set on destroying the European project.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, before we think about deepening EMU, we must first honour agreements that have been made. The provisions of the Stability and Growth Pact have now been violated 150 times. Absurd! This undermines the credibility of the euro area. I support the position of the Dutch Government, which wants rules to be followed and risks reduced. And there is still a dark cloud hanging over the euro. The new government—Conte wants to spend considerably more than comes in. Thus, italy's sky-high public debt of 130% of GDP will continue to rise. This jeopardises the position of the euro. The ECB and the Commission must stop these plans. At the same time, I say that the European Union must show solidarity with Italy and also with Greece. These countries now attract the majority of migrants and many Member States look the other way. Unacceptable! Europe must start to arrange reception together and countries that do not do so will have to contribute to this reception.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Mr President, I welcome the European Commission's proposals for the completion of the Economic and Monetary Union. I believe, however, that even if we put together all the instruments and policies necessary for this union, it will not be complete until the Member States that are not in the euro area join the euro. And these Member States, when they joined the European Union, have committed themselves to meeting all the conditions for being able to join the euro. That is why I believe that the convergence facility provided for in the new Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 will have to be used for those Member States that are committed and have a concrete action plan, setting out the specific times, the measures they must take to join the euro.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, the crisis on this ship full of refugees, in recent days, called Aquarius reminded us that we cannot have a Schengen Union without a border, without a common management of national borders.  In the same sense, the euro area crisis has reminded us, in turn, that we cannot have a monetary pillar — a common monetary policy — without a fiscal structure, without a fiscal instrument to ease crises, to lead the euro area through complicated waters. That is why it is vital to close the banking union now. This Parliament has to do its job to close now and reach agreement with deposit insurance, and we need to respond to the Commission's proposals to build a fiscal instrument, an automatic stabiliser, to accompany monetary policy. It's time to do it.  It is time for this solidarity Europe to respond to the refugee crisis, as the Government of Spain has done, and for Europe to respond also to the crisis in the euro area.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Listening to the discussions here, one cannot believe that the majority of the population in Greece, France, Italy, Spain – that is, in those states that are supposedly not benefiting from it – is fully in favour of the euro. The euro is a success, despite the imbalances. And if the rules are not followed, then even short and small changes will do nothing. That is why we need to think about the basic structure. The weaknesses and birth defects of the monetary union are on the table and, despite a strong economic recovery, they remain. In this case, I must agree with Professor Starbatty: from a German point of view, the euro is undervalued or Germany is undervalued in the euro. That is why we export wealth. Export surpluses are reflected in central bank commitments on the other side. Germany's central bank commitments amount to 956 billion euros at the end of May, and the assets of Italy, France and Spain add up to 964 billion euros. Those who forget this conceal the truth. And if we want to create a European Monetary Fund today, it must remain a national responsibility. Because where taxes come from, liability must also remain. I believe that if the Monetary Commissioner also gets access rights such as the Commissioner for Competition, then we can finally improve the enforcement of the rules.

name: Paul TANG
text: Thank you, Mr President. It is good that so many Members have gathered for this important debate on the euro. Because the euro must change in order to survive, so much is clear. That much is clear to the electorate. Austerity in bad times leads to even worse times, with Greece as the most painful example. But start at the beginning. Scrap the stupid and terrible rules for the deficit. Let countries take responsibility for the development of expenditure and debt. It's simple: with a lot of debt, there's little room, and vice versa. And then there is a safety net needed, for countries and for banks, a European Monetary Fund. But let the euro be ours. Choose a democratic anchoring of the fund. Choose a Eurozone Parliament with national and European parliamentarians. Responsibility, solidarity, democratisation, that change is needed to make the euro exist for the benefit of all of us.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the architecture of the Economic and Monetary Union has changed considerably in recent years with the development of the banking union and the capital markets union, as well as the establishment of the European Stability Mechanism, which played a major role in ensuring the stability of the euro area during the sovereign debt crisis by reassuring the markets and providing financial assistance to various Member States. Because it is still vulnerable to the risks of economic and financial destabilization, it is necessary to go further in the construction of economic and monetary union by transforming the European Stability Mechanism into the European Monetary Fund. This new step must strengthen and improve the efficiency of the euro area in order to make it more resilient and to strengthen the protection of our savers. Above all, this fund will have to continue the work of the European Stability Mechanism in crisis prevention and management. But new functions will have to be assigned to it to encourage investment and be the safety net of the bank bailout fund. Progress on economic and monetary union cannot be done without democratic legitimacy, which is why the European Parliament will have to be fully involved, as will the national parliaments.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, Economic and Monetary Union has been the economic foundation of the European Union that has brought us here. But without more deepening, it cannot be functional, and most of us agree on that. However, decisions will have to be taken in the forthcoming Council. For example, we need a European Monetary Fund based on European Union legislation but also in line with our own priorities. For example, large economic divergences lead to an increase in political divergences and extremes, dangerously fuelling populism. We need a EMU that is more accountable, democratically accountable to this European Parliament. Finally, Mr President, we cannot proceed unless we have a pan-European deposit guarantee.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, the good news is that the euro area has strongly recovered after the series of crises ten years ago, and now the euro enjoys very strong popular support among European citizens. According to Eurobarometer, two thirds of European citizens are happy to use the euro. Also no Member State wants to leave the euro area; just the opposite. There are new countries waiting for accession. In this context, I would like to support the initiative submitted by the Commission that aims at strengthening the general institutional infrastructure of the euro area. I have no problem with the European Monetary Fund or with the incorporation of the Treaty on Stability, Coordination and Governance into Union law, but I think that the proposal to establish a budgetary instrument for the euro area, especially when it comes to its stabilisation functions, deserves more attention and more discussion. First of all, it raises the problem of moral hazard, as does every insurance instrument. Secondly, it is politically unpopular in Member States, and it would require a lot of political capital in order to introduce it. But third, and most important: there is no proof that this instrument is necessary if countries follow the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact because, in that case, it always has a sufficient fiscal space to confront the asymmetric shocks.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: "The continuation of the development of EMU is not the restaurant's buffet table, from which everyone picks up the elements that seem to taste best at the moment, but is a whole that – in the same way as wagons and bikes – needs different parts to function. The Commission has done a good job. The ground proposal includes the development of both a European Finance Minister and a stability mechanism into a European Monetary Fund and, in future, a common investment mechanism to support countries in asymmetric shocks, and it will become this whole. It is very important that it is also accompanied by the continuation of the Banking Union, stricter rules to comply with the Stability and Growth Pact and, from outside the package itself, the principles and means of strengthening the social dimension and the rules of the game in working life, including principles and means of tax evasion, unfair competition and the avoidance of social security and tax competition in the future. Only in this way can Europe be strong.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I will begin at the end – that is, the end of Commissioner Dombrovskis’ speech. His final words to us today were that the EU must provide better living and social standards for our citizens; that is what matters. Indeed, that is what matters, and we must take measures to ensure that happens, because rarely do we discuss the social and living standards of our citizens when we talk about high finance. So what can be done? Number one: the EU Banking Union must encompass a European deposit insurance scheme that would be powerful for our citizens. The Commissioner also referred to the EU Invest Fund, and I am pleased to say that I have been appointed rapporteur for that, and I look forward to working with the Commissioner and others to ensure that it benefits especially the smaller businesses right across the European Union. I also want to mention a few points that my colleague Brian Hayes mentioned. We do not need a European finance minister. Indeed, the word ‘minister’ is almost an exclusive competence for Member States at this stage, and it is almost an usurpation of their right to be talking about a minister at European level. We do not want a eurozone parliament. There is one parliament – this is it. And we must agree the MFF before the next elections. Finally, I want to say that the rules must apply to all, and it would be a good idea if we made it clear to populists when they are going for election what the consequences are for their citizens’ standards of living if they break the fiscal rules. That might help to fight populism.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Mr President, I will speak on the democratic accountability of the EMU. I think we all agree that there is a strong link between parliamentary scrutiny and democratic legitimacy; this matters today more than ever. But, when it comes to the EMU, the mechanism behind this link is far from perfect: there is a democratic accountability gap, and colleagues spoke a lot about that today. A year ago, Parliament adopted a series of resolutions on the future of Europe, where you opted strongly for a single institutional framework, but we believe that the democratic legitimacy of the EMU can be further improved without a treaty change. We also believe that the less complex, more efficient and more transparent the governance, the more effective its scrutiny. This relationship should be an underlying principle in the ongoing reforms.  We also believe that an interinstitutional agreement between Parliament, the Council and the Commission could provide for better parliamentary scrutiny of different elements of economic governance. In particular, such an agreement could help with the better handling of the issues which require double legitimacy. We strongly support the incorporation of the ESM, the fiscal compact and the SRF into the framework of European law; I think this is the quickest way to upgrade the European Parliament to a fully—fledged participant in defining economic policy goals and improving the democratic oversight of European governance.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, as today’s discussion on deepening of economic and monetary union showed once again, we will only be able to make progress if we pursue a balanced approach: an approach where solidarity and responsibility, risk-sharing and risk reduction advance hand—in—hand. This is one of the guiding principles which we have been pursuing in this work.  We had a lot of discussions on deepening the EMU during this mandate, starting with the Five Presidents’ Report and with reflection papers; we put forward a package of proposals in December last year, we put forward further proposals this May, and we think it is now time to move from discussions to decisions. Therefore, we see the June summit as a critical milestone, and I am glad that I also heard a number of Members of the European Parliament call for action and concrete decisions.  It is important to strengthen democratic accountability, to improve the resilience of the euro area, to restart the process of convergence, and at the end of the day to achieve higher living standards for all Europeans. The Commission counts on your support for driving this process of deepening the EMU, and also the various dossiers still open during this mandate.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – Economic and monetary union is incomplete, as the crisis showed. The banking union has partially remedyed this situation, for the euro area, with the harmonisation of banking regulation through the European Banking Authority, and the sole supervision established at the European Central Bank. However, the banking union remains unfinished, as European deposit insurance has not yet been implemented, nor has it been agreed that the European Stability Mechanism (EESM) is the tax support of the under-endowed Single Resolution Fund. More also, neither monetary union nor banking union can function effectively without risk-free assets that can eliminate excess national public debt on banks' balance sheets and which can stabilize the euro in financial markets. It is also necessary to have an anti-cyclical budget in the euro area, which can also give credibility to the issuance of debt securities, and to integrate the ESM into the acquis communautaire. The June 2018 European Council must take these and other steps, in accordance with the proposals of the Commission and the President of France, to achieve the full federalisation of the Eurozone.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – EMU is incomplete, as demonstrated by the crisis. The banking union has partially remedyed the euro area with the harmonisation of banking regulation through the European Banking Authority and the sole supervision established at the European Central Bank. However, the banking union remains incomplete, as European deposit insurance has not yet been implemented, nor has it been agreed that the European Stability Mechanism (EESM) is the tax support of the under-endowed Single Resolution Fund. More also, neither monetary union nor banking union can function effectively without risk-free assets that can eliminate excess national public debt on banks' balance sheets and which can stabilize the euro in financial markets. It is also necessary to have an anti-cyclical budget in the euro area to give credibility to the issuance of debt securities and to integrate the ESM into the acquis communautaire. The June 2018 European Council must take these and other steps, in accordance with the proposals of the Commission and the President of France, to achieve the full federalisation of the Eurozone.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The completion of economic and monetary union (EMU) is a priority for the European Union in general and the euro area in particular to successfully address the new challenges posed by changes in global geopolitics and the economic balance stemming from them, while responding to the expectations and needs of European citizens. On the path that will have to be followed, the role of the European Parliament as a direct representative of the peoples of Europe must be valued and enhanced. In particular, it is essential that progress in the implementation of EMU contributes to the stabilisation of the euro area, the promotion of convergence, the strengthening of investment and the creation of quality jobs. The completion of the Banking Union with a sound guarantee system is a step that must be taken immediately while the European Stabilisation Mechanism must consistently evolve into a European Stabilisation Fund that will benefit all Member States in an integrated manner and strengthen the overall competitiveness of the euro area.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: – Mr President, on a point of order under Rule 147. Everybody can be at risk from mechanical delays, but yesterday on the special train that brought many of us from Brussels there were delays: we had the most appalling circumstances and we were kept in difficult conditions. Can I as Quaestor ask you to join me in apologising to all of those people who were stuck on that train? But it’s not just that train. Many other MEPs and staff had travel delays getting to Strasbourg, and it highlights the absurdity of dragging us 500 kilometres to Strasbourg every month. There are MEPs, parliamentary staff, committee staff, Group staff, Commission staff, Council staff – they all have to come to Strasbourg. It wastes our time, it wastes money and it brings this institution into disrepute. Mr President, please can we ask you to talk to the President of this House and ask him to bring it up again with President Tusk and look again at the Treaties to reflect the will of this House and give us a single seat in which to work? (Applause)

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Mr President, it is only to make an appeal. I believe it is a disgrace for this institution, which is the home of democracy, to have interpreters working under kidnapping. They have been imposed on working conditions that are draconian, that do not respect their rights and we are here working here as if it were nothing, with interpreters requested behind us. We defend democracy, the right to strike, and i therefore ask Parliament to medeminate this negotiation. We cannot do our job without interpreters and we cannot have interpreters working without rights.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Thank you colleague. We discussed this matter again yesterday in the Bureau and I can assure you that there will be a full commitment on the part of all members to resolve it, as we hope, by consensus. Another point of order by Mr Beazley, on be it, is that it is not a point of order. Flack.

name: John FLACK
text: – Mr President, on a happier note, can I just call a point of order to invite Parliament to congratulate the Bulgarian authorities for saving Penka the cow, showing that common sense and compassion can trump EU rules?

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, I will refer again to the issue of interpreters. It is not just a question of where the European Parliament meets. The European Parliament has demonstrated its supposedly democratic sensitivity. It prohibited workers from exercising their strike rights. This is democracy! Workers working in unacceptable conditions, 12 hours, without breaks, moving many kilometres on one-day contracts. This decision must be unanimously condemned! Let us now take back the decision of the European Parliament! Let the workers go! Remove the requisition! We express our solidarity with our working colleagues in the European Parliament.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: There was also a reference from Mr Syley to the Commission. Coburn.  Ladies and gentlemen, I try to be tolerant, but do not abuse my tolerance in granting speeches on the point of order, thank you.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, I was interested in what Ms Bearder was saying regarding the delay on the EU gravy train coming to Strasbourg. May I say: now she knows what it’s like for her everyday constituents travelling by rail to work. I think she’s living in another world, on another planet.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, very quickly I am very sorry for yesterday's train breakdown and I understand the inconvenience to colleagues and especially to all employees. But we are here in the European Parliament and we must respect the treaties, so I would just like to remind you, ladies and gentlemen, that the Strasbourg seat is now the seat of the European Parliament and that we must have that in mind.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: We are going to proceed with the votes, we have had too many points of order. Rule 184a speaks for themselves, many have spoken without even mentioning the Rule of Procedure. Please let's move on, thank you.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you for the clear vote. I would ask that the final vote be postponed so that we can enter the trialogue and that there is no loophole in the law, and therefore that we refer it back to committee.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: I put the rapporteur's proposal to the vote. The matter is referred back to the committee responsible for initiating interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: That concludes voting time. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments pending explanations of vote)

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, thug mé tacaíocht don tuairisc seo mar go dtugann sí aitheantas don ghéarghá atá lenár mbáid bheaga a chosaint agus a fhorbairt. Léiríonn sí go gcaithfear tuiscint a bheith ann ar an difríocht idir iascaireacht mar chaitheamh aimsire agus iascaireacht mar shlí bheatha. Tuigimid go mbeidh fás agus borradh ar thurasóireacht atá bainteach le slatiascaireacht mar chaitheamh aimsire agus aithnímid gur rud maith é seo, ach ag an am céanna tá sé tábhachtach nach gciallódh sé seo go mbeadh aon laghdú ar dheiseanna d’iascaireacht phroifisiúnta agus nach gcuirfeadh sé isteach ar an earnáil leis na flíteanna beaga.  Bheadh sé níos deise a bheith ag caint mar gheall air seo dá mbeadh an tigh ciúin! Tá sé an-deacair a bheith ag caint nuair atá daoine ag cadráil.  Ar aon chuma, cuirim fáilte roimh an nglaoch ón gCoimisiún chun airgead a infheistiú chun an earnáil turasóireachta i dtaobh iascaireacht mar chaitheamh aimsire a fhorbairt agus ba chóir go mbeadh eolas faoi acmhainní á roinnt. É sin ráite, caithfidh mé a rá go bhfuilim an-bhuartha faoin droch-thionchar a bheadh ar an gcóras eicea-uisce úr de bharr an baol a bheadh ann dá mbeadh speicis neamhdhúchasacha ag cur isteach ar ár n-aibhneacha, go mbeidh slatiascairí ag iascaireacht iontu i gcoitinne.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, recreational fishermen contribute around EUR 10.5 billion to the economy. The impact of this type of fishing is very important from an economic, social and environmental point of view. That is why we have asked the Commission to assess the role of recreational fishing in the future common fisheries policy, including multiannual plans, so that both types of commercial and recreational fishing can be managed in a balanced, fair and sustainable manner. At the same time, there is a problem with the lack, or in some cases the total absence, of available and up-to-date data. Let us remember, however, that the EFF provides funding for the collection of data on recreational fishing as well. That is why we have asked the Commission to extend the future scope of the EMFF, to provide financial support for research and analysis of the data collected and thus to fund monitoring projects for species most subject to recreational fishing.  We have also called on the Commission to establish a data register available to researchers, in order to constantly monitor and assess the state of fish stocks. Here, too, funding could be used under the EFF. Finally, we have addressed the issue of the definition of recreational fishing, an important definition, so that the activity is different from the illegal, undeclared and unregulated activity. This is a crucial issue, because only as a result of proper definition and regulation will it be possible to defend the interests of commercial and recreational fishermen, guaranteeing the protection of the environment and stocks, because there must not be a conflict between the two types of fishing, but cooperation in the protection of resources. All these demands have been accepted by the rapporteur and we have therefore fully supported the report.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr. President, I apologize. I had previously asked for the floor on a point of order. I'm sorry to have to report it now. However, I would like to inform the House of the following: a few days ago the names of the awarded European citizens were announced with the European Citizen's Prize. Among them is Turkish Cypriot colleague and competitor Şener Levent. A man whom I deeply appreciate, a man who is very much likeable to me, whom I love and whose candidacy I also supported. I do not think it is right that you should be awarded the European Citizen's Prize for appearing in this capacity, denouncing me, my colleague Neocles Sygiotis and our Party for being in favour of the occupation and presence of occupying troops and guarantees in Cyprus.  Which is totally wrong! You are all aware of our struggles here and I think it was an inappropriate move on his part. When a friend attacks you, it takes a lot of bravery to maintain a level that sustains the relationship. I keep this possibility, I want to maintain the relationship with this man and I also express to him from here my appreciation for his struggles against occupation. Let us also allow ourselves to hold the same possibility and patriotism.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to call on you to proceed strictly, because this is the part that is devoted to explaining the vote, and the point of order is only possible for this part, and I do not think my colleague has spoken about it at all. However, to what I have to say. I supported this report on recreational fishing for several reasons. Firstly, it is clear that this is not a call for new legislation. I think it is very important to say at the beginning that this is an own-initiative report that describes the problem but does not call for new legislation.  Secondly, it is clear that this recreational fishery plays a sub-subsuersive role in several regions It is really very important for the regional economy, and for this reason too, I supported this report.  We need a single definition, we need more data to analyse the problem, so I supported this opinion and this report, respectively, in order to find these uniform definitions and to transfer the relevant scientific data.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Thank you, Mr Polčák. In order to clarify, pursuant to Rule 184a, points of order are possible at any time and always take precedence over any other type of motion and any other request to speak. Clearly, there are some Members who sometimes force the Rules of Procedure a little and speak on points of order which are not strictly related to a breach of a rule of procedure. I try to be balanced and, as you saw, when I saw that there was a surplus of speeches I had them postponed precisely so as not to disrupt the voting procedure. Let's continue with the requests.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, it nice to see you in the Chair. Congratulations on how you handled the session. This report is a neat symbol of how the European Union can’t see anything that it doesn’t want to regulate. The idea that recreational fisheries – something that has been self—regulating for as long as human civilisation has existed, or indeed longer – needs to be brought within the jurisdiction of the European Union and subjected to the strictures of the common fisheries policy is a measure of the ambition that we have in these Brussels institutions. The European Union, I think, has learned from the bad PR of the last time that it tried to do this, when it was literally wanting to count every fish landed, even from people fishing on the rocks. It has now done what it usually does, which is to pay for a lobby group, supposedly representing the anglers, who are in fact a group created by the Commission, and then pretend that the legislation is representative of the sector. But stand back and ask the question: why does any of this need to be regulated at EU level at all? If we can’t allow this kind of activity to be flourishing outside the sphere of political control, then truly we have no limits whatever to our ambition.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, my explanation of vote is precisely the opposite of that of the colleague who has spoken before. I voted in favour of this report on recreational fishing because I believe that it is growing more and more relevant and does have a very significant impact on marine resources. It is therefore the competence of the countries, it is not a competence of the European Union; but because of the weight it's taking, we need to take it into account and it's essential to better manage our marine resources. That is why I think it is appropriate that there should be regulation in the future within the Community fisheries policy. It has also been essential to me in this report that we have real data on this sector that we do not know about. Right now we're speculating, but we don't know what the real data are and, of course, we need clear definitions of recreational fishing, sport fishing and commercial fishing.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I support my colleague who has just spoken about the need for regulation. I think the question is: will it be effective?  I know that those engaged in recreational fisheries are concerned also that the regulation we bring in will work for them. While I have the floor in my support for this report, there is a huge voluntary effort amongst fishermen and -women, both at sea and inland, who look after our resources on a voluntary basis, who teach and encourage young people into the skill and hobby of fishing. Lastly, those whom I know who enjoy recreational fishing tend to have a good disposition, so it does a great deal for the wellbeing of those who engage in this activity. We want it to be sustainable, we wanted it to continue. So if we are regulating (and we are), let’s be effective in how we do it.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, when we were talking about clearing obligations, I want to use my time to talk about the importance of the single market. Today in the House of Commons, British MPs will begin debating amendments on the Brexit Bill. It will come as no surprise to this House that, as a Labour MEP who has committed my time in politics to Europe, I am against Brexit and I do not support the UK leaving the European Union and thus the single market. Yet the UK could remain as part of the single market through an amendment on the EEA. I urge those who are in the House of Commons today and tomorrow and who will be voting on these issues to look at the EEA amendment to support jobs, support livelihoods and to support prosperity. An estimated 300 000 jobs in Scotland alone rely on our access to the single market. The estimate across the UK is something in the region of 3 million. So for the future of my country, if we are no longer going to be part of the single market through the EU, we need to be part of the single market through the EEA, an option that is open to MPs. I urge them to support the amendments today in the House of Commons.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The Regulation is in line with the Commission's effective and effective regulatory programme to safeguard financial stability and reduce risks. Urgent measures are needed to mitigate the threat to the financial system and increase the transparency of financial markets. The Regulation also clarifyes the provision of trade retrakories and allows for reciprocal access. Control powers are a deterrent to economic operators who want to take advantage of the market for speculative purposes. The tightening of fines also serves this purpose. The Regulation amends the rules on pension schemes and increases security. In my view, there is a need for uniform Community legislation in this area, so I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the European Union is discussing the common rules in the field of civil aviation and the provisions for the European Union Aviation Security Agency, but at the same time is turning a blind eye to what is happening in the Aegean, where Turkey is violating Greek airspace. Turkish fighters every day violate the ATHENS F.I.P. They don't abide by flight-related rules. Turkey's warplanes harass not only military aircraft but also civilian aircraft that are over-flying the FIP Athens. There is therefore a risk of an accident and measures must be taken against Turkey in order to ensure the safety of flights in the Aegean. That is why a decisive signal must be sent to Turkey that it will be in danger of stopping European Union-Turkey flights if it continues to violate the Athens FC.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This is a good report, and much needed. A fellow Marinescu should be thanked for his fairly quick work. I stress that we are making up for it today, and we are actually chasing it. It is a pity that with some costs. However, I would like to draw attention to one element that constantly eerilys us. Well, we need to focus not only on regulation, but also on the need to build systems for efficient identification, above all, of drones and other vehicles that violate space. The second element, equally important, concerns the possibility of neutralizing them. This is something we should be working on very quickly, because it will really determine safety, not the rules on vehicle identification or registration itself.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report’s new rules, so that the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) can collect data on links between poor working conditions and flight safety. I believe it is vital, as exploitative employment models soar at low-cost airlines. Take Ryanair pilots and first officers, based at Stansted in my constituency. Many are not directly employed by the airline but are employed as contractors, meaning that they do not have access to sick pay. Some Ryanair pilots have told me that they go into work not feeling 100%, as otherwise they won’t get paid. I have yet to meet a passenger who wants their pilot to be feeling a bit under the weather. When you’re hurtling through the air at 500 miles an hour at 30 000 feet, you want a pilot to be on top of their game. Of course, currently this is all anecdotal, but thanks to this vote, now we’ve got the power to truly discover what price safety.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: – Mr President, it is very good news that we can finally ensure an efficient system for monitoring and reporting emissions of heavy vehicles. It's an important step, even if it's not a definitive step. We believe that it would be appropriate to talk here too about food transport, an issue precisely where the rural world and the urban world are facing each other; because we have to go back to the consumption of proximity, to connect countryside and city if we really want to save this planet. There are reports that road transported freight volumes will increase in Europe to an annual average of 3% by 2020; therefore, improving fuel and vehicle efficiency may not be enough. We need European legislation that really combats air pollution, that walks towards the practical elimination of combustion engine-operated vehicles, which are precisely the main cause of this type of pollution.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the draft report because the aim of the report is to eliminate the knowledge gap and achieve market transparency. This step will allow relevant data calculated by manufacturers to be monitored and made available to the public in accordance with the certification methodology.  This information to be transmitted to the Commission will also be able to be passed on to third parties, which I appreciate, which they will therefore ask for. These third parties, including universities, regional governments, NGOs, will therefore be able to independently verify the veracity of the data provided by manufacturers in order to prevent new scandals, such as the diesel emissions scandal.  The next follow-up step is to set stricter standards for CO2 emissions for heavy-duty vehicles in accordance with the Paris Convention. Here I would like to say, of course, I support the Paris Convention and for this reason I also supported the draft report.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Heavy goods vehicles account for 5% of the UNION's CO2 emissions and regulation is therefore justified in this area. The current EU framework does not allow the available information to be comparative. This situation thus does not encourage market participants to increase energy efficiency and innovate. The Regulation is intended to monitor CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles registered in the EU. The data will be handled by the European Environment Agency, which will be submitted by member state authorities and car manufacturers and will be publicly available. The proposal will undoubtedly bring positive results in terms of increasing fuel efficiency and reducing air pollution. In view of the above, I supported the proposal.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – –I voted in favour of this dossier because I believe that, in order to meet the targets of the Paris Agreement, all sectors of activity have to make their contribution and the reality is that the heavy vehicle market is slow to adapt to the new reality, which requires greater efficiency in the sector in order to be able to meet the reduction of CO2 emissions. Without regulation that is both ambitious and effective, we will never get there. Member States and the business sector that understand the priority of climate change are calling for reductions of around 24% in CO2 emissions for heavy goods vehicles. The industry needs measures that require these objectives to be complied with and that is a clear sign that change is immediate. We need more transparency in monitoring and checking CO2 emissions and I look kindly at European harmonisation through the Vecto testing system for greater comparability between vehicles, using real-time measurements and independent laboratories being able to verify the data. I hope this is a way to end the blame that has delayed the inevitable.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, I was happy to support this resolution because the effort to gradually reduce emissions is right, of course. Freight transport accounts for around a quarter of road transport emissions and this share is still increasing, and it is therefore important to encourage manufacturers to produce not only safer but also greener vehicles. All the more so because, unlike countries such as the United States, China, Canada or Japan, the European Union is the only total that does not apply the limits on truck emissions. I think that is such a surprising thing, because this is very serious. Those truck emissions are huge. However, it is equally important that Member States come up with concrete solutions to help people who lose their jobs in environmentally demanding sectors in the future, because road transport, whether freight or bus, is not only ecologically demanding, but also an area threatened by robotisation, namely autonomous cars. That is also why we need to think about whether new, more perfect cars will not overcharging transport services and will not be a serious intervention in the sector. After all, there are many people working here, also in Slovakia, and they have important business contracts with abroad, which indirectly employ many people in Slovakia.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, this report rightly sets a vision for education that is about broadening horizons and encouraging young people to have the highest possible ambition and aspiration. But that will never be fully possible while we still have universities that have admissions systems that disadvantage young people from certain backgrounds, while university fees are too high, while we have Erasmus opportunities not available to enough young people from working class backgrounds, and while we still have the outrageous scandal of unpaid internships in this House, in other political institutions and in other sectors as well. The best educational opportunities are not a luxury for the richest. They must always be for the many, and not the few.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Thank you, Mr President. Education is a matter for the Member States, and it must remain so. But there is still a world to be won when it comes to cooperation between Member States in this area. And local initiatives can make a difference. When I look in my own region: exchange projects between Dutch and Walloon schools, teachers who temporarily join a German school to learn the language, cross-border internship projects and so on. That is where the added value of cross-border education lies. And we do not have to arrange this in Brussels, but we can facilitate and encourage it, and I am glad that this house is endorsing it. There is a clear European challenge when it comes to, for example, children of travelling parents such as fairground operators or circus performers. We must ensure that these people have access to high-quality education for their children via computer, wherever they are in Europe. There are already a number of Member States, where this is a possibility. But please let us make this possible for all children in Europe.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The report on the modernisation of education in the Union contains some content that is difficult to accept. That is why I voted against. Education in the classical sense includes teaching, education with attitudes towards good and evil, and prevention.  There is no definition of the identity of a man who, acting creatively and pragmatically, strives for career, self-realization and well-being. However, mental health is largely based on respect for moral principles. And morality based on destruction leads to disorder. Ethical values arise from an understanding of the idea of truth about the transcendental nature of man. And the so-called constituted ethics, based solely on human reasoning, are inherently flawed, including the fight against gender stereotypes, excluding natural differences between man and woman. Similarly, the emphasis on visualisation is limiting, as the main medium of education is the word.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this is a very topical issue, especially in our European Union. There are 6.3 million children aged between 14 and 25 who are leaving school this time, which means permanent damage to the generations that follow, especially in terms of competitiveness and integration. I believe that we must push for an additional fixed allocation from the Member States, especially in order to guarantee education that is equal to the competition that the European Union has at world level, now made for large geographical areas, especially for technological development and development that also sees the possibility of being multilingual. I believe that this is a gap which, in some parts of Europe, must be closed by an accelerated march.  Then there is another aspect that needs to be highlighted: the growth of bullying in school facilities that must be fought with strength, determination and approaches that allow children to avoid this kind of trend that is increasingly present. I believe that it is precisely on these issues that we are worth continuing to invest. It is precisely in this direction that the report is heading in this direction, and I have therefore voted for it with great conviction.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted in favour of the report on the modernisation of education because I consider this subject to be one of the most important in today's politics. The development of new technologies has brought numerous challenges for education systems, and the wave of change coming with digitalisation is referred to by many as tsunamis for which we are not ready. The traditional place of learning, the school, is today complemented by many other available sources of information, but they are not always reliable and reliable.  Changes in the economy, including digitalisation, automation, robotisation of the labour market, have increased demand for high-skilled workers and certain skills. By 2020, there will be more than 750,000 jobs vacant by professionals in the new technology sectors, and in the life sciences and mathematics sectors, the shortage of workers will reach 200,000 during this period.  The biggest problem of the EU labour market – including national education systems – is the lack of a workforce with the qualifications to meet the needs of the economy. It is worth remembering that more than 40% of Europeans do not have basic digital skills, leading to the emergence of serious barriers to their entry into the high-tech labour market. Therefore, any changes to education systems should lead to improved digital skills among citizens through appropriate education at an early stage. Let's start acting because it's very late.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the European The report contains a number of positive elements and assigns the implementation tool, such as Erasmus+. Nevertheless, I abstained during the referendum because the reporter expects all Member States to incorporate unilateral EU propaganda into the secondary school curriculum and to develop a separate non-existent IDENTITY of an EU citizen. The issue of the education and training of migrants is being raised with such an excessive emphasis that it means accepting that in the coming years the European continent will become a continent of immigrants. The wording of the report, the mandatory expectations, ignore the fact that education is otherwise a national competence.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, it has become such a habit, I must say, a bad habit in this Parliament, that it constantly expresses itself on matters that are not within its competence or at all within the competence of the EU, and this is precisely the case with this report on the modernisation of teaching.  I can, of course, agree with many parts of this report, with the emphasis on digitalisation, on the so-called knowledge society or on the role of scientific and technical subjects in teaching, but that is not the point. The point is that teaching or education and teaching policy is not the competence of the EU, but the competence of the Member States. These determine the structure of education and the requirements that are placed on education. Of course, the EU can contribute by organising and co-financing various exchange programmes, such as ERASMUS, but it does not organise teaching, and therefore we should not cross these borders, although I understand that some colleagues are improving parliamentary statistics with these reports.  I therefore did not vote in favour of this report and abstained.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, if we teach our children today as they did yesterday, we are robbing them of the future. Unfortunately, this introduction to the resolution on modernising education accurately describes the problem of our Slovak education as well. That is precisely what our ministers are doing, and children who do not receive a quality education are paying for their gamble. The European Parliament's report makes it clear that teachers must be involved in the reform not as guinea pigs, but as co-creators. However, the education leadership is doing the complete opposite with us and ignoring teachers' demands for the necessary changes. For the foreseeable future, we face challenges such as robotisation. The best option to remain competitive for Slovakia is precisely investment in education. Schools must be the centre of critical thinking, training, problem solving, teamwork, relationship building. I am very sorry that our children themselves feel that the only way to get a quality education is to study abroad. And just as parents from Slovakia are forced to leave for work far from their families, up to thirty thousand young people go abroad to study, half of whom want to stay abroad after graduation. Nevertheless, I could not support this resolution, as it again contains, quite senselessly, a paragraph on gender ideology and intervenes in this area, but also in others, in the subsidiarity of the Member States ...  (The Speaker's presiding officer interrupted)

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – I voted in favour of the report on modernising education in the European Union because I believe that it highlights pressing problems in this area. First of all, I fully support the thesis that teachers should be given special attention. They are the 100 000 people of any education system, and without their direct participation, no education reform can be successful. Decent pay is not enough. Teachers need to have access to retraining and qualification opportunities throughout their careers in order to be able to adapt more easily to new challenges.  Secondly, I defend the thesis that modernising education should not be understood solely as an improvement in the material base of schools and investment in modern digital infrastructure. The availability of modern technologies does not guarantee that knowledge, skills and competences are better absorbed. There are still 70 million Europeans across the European Union who do not have basic skills such as reading, writing and calculus. These statistics are eloquent enough.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, I would like to stress that the report on the modernisation of education in the Union, adopted today, recommends in paragraph 134 that Member States integrate learning on the Union into their secondary education curriculums in order to familiarise students with the functioning of the Union, its history and the values of European citizenship. Looks good to me. For years I have been calling for a better understanding of the institutions of the European Union, their background, their functioning and their objectives in schools in the Member States. Only what is known is valued. Hence he has repeatedly requested the creation of a kind of 'European subject'. In this regard, I would like to stress that last month the Council adopted a recommendation proposed by Commissioner Navracsics which is precisely in this direction. The European Union will accompany young Europeans throughout their lives. It should be studied carefully in their family centres. It should not be studied lightly or superficially, like any other international organization. The European Union is much more important to young Europeans than the rest of the international organisations born after World War II and must therefore know it well.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, thanks to two very excellent programmes, I get to spend a lot of time in schools. One of them is run nationally in Ireland, and it is called the Blue Star Programme for primary school children. It does an exceptional job in telling and teaching children about culture, heritage and history, and when I go into schools I am invigorated by the little ones telling me back what they are learning, and they love it. I recommend it to you, and I will spread the word. And thank you to the wonderful teachers who promote this programme. The second is our own programme: the Ambassador School Programme for secondary level pupils, and here again, the tremendous engagement in those schools that are part of this programme is just to behold. It roots out cynicism and ignorance about the European Union, and promotes an absolutely wonderful ideal for Europe, which we have yet to attain.  While I still have the floor for four seconds, I would say to our teachers and schools around Europe that we do value the work you do and we want to work more closely with you.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: - Mr President, Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. My first word is satisfaction. The European Parliament has laid down a clear, transparent, achievable vision in the Iturgaiz report for the development of the European aquaculture sector, and I am therefore pleased to vote in favour of this. I welcome the fact that many of my proposals have been carried through in this report. However, I would like to point out that, unfortunately, my reasonable proposal was not supported by Parliament. At present, fish farmers are not rewarded for ecosystem services that are of conservation importance, while sustaining wildlife of European importance. Freshwater lake farms, for example, return the water they use thanks to their recirculation systems, usually in better quality than when they were taken out. These ponds are a resting, feeding and breeding place for migratory and migratory birds, as well as for fauna with a life bound to domestic waters. Therefore, fish farmers deserve a greening premium just as much as farmers. This WTO green box aid would significantly stabilise the livelihoods of fish farmers. I call on the European Commission to propose the introduction of such support in the post-2020 fisheries policy.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: – Mr President, I would really like the rapporteur of this report to explain to us how the promotion of the local economy and sustainability is compatible with aquaculture laws such as the one that his party, the People's Party, wanted to promote in Galicia, for example.  To tell us what sustainability was this one that spoke of obtaining maximum productive use, that allowed actions in protected areas and that also allowed the cultivation of invasive alien species. The blue economy, like the green economy, does not seek to encourage, does not focus on the sustainability of resources, but puts it, quite the contrary, on how to continue doing business with them without taking into account that they are limited. Sustainable aquaculture cannot under any circumstances become the perfect excuse to give greater alibi and to favor large companies. Sustainable aquaculture means betting on the local economy and family businesses, promoting responsible consumption and reducing food waste.  Sea people have long been denouncing that there is a clear intention to dismantle the artisanal fishing fleet and favour a very particular model that will value large enterprises to the detriment of small businesses and economies of scale to the detriment of proximity consumption. How long will we continue to encourage this type of trade and market from these institutions?

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, blue growth places aquaculture among the sectors with the greatest potential in terms of sustainable jobs and growth. However, aquaculture production in the European Union is going through a recession and, as the sector directly employs some 85 000 people in Europe, especially small and medium-sized enterprises and micro-enterprises, this decline also has important repercussions on the European and also the Italian labour market. There are some 800 plants operating on our national territory alone, producing 140 000 tonnes of fresh produce per year, or about 40 % of national fish production.  Despite these numbers, the sector is still the victim of many problems, first of all the lack of financial support within the EMFF, around 15 %, or the lack of transparency on concessions, which often leads to the non-application of environmental standards.  In addition, information must be provided on the use of vaccines and antibiotics in aquaculture, in view of the possible risks to human health and also to the ecosystem, and bearing in mind the problem of antimicrobial and antibiotic resistance at the level of the entire chain.  Finally, fish feed must come from sustainable sources and must not undermine the maximum sustainable yield targets of the common fisheries policy, possibly by increasing the use of seaweed and other algae. All these requests have been accepted by my colleague and we have therefore supported her work.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report, which I think is important in highlighting the importance of aquaculture in Europe and some of the problems it currently has. The European Union is the world's first market for fisheries and aquaculture products. Member States are currently importing 60% of the total of what all Europeans consume. This indicates that aquaculture can play a much more relevant role, and this sector therefore has great potential in the European Union. And yet what's happening isn't that. Global production outside the European Union has grown by 7% annually since 2000, while aquaculture production in Europe has entered recession over the past decade. That is why the opportunity of this report. It means that we have the potential to continue to grow, and to do so, investments in innovation must be made. Aquaculture finally provides high quality products, with high standards of sustainability and consumer protection. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to support this sector.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my support for the report 'Towards a sustainable and competitive European aquaculture sector' prepared by my colleague Carlos Iturgaiz. Its aim is for aquaculture to be prominent in the European Union economy where, unfortunately, it is not making progress. While aquaculture has grown dramatically in other parts of the world over the past ten years, particularly in Asia, European production in general is stagnant. In Spain it is an important activity, especially in my land (Galicia), for example, the prestigious mussel sector.  The European Union is the world's leading importer of fishery products. Many of these imports come from aquaculture. More than half of European aquaculture consumption is served by extra-European products. Therefore, our market offers European aquaculture ample space to develop, but our companies face numerous bureaucratic difficulties and also obstacles to accessing suitable spaces. Moreover, it is not easy to make your way through the already important competition for non-European products. All this means losing opportunities for wealth and also employment in a Europe, especially the southern Europe, which needs to continue to create jobs. Hence the need, Mr President, to strongly promote aquaculture in Europe as pursued by the report we have just voted on.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As Mr Hannan rightly said earlier, the european Union's concern seems unlimited. The Member must know everything and speak out on every subject. We have just been worried about the difference between sport fishing and recreational fishing, and members are already sneering at how sinister the advice is against our snails.  There are advantages to this report, it calls for the liberalisation of licensing, so as not to discourage investors, but on the other hand, the Union prides itself on its restrictions and restrictive requirements. This works in such a way that, first, the Union imposes strict requirements, which makes on-the-spot production unprofitable. Consumers choose cheaper imported products, and the Union therefore bans their imports, imposes restrictions on imported products and calls for this process to be deepened. And then she instructs the whole world and auges the whole world that everyone should do as she does. This only leads to consumers being dissatisfied.  In addition, paragraph 74, of course, emphasises the important role of women in the aquaculture sector. Can we not accept a single declaration in which we will emphasise the important role of women in everything simply and finally conclude this subject? I voted against.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Before closing the sitting, I wanted to thank the interpreters once again for their very important work, today as always, and to renew the commitment of myself and the other members of the Bureau to a positive resolution of the current deadlock in the negotiations. Surely there will be the utmost commitment and willingness on my part and on the part of the other Members to find a solution that we hope will be absolutely consensual.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Iran nuclear agreement (2018/2715(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I believe it is very timely that we are discussing the nuclear deal with Iran just today. You know that just a few hours ago the United States and the DPRK ended their summit in Singapore. Today’s summit between the two proves that diplomacy and dialogue are the only way forward, in this case towards lasting peace on the Korean peninsula and beyond. Let me say that, in more general terms, this is a clear sign of the fact that the diplomatic track is often challenging, is often the most difficult one to be followed, but it is always the rewarding one and needs to be sustained over time. It was the same track that the international community and the European Union followed for over a decade with Iran, resulting in the signing, almost exactly three years ago, of the nuclear deal. We did it because it was in our security interest – our European security interest and the global security interest. Through this deal we prevented nuclear proliferation, we avoided a regional escalation and we made sure that Iran would never acquire a nuclear weapon – ever. Three years on, the deal is delivering. Iran abides by its nuclear-related commitments, as has been confirmed 11 times by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the last time was just a few weeks ago. Our position as Europeans has not changed. On the contrary, we have seen the reasons why this agreement was a good agreement. We remain committed to the full and effective implementation of the nuclear deal with Iran. What today is different is that on 8 May the United States took the unilateral decision to withdraw from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), the nuclear deal with Iran, which is a multilateral agreement unanimously endorsed by the UN Security Council with resolution 2231. The European Union reacted in an immediate and united manner, as also agreed at the top level by the Heads of State and Government of all European Union Member States, in Sofia, on 16 May and reconfirmed, just a couple of weeks ago, by the Foreign Ministers of the 28 Member States at our last Foreign Affairs Council. Since a month ago, the bulk of the international community has confirmed and reiterated the strong support for the nuclear agreement with Iran, simply for a very pragmatic reason – that there is no better alternative and the world cannot afford a nuclear arms race. In particular, I would add, the world cannot afford a nuclear arms race in the Middle East.
