This support from the rest of the international community is something I experience every single day in my meetings, be it with the Chinese Foreign Minister or the Japanese Foreign Minister or the African Union Chairman or our colleagues from Latin America or the rest of Europe that are not part of the European Union. This features always very high on the agenda. How can we partner together and make sure that the agreement stays in place. And, let me say, here the European Union has a responsibility also to share with partners around the world, which is how to maintain one of the few functioning pillars of the nuclear non—proliferation architecture.  This support was also reiterated by the other co—signatories of the nuclear agreement – France, Germany, the United Kingdom, Russia and China. We convened and we chaired, as the European Union, the first Joint Commission without the United States on 25 May in Vienna. The work on the implementation of nuclear—related commitments continues. This is essential for security. For instance, the Arak reactor modernisation project led by China continues, as does the conversion of the Fordow facility into a Nuclear Physics and Technology Centre, a project led by Russia. A dedicated workshop on Fordow is foreseen to take place later this week.  It is essential for our own security and for the security of the region that implementation work continues and we are guaranteeing that this happens, regardless of the US withdrawal. Implementation must continue, both on the nuclear commitments and also on the economic track, because the other essential part of the nuclear deal is the lifting of sanctions and the opportunities it creates for normalised trade and economic relations. From this perspective, the US decision to withdraw from the JCPOA and to re—impose all secondary sanctions is extremely problematic and needs to be addressed, first of all by the European Union, by its Member States, and by the rest of the international community at large. Many European companies have chosen to do business with Iran after the agreement was signed and are doing so in good faith, based on commitments made by the international community, as I said, based on the implementation of the UN Security Council resolution unanimously adopted. Some of them have already announced now that they would discontinue their engagement so as to avoid US penalties. Others have informed that they would withdraw from negotiations that had already started – leaving, by the way, the economic investment space to other players in the world, which also is not in the European interest. This has created, as you can imagine, and as you know, enormous pressure inside Iran, especially from those who have always opposed the agreement, and the credibility of the entire international community, of the multilateral system, of the UN system, is being questioned. The recent statements by Iran on uranium hexafluoride must be seen in this context. These announcements are clearly not a violation of the nuclear deal, but it is also clear they do not contribute to build confidence and they are meant to put pressure on the international community. The letter sent by President Rouhani to the Heads of State and Government of France, Germany and the UK is to be interpreted exactly in the same context.  It’s clear that our strategic and security interest is to save, to preserve this nuclear deal. We have reacted in a firm, decisive and united manner to protect at the same time our security interests, and let me say, in this way, our economic sovereignty. This is also an incentive, I would say the incentive, for Iran to continue to comply with its nuclear restrictions. Any other alternative could have tragic consequences and it would make us all less secure, with no exceptions.  As a first major step, last Wednesday, the European Commission adopted two delegated acts. The first is an update of the blocking statute, which forbids EU companies to comply with US secondary sanctions. The second is an extension of the lending mandate of the European Investment Bank to support economic activities in Iran. After a period of non—objection, both acts should enter into force on 5 August, just before the first batch of US sanctions takes effect on 6 August. The support of this Parliament to conclude both processes swiftly will be of the essence and extremely important, also as a political sign. We are also working on concrete measures aimed at sustaining our cooperation in key economic sectors, particularly on banking and finance, trade and investment, oil and transport. In this work we keep a strong focus on small and medium—sized enterprises which are less engaged in the US market.  The most important challenge now is to find solutions on banking and finance, because legitimate trade and investment need banking partners and financial models that work. These issues are being addressed through intensive expert consultations, happening basically on a daily basis, including in Brussels and in Tehran last week, but also at the political level.  As I mentioned, we worked on this with EU Member States’ Foreign Ministers at the last Foreign Affairs Council. We focused in particular on the need to combine our work at EU level, with the two measures I just mentioned and the work that is ongoing at the expert level, with action from single Member States to protect national economic operators. This is the only way to be effective in this endeavour – to combine EU—level measures and national measures in a coordinated manner.  This is why we decided, and we have started to do so, to set up a network of national focal points of all EU Member States to further coordinate and intensify our work. This is essential to keep Iran in the nuclear agreement.  Of course, Iran also needs to do its part – and this is very clear – to improve its standards against money laundering and terrorist financing and step up banking reforms. These are essential steps to make Iran more attractive to European businesses and banks.  Last week, the Foreign and Finance Ministers of France, Germany and the UK, together with myself, wrote a letter to the US Secretaries of State and of the Treasury. We expressed our expectation that the extra—territorial effects of US secondary sanctions will not be enforced on EU entities and individuals, and that the United States respect the good faith of economic operators within EU legal territory, and we asked for a number of specific exemptions.  Let me be very clear. First of all, this is not an economic issue for Europe. This is a security issue for Europe, and the main thing is the nuclear non—proliferation efforts we’re making. Second, our determination to preserve the deal is also in the interests of the United States, because preserving the nuclear deal is essential to our common security, both for Europe, for the United States and for the entire Middle East, which might otherwise fall into a spiral of nuclear proliferation and of an even more dangerous level of conflictuality.  Think for one moment of the scenario without the nuclear agreement in place tomorrow and you’ll realise how dangerous this would be for all of us.  Preserving the nuclear deal is also essential to maintaining our unique and precious – even if difficult – channels of communication with Iran. The nuclear deal was never meant to solve or to address all issues in our relations with Iran. On the contrary, at the very beginning, meaning some 15 years ago now, that the purpose of the agreement would have been limited to only nuclear issues. Like it or not, that was the mandate the High Representative at that time received from the UN Security Council, and this is the mandate that was fulfilled.  Having a nuclear deal in place with Iran has opened up a window to address other issues that are not nuclear—related and that are there and that are our issues of concern as much as they are American issues of concern. They are outside the scope of the nuclear deal; they always have been. They need to be addressed. We believe that they can be better addressed on the basis of maintaining the nuclear deal with Iran, rather than on the basis of destroying it.  I’ll give you a couple of examples of small windows that have opened up in our dialogue and political talks with Iran on issues that are not related to the nuclear ones. We have had the opportunity to discuss ballistic missiles, regional issues and human rights in the EU—Iran high level political dialogue and in other meetings – quite a unique formation, especially for the West.  I’ll be very clear, we have serious issues with Iran’s behaviour and stance in those fields. This is no mystery – either for us, or for them – but they are not linked to the nuclear agreement implementation and they would not be easier to deal with at all without the nuclear deal in place. On the contrary, let me say by experience that during all the years of negotiations of the nuclear deal anything else that was not nuclear—related was basically off the table. Once you keep and consolidate the nuclear deal with Iran and make its survival beyond question, then the space opens up to deal with other issues.  We are addressing these issues in their own right, in direct contacts such as on Yemen. On this, I would like to share with you that we have set up a regional dialogue with Iran, chaired by us, by the European Union, with the participation of France, Germany, Italy and the UK. So far this dialogue has focused on Yemen and it has already delivered one step that was important – helping organise the visit of the UN special envoy Mr Griffiths to Sana’a at the beginning of June, to meet with the Houthi leadership. We will discuss further steps of this work exactly with the special envoy of the United Nations at the next Foreign Affairs Council to see how we can use our channels to try and make the work to solve the Yemen crisis more effective.  If the nuclear deal collapsed, it would also be much more difficult to address our non—nuclear concerns that we have. The current tensions on the nuclear deal have already narrowed the space for discussing all the other issues and we believe it is in nobody’s interest to close the channels that currently remain open. Again, the only outcome would be to give more space to those in the region, including in Iran, that argue for more radical positions.  Our position on the Iran nuclear deal is based on our principles and it is based on pragmatism. The nuclear deal makes Europe more secure and prevents a nuclear arms race in the Middle East. It brings economic benefits to the people of Iran, and it should continue to do so, and it opens precious new channels – albeit difficult ones, as I said – for diplomacy and dialogue.  This is why we are determined to preserve the nuclear deal and prevent a new escalation of tensions in an already troubled region and world, because Europe and the world cannot afford wasting all of this.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by thanking you, Mrs Mogherini, warmly for the comprehensive presentation of the situation and also personally – And I believe on behalf of all Members who are interested in foreign affairs in this Parliament – for your very personal commitment on this very important issue. I am sure we all agree in this House: the Iran agreement has never been perfect, we must all be aware of that. Nevertheless, it remains the right way to prevent a nuclear-armed Iran, as you have just said. And the fact that, according to the International Atomic Energy Agency, there is "no credible evidence" of an Iranian nuclear weapons program after 2009 is just to blame for this agreement. That is why the American decision is so difficult to understand. But I would like to make one more point: Iran's internal and foreign policy role remains highly problematic. Mrs Mogherini, you have just mentioned this: the massive violations of human rights, the ballistic missile programme, the destabilising role in countries such as Iraq, Syria or Yemen, support for Hezbollah in Lebanon and, last but not least, the aggressive threats against Israel are unacceptable to us, and we hope, High Representative, that these issues will continue to be addressed openly and unequivocally at all political levels. You deserve the support of the European Parliament.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I will start by saying that there is nothing strategic in dismantling our common EU—USA achievements throughout history, dismantling the multilateral rule-based system or calling into question the high value of multilateral diplomatic victories. For the sake of clarity, the Iran deal required the country to eliminate 98% of its uranium stockpile, dismantle and seal two thirds of its centrifuges, cap uranium enrichment at levels well below weapons grade and remove the core of its plutonium reactor. Today the sweeping inspections regime of the International Atomic Energy Agency certifies that Iran is complying with all its commitments. Yes, the deal is key for nuclear non—proliferation and should be kept in place as long as possible. This is key for global peace and security and is in the interests of the international community, including the USA and Iran. The credibility of the USA negotiating future nuclear agreements, notably the one with North Korea is now at stake. Today, after the summit between President Trump and President Kim Jong—un I can only hope that the North Korean deal will be as ambitious as the Iranian one. At the same time, this is to protect European companies in the light of the reintroduction of American sanctions. Thus, the S&D Group welcomes the Commission proposal to activate the blocking statute. It goes without saying that the dialogue with the United States should continue. Nevertheless, in order to address separate issues, such as Iran’s presence in Syria and its support for the bloody Assad regime and the development of ballistic missiles, in parallel we call on the EU to take all necessary measures to ensure tangible economic benefits for Iran. Finally, we are living in turbulent times. It is therefore key for the European Union to stand firm and unite in the face of this challenge.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the signing of the JCPOA with Iran in 2015 was a breakthrough to halt the march towards nuclear proliferation in an unstable region. According to the IAEA’s verification and monitoring programme, although the limits were probed and are being probed, no outright violations have been detected to date. I would like also to take the opportunity to acknowledge the role of Baroness Ashton and the role of the European External Action Service in bringing the deal to fruition back in 2015.  President Trump’s decision, therefore, to pull out now and risk unravelling this finely-tuned agreement is baffling. It sends all the wrong signals to the other wannabe nuclear states, including the DPRK. The remaining EU signatories have a vital role now. On the one hand, the US must be persuaded that the deal is still our best tool against nuclear proliferation, and on the other hand, Iran must be encouraged to continue to meet all its obligations. Finding ways to financially protect the European Union companies doing business with Iran will indeed be challenging. In Europe, of course we do not share common values with the Iranian Government. There are still other major issues of concern to be addressed, such as the Iranian ballistic missile programme, its involvement in proxy wars in the region, gross human rights violations and supporting terrorism, but we must not let one poorly-advised anti-multilateralist president destroy an agreement that has, at its heart, the desire to maintain a more peaceful world. I am very grateful that brexiting Britain is backing the European Union, not its traditional ‘special relationship’ partner, the United States, on this very important issue.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, after the G7, President Trump left not a millimetre of doubt about his opposition to his main allies. Anyone who was not yet convinced now knows the EU needs foreign and security autonomy. Our strength is tested in the process of keeping the spirit of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) alive. The EU has chosen, with international partners, to bind and verify Iran’s nuclear programme through the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), and our part of the deal is lifting sanctions. Of course, we are committed to peace, diplomatic solutions and, first and foremost, that which we ourselves have signed up for. So to have this policy autonomy is key. Certainly, to have the US choose to abandon one of the biggest diplomatic successes at times where these are few and with so much at stake is enough for us to absorb, and so we simply cannot accept that Washington spells out which sanctions our European companies are bound by. I would be interested in what is possible to mitigate US extra territoriality without pushing private-sector risks into public institutions. At the same time, our autonomy must be clear in Tehran. Iranian leaders cannot and must not dictate what we in Europe should do. Iran itself must build confidence that they are committed to their part of the deal if they expect us to try and work hard to absorb the challenge of the US stepping back. I’m interested to learn a bit more about how conversations with China and Russia are going, because the spotlight is so much on us. In previous debates, I have made clear that I believe that we have lost too much time focusing only on Iran’s nuclear programme and not on the country’s toxic role in the Middle East as well as the systematic human rights violations against the Iranian people. I urge you to make sure the EU has a broad agenda in relation to Iran and not to be trapped in the single issue of saving the deal, however important that may be.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I, too, would like to express my sincere thanks to you for your commitment and for the things that you have already achieved, High Representative. If Europe follows President Trump's will and also re-applies sanctions against Iran, Iran will resume nuclear weapons production, and a nuclear arms race in the Middle East will begin. For if Iran has nuclear weapons, then its arch-enemy Saudi Arabia will certainly not be deterred from procuring them as well. And Saudi Arabia would certainly not be the only country that, on the one hand, is reaching for the bomb and, on the other, supporting terrorists. We must prevent this by all means. Europe must prevail against Donald Trump, who wants to punish all companies that trade with Iran. Our best measure, on the other hand, is an old regulation, which you, High Representative, have already mentioned: the blocking regulation, which helps European companies wishing to trade with Iran. This regulation compensates all companies that are no longer able to carry out their activities in the United States because of their trade with Iran. We have no choice but to take the measures you are proposing. Trade between Europe and Iran must not be stopped. I expect the European Parliament and also the Council of Ministers to agree with you in advance and to signal that these measures will be confirmed, because anything else would pose a deadly threat to all of us. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Buchner, we are all interested in Europe's economic relations with all the countries of the world developing as positively as possible. We also have the WTO and the Appellate Body for this, and we are really trying to get things in the right direction, not only multilaterally, but also plurilaterally. Do you believe that it is possible to create a corresponding basis here with Iran, too, that our businesses, the economy, can meet with small and medium-sized enterprises and that both sides will also be in favour of a peaceful solution?

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I think it is possible. We have already started some business and the point is not the money transfer, which is already possible now. The point is what you, High Representative, have mentioned, namely that European banks also give loans and that the usual business with money transfers works. So the answer is yes.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I have thought for quite a long time what I am saying now. For, on the one hand, President Trump is sending signals to end the war and denuclearize on the Korean Peninsula, which we naturally welcome, and on the other hand, he is announcing a treaty on denuclearisation with Iran. He signed a statement from the G7 summit, only to tweet himself off a few minutes later. He dances happily with the Saudi despot during a state visit to Riyadh and denounces the countries that do not suit him as dirty countries. US foreign policy has become unpredictable and therefore arbitrary. The United States, as a serious partner, is only scrupulously perceptible, and it has long since lost its leadership role, which it insists on time and again. We must strengthen the UN and not squat in front of the queue like a rabbit and hope that it does not bite. The time has long since come to go our own way consistently, to remember one's own strength, to do the things that need to be done. The Iran nuclear deal must be preserved. A further escalation in the Middle East can trigger a conflagration in this important region and also destroy the hope of so many people. That is not what we want. Peace – let me conclude – and only peace makes it possible to develop the economy, to fight corruption, to improve the situation of people and to defend human rights effectively. Let us go down this road!

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, look at you from the enemy but from your friend looked at you a hundred times. This aphorism fits perfectly with the complicated situation that has arisen as a result of the American decision to unilaterally withdraw from the Iran nuclear agreement.  This has led the Commission to extend the EIB's mandate to Iran to support our businesses and to dust off the so-called blocking statute, which prohibits European companies from complying with US extraterrestrial sanctions. This game of chess is as big a problem as it is complex. Although the Eu ropean Union and the Member States have repeatedly stated our support for the agreement, the confirmation of secondary sanctions would destroy the economic incentives for Iran, which has in fact threatened to leave in turn. I believe that the US decision to unilaterally leave the agreement is an historic mistake and I firmly believe that it is our duty to do everything possible to safeguard it, despite the fact that the instruments available may not yet be sufficient for the difficult task.  I would like to make one final appeal to President Trump: let us sit down together and, on the basis of the current basis, which is precisely the agreement itself, an agreement that is working, let us start negotiations to extend it, meeting your concerns. As a gesture of good faith, however, the United States at least renounces the application of secondary sanctions to European companies. If we fail, we will see a very dangerous precedent, not only because of further destabilisation and escalation in the region, but because it would become clear that the United States in the first place and the West are no longer reliable partners in keeping their word. Our security, as you said, and not just our trade, is at the end of our business. Ladies and gentlemen, confidence is gaining by drop, but it is lost by litres. It is essential that there should be no rifts between us on this issue, and I say to our US allies: be ware of abandoning multilateralism in favour of bilateral comparisons, it can be a double-edged sword for you too. As an ancient Persian proverb says, "if the cat and mouse come to an agreement, the grocer is ruined."

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have the impression that, faced with an objective reality, that is, whether we like it or not, that the nuclear agreement with Iran is hanging by a thread, Europe's response appears, as it were, opaque.  There was the letter signed by France, Germany, Great Britain and Mrs Mogherini for the European Union, in which the United States was in fact somewhat pleaded to exempt European companies from the consequences of sanctions. I have also heard in this House talking and insisting, rightly and controversially, on this concept of American extraterritoriality. But when has it ever been hindered before? And when, on the many occasions on which we have commented and generally praised this agreement, has there been the scenario – we must always envisage a plan B – that suddenly this agreement could be frustrated? And what would have been the result for our businesses? It is said that we want to protect small and medium-sized enterprises, but the ones that go to face the jobs and the great consequences, in a country like Iran that is not really quiet, are big business and they are all running away.  What is not clearly stated in this debate by Mrs Mogherini is that they all run away, all of them leave, those of the car, those of oil, drawing a very dangerous scenario for Iran, above all, and therefore for the consequences of geopolitics and also of security very dangerous for the whole world.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the agreement on Iran's nuclear programme is undoubtedly perhaps the greatest success of the European Union's foreign policy, because, in addition to controlling Iran's nuclear programme and activities, it has laid the foundations for a peaceful solution to the Middle East problem and has also enabled trade relations with Iran. Large companies, such as Airbus and Total, have entered into trade agreements, the country's economy has grown and strengthened, jobs have increased by 700 000 and Iran has allocated part of the funds to counter terrorism. For all the above reasons, President Trump's decision to unilaterally withdraw the US from the agreement poses risks. First of all, Iran is threatening to withdraw unilaterally from another agreement it has signed with other countries and will resume its nuclear programme at national level, and has recently announced its desire to acquire opportunities for uranium enrichment. In addition, there is a risk that the conflicts between US and Iranian naval forces in the Persian Gulf will resume.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, the Iranian nuclear agreement is, as we all know, a pillar of the global security architecture and an important achievement of the European diplomacy that you are leading.  During the AFET/DROI mission to Tehran in February, I was able to gauge the concern of our Iranian interlocutors about the change in American policy, because they, at the time, were already convinced that Trump was going to do what he did.  We have tried to assure our Iranian interlocutors that Europe will work to preserve this agreement and what you are doing and what the foreign ministers are doing. But I also accepted the dissatisfaction of our Iranian interlocutors with regard to us Europeans. I was shocked by their criticism, particularly in terms of the economic fallout: they blame us, they accuse you that they are not there, and we had to defend you, Madam High Representative. My concern is that they continue to do that, and they continue to say things that are not always in the political philosophy of this agreement. Recently, Ayatollah Khamenei spoke of the increase in Iran's nuclear capability as part of the agreement, which is completely unacceptable. I conclude by saying that I am pleased with what you have said about the possibility of discussing human rights. But I would also like to see concrete results. We discussed the case of Ahmadreza Djalali again here. He is a citizen who also has Swedish nationality and I would like to see him released...  (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mrs Mogherini, we welcome your clear position and the Clear position of the Commission, including the mandate for the European Investment Bank and including the reinstated Blocking Regulation. I do not want to repeat everything that has already been said. Iran has kept to its agreements, the United States of America does not. They have unilaterally resigned, and if they really should impose the sanctions, they will have accepted a breach of the treaty or a breach of international rules. I still consider this to be completely irresponsible. Security in this region has a lot to do with our security. And if Iran doesn't get its benefits, why should it stick to its part of the deal? This will be a threat to all of us, because Saudi Arabia has announced what will happen; Israel has it, too. We cannot accept this danger for all of us simply because a President of the United States no longer has any respect for his allies. Let me make a comment which is also very important to me. I believe that we should once again urge our partners in Iran to finally set up an EU mission in Iran. It is not blocked by us, if I have understood it correctly, but it has so far been blocked by Tehran. If we want to work together more closely, sometimes it has to be done quickly and in a direct way. That is why such an EU mission in Tehran would be exactly the right thing to do.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! The nuclear deal with Iran was problematic from the outset. It is problematic because the American President who included it knew very well that it could not be democratically ratified in the United States Senate. That is why we are now in exactly the same situation as in relation to the Paris climate agreement, that it is the president-elect's prerogative at any time to decide whether to comply or leave the agreement. Beyond that, there is the fundamental issue of the agreement with Iran that it does not include the many aspects of Iranian problematic behavior. We are talking here about the development of ballistic missiles, about a situation where Iran is spreading terror both in the Middle East and in Europe. Basically, therefore, the agreement is not good and thorough enough. That is why, of course, we can sit down, as many people do here, and regret that the Americans have withdrawn from the agreement. We could also try to find a more constructive model where we actually - together with the Americans - find a way to stem the harmful Iranian influence, both in the region and in the rest of the world.

name: Javier NART
text: – Mr President, I make all your words mine, Mrs Mogherini. It has been impeccable, correct and has done an impeccable analysis of the whole situation. When we were in Tehran talking to Ali Akbar Velayati, he said one thing that was very obvious: "We respect the agreement if the agreement respects us." And, therefore, whether we are able to fulfill the exchange between nuclear security with multisecurity and development. If we are unable to secure development because the United States, through its economic pressure, its strategic control of financial movements, blocks it, we must not only go to the Blocking Regulation. Look, Mrs Mogherini, I believe in friendship and collaboration with the United States, just as I think the distance between Washington and Brussels is the same distance as between Brussels and Washington. And so, to be respected, we have to be respectable and we cannot simply comply with our money through the Blocking Regulation. If we are under economic pressures that we are victims of, the only language that trump understands is simply the contradiction.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Commissioner, it is good first of all that the European Union has expressed its full support for the nuclear agreement and has even differentiated itself vertically from the United States for the first time. Of course we all know that this differentiation is about the conflict of energy interests and not just about nuclear. But if we really want the agreement to remain active, interventions are needed to demonstrate this at all levels and not just to protect businesses and investment. This means strengthening the European anti-nuclear position, but strengthening it with actions. The first minimum sample would be for all Member States of the Union to join the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons. Let us not forget that until now only Austria has ratified it.  Commissioner, if you are really interested in peace in the region, put pressure on your important partner, as you call it, Israel, which has not even acceded to the first nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Let us do even the least that will prove the credibility of our wills.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thanks to the nuclear agreement and the end of the embargo, Iran has opened up to the world and many Italian and European companies have resumed trading with iran, investing billions of euros in Iran to create infrastructure and services. Through trade we can improve the situation of the Iranian people and create new job and development opportunities for our businesses, not only large ones as at the beginning, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises, a very interesting market opens up, given the size but also simply referring to what was already quite relevant to our companies before the embargo period. It is clear that the sanctions imposed today by the United States will hinder these projects and, according to the American approach, any company trading with Iran risks losing access to the American market and the ability to use the dollar as a currency for trade, in practice the loss of an essential market and the paralysis of credit. It is clear that there is no legitimacy in these sanctions, because Iran has complied with all the terms of the nuclear agreement. So Europe, as has already been mentioned, must be prepared and help European businesses. The Eu ropean Union should negotiate specific exemptions with the United States, allowing our companies to continue doing business, but member states should also be allowed to provide themselves with ad hoc funds to support companies affected by sanctions and excluded from credit channels, without this form of support being considered state aid.  Every measure should be agreed and harmonised between the different States, because it is precisely the lack of coordination between European states that would do enormous damage to our companies. And it is of course necessary to understand who will pay if they suffer losses. Trade with Iran is certainly important for the Iranians, but it is also important for our companies, and if we do not want to lose it we must run for cover and we must all do it together.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Mr President, for French companies, the Vienna agreement on the Iranian nuclear programme represented a hope of regaining market share in a large country with which France has long had privileged relations. PSA made a dramatic comeback with 450,000 vehicles sold last year and great prospects in this country of 82 million inhabitants. The French carmaker has thus regained the place it had to cede to its American competitor General Motors after an executive order signed by Barack Obama in June 2013. Peugeot and Citroen have long established themselves in Iran and the Iranian market has once again become the first foreign market for them, ahead of China. Iran is also a strategic issue for another French industrial giant, Total, which signed a very large gas contract in July 2017. Iran has the second largest natural gas reserves in the world, just after Russia. Instead of in vain against President Trump's tariff hike, denounce and act against the scandal of the extra-territoriality of American law, which seriously harms our economic interests. A November 1996 Council regulation is supposed to protect European businesses, but it has never been implemented because it has the courage to take on a real tussle with the United States. In 2014, we should have prevented the U.S. justice system from imposing a record $9 billion fine on BNP, already because of the U.S. embargo on Iran. The United States is defending its interests, it is time for European nations to defend their own.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, recently in Yemen the Houthis announced that their missiles could now reach Abu Dhabi and that Emiratis could expect similar attacks to those carried out against Saudi targets. Let me be clear: all these missiles are Iranian. The Houthis are unable to fight the legitimate authorities in Yemen without the active involvement of Iran.  Madam High Representative, if you consider the destabilisation in Lebanon, the tragedy in Syria and the resurgence of Hezbollah, there is one common denominator: Iranian regional aspirations. Why no mention of the human rights abuses against the Iranian people and the murder of Iranians speaking out against this despotic regime? Why are you not speaking about these criminal acts? Why not hold the Revolutionary Guard to account, or are drug smuggling and money laundering no longer a concern of anyone here? Are you seriously suggesting that we can trust this regime, and indeed saying that we should reward them? Perhaps you are so guided by your anti—American rhetoric that you will stubbornly take everyone down this disastrous path, although, as always, it will be others who will ultimately pay the price of your folly.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Mr President, the High Representative reminded us of the need to insist on the maintenance of the nuclear agreement with Iran for security reasons, provided that Iran fulfils its obligations. According to the International Atomic Energy Agency, two-thirds of centrifuges have been destroyed, 95% of enriched uranium is out of the country and the Arak nuclear reactor is inoperative. However, Madam High Representative, there is one question that floats in the environment: will European companies with interests in the United States risk us sanctions in this country? You just said this: Will the Commission be able to obtain exemptions? The truth is that after the tariffs on steel and aluminum and the G7 meeting, it is doubtful. If we look back to Singapore right now, we see that the North Korean autocrat, based on its sixty nuclear bombs and more than 1,000 missiles, has achieved its minute's glory. There is no alternative to what the high representative proposes. It is very important to maintain this nuclear agreement, but human rights that are continually degrading in the country are also very important.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Mr President, I find all my colleagues very cautious, the truth. Some things we already know: that Trump has come to blow up the international relations system, carefully built after the Cold War, we know, has already happened; that President Trump has decided to have a bad relationship with his G-7 allies, with his northern neighbor, Canada, with his southern neighbor, Mexico, and with the European Union we also know, that has already happened; that their permanent provocations and gangs have made the world a more insecure place, we also know that. Now it remains to be seen how we react to something that is already a certainty: that this behavior is behavior that makes the world more dangerous today than it was before Trump was the president of the United States. The way to react to this, certainly none, is to defend our interests together. What is left to this Parliament, therefore, this afternoon, as we are doing, is to strengthen the position of the European Union and to firmly sustain the high representative's action in the defence of a nuclear pact which is probably one of the most important tools for our security and stability. We must already know that in the White House we do not have a friend, and perhaps so we can strengthen our own friendship within European borders, make ourselves stronger, to the extent that what we have in front of us, unfortunately, is a new phenomenon. And he's a White House tenant who hasn't come to help us, but quite the opposite. And I think the high representative's work in recent months in defending the nuclear deal is an excellent job. I believe that we are all convinced that our stability and security depend to a large extent on the continued agreement, and that is why today I would like to strongly support the high representative's task.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Mr President, honourable Members, Honourable Mrs Mogherini, Let me first congratulate you on your timely and useful position for the European Union, which you expressed in the early hours of this crisis. The position was correct and it must also be followed by our colleagues.  Dear colleagues, the agreement with the Islamic Republic of Iran is good for the European Union and its members. This agreement works, this agreement can and will create jobs in each member state. It can, is and will be an additional guarantor of the security of citizens in these countries.  We cannot and must not allow third countries to jeopardise the interests of the Member States of the European Union. We cannot and should not be hostages to unemerized and voluntaristic politics. When we talk about human rights, we must clearly understand and know how far the possibilities go not to interfere in the internal affairs of sovereign states. This is an agreement is good, we have to respect it and develop it.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, it is very bad that we have come to a situation where allies such as the European Union and the US have such diverging opinions on Iran and how to move forward. The Iran nuclear agreement is not perfect, but to change it, the allies – meaning the US and the European Union – should work together, not act unilaterally. The unilateral actions of the US undermine this much-needed alliance and also the international legal environment. It is also clear that some expectations that came with the Iran nuclear agreement have not been fulfilled, such as the way Iran is spending the money that it has received due to the lifting of sanctions. Instead of using this money to build up its country and help people, it is using the money to enhance its military structures and support conflicts in its neighbouring countries like Yemen, Syria and Iraq. Also, the continued threats against Israel are unacceptable and must be addressed also by the EU. Of course, the EU should think of Plan B, should Iran go ahead and resume the enrichment of uranium, as the Iranian President has threatened.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: – Mr President, the Iran deal is dying before our eyes and only Europe is still clinging on to this flawed plan. Lauded as a means of ensuring peace and security for generations, its only effects have been to potentially catalyse yet more death and destruction in the already unstable Middle East, and to drive a wedge in western diplomacy, as Trump actually follows through with his campaign pledges and ends US participation.  The USA will be re-imposing sanctions on Iran. It was also reported last week that the Iranian regime is looking at options to boost uranium enrichment in case the deal fails. So let’s be clear: Iran is preparing for the failure of the nuclear deal. But what is the EU’s reaction to all this? The Commission is trying to force through a delegated act to make Iran eligible for European Investment Bank funding. Not content with clinging to a dying deal, you actually want to give economic and political support to the Iranian regime. It makes sense though doesn’t it? Trump pulls out of the nuclear deal and you see an opportunity to make the EU look like big players on the world stage.  This is more about EU vanity than it is about solving complicated political issues. It is almost as if the EU is trying to fight a proxy war against America in the Middle East. Our ability to influence Iran is greatly weakened without US participation. If the EU and Europe’s major powers continue down this line, its only real impact will be to tilt backwards towards the anti-Americanism that seeps through the seams of these institutions.  So how will this affect potential economic projects financed by the EIB? How will this influence the deteriorating trade and diplomatic relations between the EU and USA? According to Reuters internal sources, the EIB is unhappy with the Commission proposal because the EIB raises funds on US markets. To make matters worse, a delegated act is a power the unelected Commission has to adopt legislation without any anyone who was elected having a vote. So this proposal is far from being democratic and accountable. Whilst we will of course continue to work closely with European allies when our interests converge, this is not one of those times. May’s government is too scared to fully embrace the opportunities and independence that Brexit provides, and is continuing to follow EU policies and legislation, no matter the cost to the UK. Don’t get me wrong. I don’t want an independent Britain to be the 51st state of America. But the British people certainly voted to stop being the EU’s 28th State. This is going to be one of the first big tests for the UK to refind its place in the world as an independent nation. The whole point of Brexit was to make our own democratic rules and pursue our own interests, but like the rest of the negotiations, Ms May will surrender to the EU, following EU rules and policies as closely as possible, completely against the express will of the British people.  The UK Government, packed with remainers, could not see the benefits of Brexit before the vote and is too scared to seize them now. This is not academia or a domestic political squabble, but will have real and long-lasting effects on our standing in the world, driving a wedge between the UK and our most important strategic partner, the USA. We should not follow Mogherini’s vanity project at the expense of our most important global relationship. It is time for us to follow our American allies and call it as we see it. The Iran deal is dead, and we must seek out a new style of diplomacy, one that actually gets results, as we are seeing on the current Korean Peninsula ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleagues, once again, I have been as tolerant as I could be as Chair, but next time I really will be cutting off the microphone within seconds of when you should finish. I think it is unfair to your colleagues.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Listening to this debate, I note with concern that many speakers are very skillful in defending the thesis, which is unfortunately untrue. Well, the ancients already knew that if you want peace, you have to be prepared for war. Countries with strategic retaliatory capabilities are not under attack. It is not weakness that is a mainstay and a guarantee of peace and security. The mainstay of peace and security is strength. Strong no one attacks. Please note that the countries of North Africa did not have the possibility of strategic retaliation and were destroyed. So if we want world peace, we should want countries to be able to defend themselves and not be attacked. And in general, who can decide which country will be able to retaliate, and which should not? I don't think we have that right.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has When I was in Iran three weeks ago and also had talks with leading members of the Guardian Council there, I saw the following: on the one hand, there is a great deal of confidence in the countries of Europe that they are at least keeping their word, on the other hand there is a strong mistrust that Europe is finally dancing to the whistle of the United States again. I think that the hope that, on the one hand, the EU, Europe, will clear its own path and set itself aside from the United States and finally play off the economic power of five hundred million Europeans, this hope is great and must not be disappointed under any circumstances. Donald Trump, the US is out. Renegotiation was also discussed – why not? Why not create a nuclear-weapon-free zone throughout the Middle East, including Israel, so that peace there is finally guaranteed?

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European Parliament. It is a question of saving the Non-Proliferation Treaty. That is why it is important, and that is why I wish you every success, Mrs Mogherini, that the treaty that you negotiated and supported, enforced by the three EU Member States – which are democratic – is now being defended with the other partners against the extraterritorial claims of the United States of America. At the same time, we should ensure that there are, of course, criticisms of Iran: because of its internal structure, human rights violations, the missile programme, participation in the wars in the Middle East and israel policy. But we must make it clear that if President Trump destroys the Iran deal, he will have no credibility with North Korea. I also wish him every success in his negotiations. If he were to get the verifications with North Korea that you negotiated, Mrs Mogherini, in the case of Iran, then he would have a good result. What has come out today is a fine statement without any assurance that North Korea is sticking to it.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Iran nuclear deal was rightly hailed as a triumph of diplomacy. An almost insoluble problem could be solved through talks and confidence-building measures, and the efforts of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Federica Mogherini, were crucial to this success. It was not only proof that European foreign policy can work, but also a strong signal of multilateralism. The agreement also opened the door to possible developments in the region, for peace, for greater prosperity, democracy and the rule of law, and more stability overall – all depending on Iran's adhered to the agreements. The International Atomic Energy Agency has repeatedly stated that the agreements have been complied with. The American President's decision to wilfully disregard all this is irresponsible and represents a radical breach of the principle of trust. On what basis should conflicts be resolved in the future if we can no longer be confident that agreements will be respected? It is therefore to be welcomed that we stand by our agreements. However, goodwill must not be left alone, it needs robust safeguards – also in the interests of European companies, which have taken decisions in the confidence of the validity of international agreements. This is where the European Investment Bank is in demand. All previous projects in the common interest must continue, such as the slow-moving human rights dialogue, which is very important and will be crucial, or the joint efforts in the fight against drug trafficking or regional security cooperation. And it would be very helpful to finally be able to start the opening of an EU delegation in Tehran. Only intensive diplomatic activities can solve the current crisis, as it has done before.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, with the 2015 agreement the European Union committed itself to effective control of Iran's nuclear programme while lifting sanctions against that country. There is no doubt that we are in favour of the agreement, even after the Withdrawal of the United States pursuing an erratic policy, provided, of course, that Iran also fulfils its obligations. The lifting of sanctions will have a positive impact on the survival of the poor people of Iran, help the development of democracy and overthrow the regime, but at the same time help the Union's economic relations with that country. Let me remind you that many of Iran's planes have fallen from time to time, dragging hundreds of people to their deaths, because, according to Tehran, we did not sell parts for their maintenance. I would point out that the application of sanctions is effective when it is not selective, either with regard to the same crime, such as the acquisition and proliferation of nuclear weapons, or with regard to similar crimes, such as the occupation of foreign territories. We are applying sanctions against Russia, but we are stroking Turkey.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: – Mr President, this debate is based on a number of fake news items on the so-called Iran deal. There never was a deal. I cite the Obama Administration: ‘The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action is not a treaty or an executive agreement, and it is not a signed document’. I cite Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif: ‘No agreement has been reached, so we do not have any obligation yet,’ and Iranian leader Ali Khamenei: ‘Nothing has happened yet’.  In the US it was a decision taken only by one person, the former President of the United States, against the articulated democratic majority of the US Congress by all of its Republican – and some of its Democrat – members. It was an agreement without any binding obligations, as the leaders of Iran very openly and precisely made clear on the very day this so-called deal was published. It was an agreement that solely stated the personal and political trust of the former President of the United States in the Iranian leadership. It signalled the trust of this utterly overrated President in a government that repeatedly announces its will to extinguish Israel; a government that supports a number of Islamic terrorist organisations all over the Middle East; a government that has shown its disrespect for most of our values for almost four decades. This deal was established undemocratically; it was non—binding and was a clear proof of the inappropriate visions – not to say lack of visions – of Obama’s foreign policy, which the vast majority of this Parliament still follows against any intelligent understanding of the situation. Let’s go for a new deal. Let’s go for a real deal. Let’s go for a deal that respects the vital and legitimate interests of Iran’s neighbours, and especially Israel.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, the unbearable claim of the United States to impose the universality of its sanctions on the whole world, after its unilateral denunciation of the agreement with Iran, is totally unacceptable. We pay for the total lack of reaction when we previously allowed the French bank BNP Paribas to be racketed by the United States to the tune of 7 billion euros - 9 billion dollars - because its Swiss subsidiary had continued to work with Iran. I am the only Member who has then questioned the Commission and the Council. Your answers were indigent, like that of French President Hollande, who was visiting this Chamber at the time. Even today, you are opposing the words - point of contact, further discussions, blocking law - but already European companies - Total, Peugeot, Airbus - have given up their plans in this country. The only effective measures would be to prepare us to place in receivership American assets equivalent to European assets that would be stolen by the American authorities. We have been allies of the United States of America, we are not their vassals.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Mr President, it is not out of complacency or naivety that the signatories of the JCPOA (Common Comprehensive Action Plan) have favoured the diplomatic route on the Iranian nuclear programme, but it is because for 15 years there has been a clear observation that there is no realistic alternative to deal with this threat, because it is indeed a serious threat. Europeans must be a pole of stability and reliability on the international stage. The word of a multilateral agreement obliges its signatories, beyond domestic political quarrels. To get rid of it abruptly offers no satisfactory solution to anyone. This agreement does not, of course, address the problems posed by Tehran's policy in the region or the legitimate concern about the development of Iran's ballistic capabilities. But on the one hand, we knew this data very well when we negotiated the agreement, and on the other hand, it is inconsistent to think that these disputes can be resolved by starting by questioning the nuclear agreement, which is a foundation, even fragile, to any more general negotiation. Military adventurism in a deeply unstable Middle East has already caused enough damage.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Senhor Presidente, tem o meu apoio nos seus esforços para preservar o acordo nuclear com o Irão que é a pedra angular do regime global da não proliferação nuclear e, assim, absolutamente estratégico para a União Europeia, para a segurança da região e para todo o mundo. Besides, the JCPOA can, with the lifting of sanctions, foster economic, social and people-to-people exchanges, thus enhancing political dialogue with Iran and bringing to that dialogue questions like regional issues and human rights – including in Iran. We need this channel of dialogue; it can actually encourage Iran to play a responsible role in the region, in contrast with the Wahhabism fuelling terrorism from neighbouring Saudi Arabia and proxies.  To counter those who want to destroy the JCPOA, I support the Commission’s proposal to reactivate the blocking regulation, making it possible to protect legitimate EU trade with Iran, and to empower the European Investment Bank to finance trade with Iran. We must refute Trump’s hypocrisy in opposing the verified JCPOA when he is trying to sell his unverified deal with the North Korean dictator, and all those who try to pretend – like Israel and the Saudis backing Trump – that Iran is the only source of trouble in the Middle East.  No doubt, I condemn many of the Iranian policies – namely violating human rights in Iran, and namely supporting the regime of Assad in Syria – but Iran is not the only troublemaker in the region. We should equally condemn all those who are fostering trouble and fuelling conflicts, like the UAE, which is now preparing an assault on the port of al Hudaydah in Yemen, which the UN has warned could lead to catastrophic humanitarian consequences. The divergence with the Trump administration over the JCPOA is actually part of a deeper problem in transatlantic relations: trade wars, withdrawal from the climate agreement, from the migration global compacts, brazen interference against our Union in European countries, supporting populist far-right policies. This is a bigger problem, and we need... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: – Mr President, three years ago I spoke here against the disastrous Iran nuclear agreement, the JCPOA. I have to ask Ms Mogherini: what are you celebrating by signing this deal? Is it the freeing up of USD 100 billion in frozen assets so Iran can sponsor terrorism, funding Hezbollah in Lebanon and Syria, Hamas in Gaza, Houthi rebel missiles in Yemen, annexing Iraq and destabilising Bahrain? Iran is a septic octopus with its poisonous tentacles wrapped all around the Middle East. Or are you proud that Iran lied to you about its nuclear ambitions (as secret papers released by the Israelis prove) or has engaged in five ballistic missile tests since the deal was signed? Or was it that, even if it fully complies, that regime can still have uranium enrichment? Or is it the fat contracts for Total, Airbus, Peugeot and Citroen? I fully agree with President Trump’s bold decision to withdraw the US from the deal and return to sanctions. Trump is right. The EU is wrong.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which High Representative, I fully support the line you are taking politically here. I am very surprised at colleagues who do not justify the rejection of this agreement with Iran on the grounds that Iran is violating this agreement, but that they are justifying it with other political activities worthy of criticism by Iran. In fact, that is all to be criticised, and everything that we do not like about Iran has been listed. But this has nothing to do with the subject of the negotiations. When we were negotiating these things – I remember I was there at the time – the priority of the priorities was to prevent the Iranian bomb. And it was right to conclude this agreement. And I wonder: is Israel's security better guaranteed, for example, when Iran no longer feels bound by the agreement? I don't think so. Otherwise, my question in the area of the economy is this: can we not switch our trade with Iran as a whole to the euro, so that we are no longer so dependent on American banks?

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this debate of ours is part of a profound change in international relations, as witnessed by the last G7. The current US administration seems to have taken a disarming line in its simplicity in external relations, which is also well interpreted in the Iranian case by Mike Pompeo.  If you want to be considered a friend of the Americans, then you must accept the conditions that are placed on you, twelve in the Iranian case, or pay the consequences of rejection. There is all the gamble in this, which may perhaps pay in the Case of North Korea, but I doubt it works with Iran, with the risk of a dangerous escalation. I do not think we should use the American attitude as an excuse. Let us be clear: at the moment, there is nothing that can reasonably be done to convince Trump, Netanyahu and Bin Salman to push them towards a position of dialogue and rational analysis of the situation. If Europe, like Iran, wants to have a chance to get out of this difficult situation, it is essential that this opportunity is seen above all in its ability to wear down their intentions through common sense and patience. Pompeo's conditions, among other things, are more of a tool in the hands of the Israeli administration than in the UNITED States, opening the door to legitimising a conflict that has already begun a few weeks ago on Syrian soil. A well-designed plan that Europe and Iran can only undermine through diplomatic patience, with a view to closing that window of opportunity that Netanyahu today seems to want to manage himself.  That is why, Madam High Representative, in signing your line, I would ask you first of all to work to prevent, here and in the region, creating a casus belli that can have difficult consequences to manage.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Thank you, Mr President. I look forward to a rational and moral European policy versus the Islamic Republic of Iran in geopolitical, economic and moral terms. Geopolitics, Mr. President. Let the European Union, together with the United States, act against Iran's expansionist course and Iran's destabilising course in the Middle East. Secondly, economically. Do not let the EU jeer its close financial, economic and trade relations with the US for incomparably weak relations with Iran. Moreover, we are not going to support the Iranian Revolutionary Guard with its terrorist actions, internally and externally. Immoral! The EU should not be nuclear-blackmailed. This has been the case from the beginning, from the beginning of the nuclear deal with Zarif's negotiations. And moreover, morally speaking, a policy of appeasement against a regime that terrorizes its own people and the region and seeks to destroy Israel; let the EU abandon this policy, because it is immoral.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, there is no doubt that the JCPOA has been an important achievement that could guarantee security in the region and bring Iran back onto the international scene. It is very unfortunate, therefore, to see the US backpedalling on this deal. The consequences for international relations and for security in the region could be dire.  The EU finds itself in a difficult situation. I agree that we should keep Iran tied to this deal. It will be tough, but in the given circumstances we have no other choice. We will have to work, moreover, out of the uncertainties around the investments that the EU made in Iran. This concerns in particular the sanctions the USA could bring to businesses interested in investing in Iran. We also have our own EIB investments in Iran. It would be very unfortunate if they were subject to US sanctions. The situation will need a diplomatic solution.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it cannot be denied that Trump's decision to withdraw from the Iran nuclear agreement, in addition to damaging the credibility of the United States, endangers the stability of the entire region and is a step backwards in the path of non-proliferation of nuclear weapons.  We Europeans must safeguard the results of our diplomacy by preventing the efforts of more than twelve years of negotiation from being frustrated. We must ensure that the agreement is fully implemented, ensuring that the lifting of sanctions improves economic relations with Iran and that this also has a positive impact on the living conditions of the Iranian people. I fully appreciated and agree with the speech by the High Representative Federica Mogherini. We in the European Parliament must fully support its efforts and the work it has done so far and we must persuade, by all means available to the European Union, Iran to keep its commitments, despite the US withdrawal. This will also favor... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, I will make three points. One element is missing here. There was not one serious word addressed to the Iranian people. You mentioned just the human rights dialogue, which has failed to produce any tangible results. I think that an issue which is no less important than the nuclear deal is the continued repression of the Iranian people by the extremist fundamentalist regime. Second, I am worried that the EU approach has been tilted towards protecting EU companies’ access to the Iranian markets rather than protecting with equal commitment human rights and civil liberties there. And third, Ms Mogherini mentioned that the deal has avoided regional escalation. I think the opposite is true. The Iranian military expansion in the Middle East has recently reached the Israeli borders. There is a direct threat to the very existence of Israel, as Tehran has repeatedly called for the annihilation of the Jewish state. Has there been any serious reaction to that from the EU?

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr High Representative Mogherini! Less than two weeks ago, we stood here debating human rights in Iran. Although the debate today is about the nuclear agreement, I would like to start by stressing the importance of the EU standing up for human rights and against the death penalty. I would like to repeat one of the latest demands: release Ahmadreza Djalali, Iran! Do it now!  On today's subject, I would like to say that the unilateral decision by the US to withdraw from the agreement is both worrying and irresponsible. Several have said this: it increases tensions in the region and it may benefit the least reformist forces. The nuclear agreement is not perfect, but it is the result of 12 years of diplomatic efforts. The agreement has meant that we have had a control mechanism in place. It has been important for our security and for global non-proliferation efforts. Now the EU must get behind Mogherini and get a holistic picture of the situation. In parallel with the work on nuclear weapons, we must continue to press in the alarming areas.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Mr President, as Europeans we believe in political dialogue and disarmament. At the same time, the JCPOA is a deal with serious flaws, the first one being that the negotiations leading up to the deal were a missed opportunity to improve the human rights situation in the Islamic Republic. Secondly, the deal allowed Iran to keep its nuclear infrastructure intact. It was designed to put off problems, not to deal with them once and for all. Thirdly, the revenue from lifted sanctions went into the pockets of the revolutionary guard, rather than to the country’s suffering people. The EU should now look at these failings and condition our future commitment to the JCPOA on human rights improvements, a complete stop to the sponsoring of terrorists, and the full dismantling of the Iranian nuclear infrastructure.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, while US President Trump claims to champion denuclearisation in one part of the world – signing a deal with North Korea built on shaky grounds of Twitter diplomacy and laced with vague, noncommittal wording – he abandons the strong, solid nuclear deal with Iran: the product of years of negotiations by the international community, and the effectiveness of which is attested by at least 10 International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) reports.  High Representative, in your address to us earlier, you stressed the importance of the joint comprehensive plan of action (JCPOA). The majority of this House agrees, but now it is vital that we ensure that the re—imposition of US sanctions does not spell an end to the deal. So my questions to you are: the EIB, as we’ve heard before, has been asked to extend its activities to Iran to help shield businesses from the US sanctions, but it is hesitant because it is worried about US retaliation. But as far as I’m concerned, their core mandate is to carry out our policies, and there’s nothing more important than carrying out this particular deal.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Mr. Chairman, it is true, Mrs. Morgherini, as you said, that the Iran nuclear deal is a pillar of security in this area of the Middle East. I agree with you. I also agree that this pillar of security has been shaken by the united States' exit from that agreement. The only way to stop the creation of an Iranian nuclear bomb was this very agreement, and therefore it is positive in that part. However, the fact is that there is a major human rights violation in Iran, which we rarely mention here.  I recently had the opportunity to be with the AFET delegation in Iran and I was personally able to convince myself, from the talks, how this regime is maintained there and how the basic human rights of the citizens of Iran are violated. I think that's what we need to talk about. Likewise, let's not forget Iran's aggressive policy towards Israel. In any case, I think that democracy needs to be strengthened there and that work needs to be done to change the regime. It will be the only way to calm the situation in the Middle East.  (The Representative agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure))

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I just wanted to ask you: when you talk about human rights violations in Iran, why are you silent about human rights violations in the United States and Israel?

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Antwort auf eine Frage nach dem Verfahren der "blauen Karte". – Das ist eine interest to Frage. Your question is interesting, however, today's topic is precisely Iran and the nuclear deal. We did not talk today about the human rights situation in the United States of America, which is a democratic state, and the topic today is not Israel, but the fact is that Iran has an aggressive policy in relation to Israel, and we can document that.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, from here today, from the European Parliament, we want to strongly condemn the Trump Administration's unilateral decision to violate the iran nuclear deal.  An agreement that also had verification mechanisms, and we knew that the commitments that resulted from it were being fulfilled. An agreement that for us is much more than an agreement. It is a fundamental piece to avoid nuclear escalation in a region today with very strong tensions. That is why we want to strongly support the efforts of the High Representative and the Council to safeguard this agreement and send two messages. We're not talking about Iran today. We talk about diplomacy and multilateralism as mechanisms for ordering international relations—the word in front of force; that's what Europe is defending today. And we're talking about the transatlantic relations, which are breaking down.  Today's lack of confidence in the new US administration must have a strong response in defense of our interests and values from Europe.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. Chairman, Madam Commissioner, Iran is facing an economic crisis, unemployment, poverty, the enciling of fundamental human freedoms, and in particular women's rights. Nor should we forget the fact that Iran in the past year after China was the first country with the highest number of executions, which is contrary to our values in the European Union, because we do not condone the death penalty as a legal sanction.  In Iran, there are internal priorities that need to be worked on, to ensure a dignified life, freedom and fundamental rights for citizens. These are problems that the nuclear deal cannot and will not solve. The rights of the Iranian people, every child and every woman, every political prisoner, must be put first. I believe that these rights had to be a precondition for signing the contract.  The Iran nuclear deal is important and its intention was good, but it must not put aside human rights violations and disregard for its own people, and the European Union must respond appropriately to this.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, first of all let me congratulate you on your excellent work on this dossier which is as difficult as we all know. Ms Mogherini, it is a fact that the joint global action plan was a historic instrument on multilateral diplomacy which should, despite its imperfections, be a cornerstone for a wider future solution after 2025 covering iran's Ariane ballistic missile programme and covering a wider range of regional actors. President Trump's inability to understand this innovative strategy ratified by the Security Council poses a threat to the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons and the security of the Middle East and Europe.  Madam High Representative, I agree with you that, at this particularly critical time, the Union must continue to focus on maintaining the agreement with Iran by strengthening its monitoring and verification without, however, Madam High Representative, forgetting that, at the same time the ayatollahregime calls for the non-application of the extraterritorial effects of US secondary sanctions, the repressive nature of a regime which continues to be repressive in the system which , despite promises of reform, continues to deter a sad record of human rights violations and is the leader of the world's per capita executions. Mrs Mogherini, I ask you not to forget these Iranians who suffer brutally every day at the hands of such a brutal regime.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, as the eyes of the world focus on the Iranian nuclear deal and Trump’s unilateral decision, I ask colleagues to keep in mind the people of Iran. Human rights in Iran continue to deteriorate, with peaceful protests facing intimidation, violence, detention and torture. While we work to preserve the nuclear deal, we must never lose sight of the principles and values upon which this Parliament was built. We must never stop standing up for those without a voice and holding those with power to account. We must never stop in our efforts to promote democracy, free speech, the rule of law and the right to peaceful protest.  This House must stand in solidarity with the people of Iran, who desire these most basic of freedoms, and this House must stand in solidarity with those in Iran currently in prison, enduring torture, or those who face the death penalty for the simple belief that tomorrow may be better than today.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Madam President, there is a major loophole in the current nuclear deal, and that is the lack of any limits on Iranian military expansionism. Iran is directing a massive army of Shia militias in both Iraq and Syria, and in both countries has a direct military presence in the shape of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps. In Syria especially this Iranian presence is very clear. It is obvious that any economic support from the EU to Iran will go directly to the companies owned by Ayatollah Khamenei and his family and to the companies owned by the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps. This is the very force that helped Assad drive refugees to Europe. My question is why the EU policy towards Assad has changed so fundamentally that we plan to support the forces he is depending on. Why should the EU support the forces that are harassing the Christians in Iraq? The EU needs to consider these consequences before there is any continuation.

name: Patricia LALONDE
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, the Iran nuclear agreement must be preserved as it stands despite the withdrawal of the United States. The idea of wanting to add three clauses, as some leaders of the European Member States have suggested, is unworkable. The Iranians will never accept it, so we are taking the risk that Iran will not resume uranium enrichment. Iran is not North Korea. The Iranian people will stand in solidarity with their leaders and any desire on the part of the West to orchestrate a change of regime risks plunging the region into total chaos of which Europe is likely to be the first victim. Iranians demand the right to self-defense, the Iran-Iraq war has claimed more than half a million lives and remains present among Iranians, as these posters of martyrs remind us on the street facades of Tehran, as in all cities in Iran. Europe must use diplomacy to get the Iranians to withdraw from the syrian south. We need to end up with real negotiations on Yemen with the Houthis rather than pushing Iran into vain threats. Colleagues, we must do everything we can to lift sanctions against Iran and try to circumvent US sanctions so that European companies can stay in Iran. The future of Europe is at stake, I know, Mrs Mogherini, how convinced you are.
