name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, we are debating and fairly denouncing Mr Trump's attitude towards the Iran denuclearization agreement. But don't you think we have to broaden the issue a little? Aren't we going to find a word to say on this issue in favor of denuclearization of the planet? Recently, a representative of a Nobel Prize-winning organisation was here and he argued quite rightly, and he was applauded by everyone that, once the nukes were invented, they would at some point be used, either by mistake or deliberately. This great issue, this great disaster over the heads of humanity, cannot be left out of the debate when we talk about the denuclearization of a particular state or region. Allow me, Mrs Mogherini, to recall – and I am referring to a personal matter, but I am obliged to do so – our militant past in favour of the denuclearization of the planet.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, Iran: another field of fierce competition for capital gains. The agreement does not fit the interests of all suitors to control the wealth of this country. That is why the United States is torpedoing the agreement, while the European Union, Germany, France and Russia, which have won many large contracts for their monopolies, are trying to protect it while putting conditions against Iran. The danger is great, also calculating the intensity of Israel's aggression, which murders the Palestinian people, bombs Syria and launches threats against the Iranian people with the cover of the European Union, the US and NATO. Of these competitions and wolf agreements the peoples will only know losses and bloodshed. That is why they must fight against the imperialist war, the alliances and the agreements of capital that redeem the wealth that the peoples themselves produce and they must reap it.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Madam President, argument number one seems to be that we, as the European Union, must cherish stability in the Gulf region by sticking unconditionally to the JCPOA. However, you only need to look into the present situation to understand that, with the Mullah regime, we are far from stability. The reaction from Ayatollah Khamenei to the withdrawal of the United States from the agreement speaks volumes. The Tehran dictatorship is actually using the opportunity to milk the Union and keep oppressing its own people. The main issues for the Iranian people are freedom, human rights, women’s rights, poverty – and not the nuclear deal. But the main thing for the Union seems to be the deal and all the other deals that come with it.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, whilst I am hugely concerned about Trump’s irresponsible and dangerous foreign policy, tearing up a landmark, EU-brokered deal designed to presage a more peaceful world, I want to remind those in positions of power and influence that many people remain unfairly imprisoned in Iran, a country with an appalling human rights record. Nazanin Zaghari—Ratcliffe is a British—Iranian dual citizen, who is currently detained in Evin prison on trumped up charges, her situation sadly made worse by Boris Johnson’s ignorant and careless words. Having met Nazanin’s husband, Richard, I can testify to the terrible pain being experienced by her family. So I urgently call on the High Representative to use all the means in her power to urge the Iranian authorities to release Nazanin and others like her. I’d also like to express my solidarity with the Iranian people, who occupied the streets to protest against corruption and rising prices. Despite calling itself moderate, the current government continues to violate human rights and disregard the Iranian people’s wish for a more open country.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, we condemn the decision of the US administration to denounce the nuclear agreement and to impose new sanctions on Iran, disregarding the Charter of the United Nations and international law.  A provocation embedded in its policy of confrontation, setting a risk of escalation of aggression by the United States and its allies in the Middle East, notably against Iran or Lebanon, is a hot line in the wars of aggression against Afghanistan, Iraq, Libya, Syria and Yemen.  We underline the warmongering role and systematic disregard for international law of Israel and Saudi Arabia, your allies, countries both responsible for wars of aggression against peoples of the Middle East. The reactions of the European Union and its major powers do not erase their responsibility and collusion with the interference and aggression operations of the United States, or NATO, in the region, as recently as Syria, or in those wars of aggression based on lies of war propaganda.  The defence of peace in the Middle East involves the end of the wars of aggression and the defence of the principles of the United Nations Charters.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, first of all, let me thank you all for having expressed quite clearly a sort of convergence and a certain unity behind the work we are doing to try to preserve the nuclear deal with Iran. It is the same unity that I have seen in the Commission, the same unity that I have seen in the European Council, in the Foreign Affairs Council, and the same unity that I have seen uniting the European Union within our Union, but also with our international partners all around the world. Let me stress this point because we have a responsibility as Europeans at this time. The world is looking at us to try and preserve this achievement – no achievement is perfect, but it’s an achievement – and it’s also looking at us to find ways themselves – our international partners – to contribute to preserving these agreements.  I have heard a certain confusion on the extreme right of the Chamber. You know I never enter into these discussions, but I think I have to clarify a couple of things. One is the nature of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) because fake news can produce fake news and can itself become fake news. Let me be very clear on this: the nuclear deal with Iran is not a treaty. It has never been a treaty. It is a multilateral agreement that was negotiated for 12 years under the mandate of the UN Security Council, which mandated the High Representative of the European Union to facilitate the negotiations between Iran, on one side, and Germany, France, the UK, the US, China and Russia, on the other side, to reach an agreement that then became a UN Security Council resolution annex. So the legal framework that legitimates the JCPOA is not in the nature of being a bilateral or multilateral treaty. This is why it has not been ratified by Parliament, but it is an annex to the UN Security Council resolution. There is a UN Security Council resolution that unanimously endorsed and approved the text of the JCPOA and if you want to see it – sorry, the colleague has disappeared, as fake news disappears from time to time – the signed version of the JCPOA is in my office. You’re free to come and see it. It exists. It’s 102-3 pages long – it takes some time to read it and probably a lot of time to understand it – but it exists and it’s available on the website for everybody to consult it. Indeed it has a legal basis, being a UN Security Council resolution document. As such, technically speaking, the unilateral move of the United States Administration is the unilateral decision to stop complying with the UN Security Council resolution the United States itself voted. That is just to clarify what the JCPOA is. The second element of confusion I see especially – well, only – on the extreme right part of the Chamber is this – and I understand the political dilemma that some political forces might have at this stage, namely following the Trump agenda of destroying multilateralism and going only to bilateral agreements or affirming European autonomy. In French I would say ‘c’est où votre souverainisme?’, because for me protecting and preserving European interests – security interests, economic decisions – at this stage is a matter of priority. I’m surprised that some forces that have always argued for sovereignty and autonomy are now tempted to follow not Brussels but Washington. I think this is a mistake. This is a mistake that goes beyond the nuclear deal with Iran, but I leave this for political reflection in some parts of Europe. What is at stake today? First of all, what is a stake is the risk that Iran decides to restart its process to achieve a nuclear weapon. This is what we are talking about. The agreement is not perfect. I don’t know about you, but I don’t know anything in diplomacy – not even in life – that is perfect. No agreement, no deal is perfect, but this agreement is working. This agreement’s purpose was – and still is – to prevent Iran from developing a nuclear weapon and it is preventing Iran from developing a nuclear weapon. That’s it. The risk is that, were this agreement not in place tomorrow, what would be the immediate consequence? Nuclear proliferation? Iran developing a nuclear programme that is not peaceful? The region going into a spiral of nuclear proliferation? And we know the region. We know the conflictuality of the region and some of you were perfectly right: the risk of slipping into a major scale conflict is real. It’s perfectly possible. There are two other issues at stake: the credibility of multilateralism and of international agreements – I would say of UN Security Council resolutions. The arguments that whatever is signed can be destroyed unilaterally after a few years is a dangerous one. I often gave this example in Washington. If a private company signs an agreement, when the CEO changes the agreement stays in place. If we introduce the element of uncertainty of agreements signed, the entire world collapses and the credibility of any negotiation – of any negotiation – collapses, and the international system also goes in that direction. So what is at stake is – and our responsibility is big in this – to try to maintain the credibility of diplomacy and multilateralism and, at the end of the day, bilateral agreements as well, because if you can unilaterally withdraw from a multilateral agreement, why shouldn’t you do the same on a bilateral agreement if at a certain moment you change your mind? Third, what is at stake is the autonomy of the European Union. This goes beyond the nuclear agreement with Iran. This would lead us to a different kind of debate, one that we will surely have at some point, but it is essential that the European Union, together with our international partners, is able to take decisions based on merit, based on our interests and our values, and based on what we think and decide is good for us and for the rest of the region and the world, that, by the way, was a joint analysis and a joint decision not only with our American friends, but also with the rest of international community. Otherwise, the UN Security Council resolution would not have been unanimously adopted. We didn’t move from where we were, and our analysis of what is in our interest and the global interest stays the same, especially after 11 reports that the deal has worked and that Iran is compliant. I believe that we need to be able to affirm that the European Union positions are determined in Europe. Having said that, the risk of not managing to save this agreement is real and I think we should not underestimate that we are running a risk. Even if we do all we can – and we are doing all we can – to preserve this agreement, there is a risk that this derails. I think we have the power and the instruments, together with our Member States and together with the other international partners we have, to prevent this agreement from being completely disrupted. But there is a risk that this work does not succeed. I think this is the worst case scenario because this would undermine security – nothing to do with stability – and would undermine the nuclear non—proliferation regime and the credibility of the West and of multilateralism and diplomacy. This is why I believe that, even if it’s difficult – and I see all the limitations – we have the responsibility to try to achieve this result. Even if it’s difficult, we must we must do all we can together to preserve this agreement, and this is exactly what we are doing because, again, the scenario of not having the agreement in place would be a disaster for Europe, for the security of the Middle East, for the proliferation of nuclear weapons, and I believe also for the United States of America.  (Applause)

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is over.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report presented by Charles Tannock on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the modernisation of the EU-Chile Association Agreement (2018/2018(INI) (A8-0158/2018)

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, having been around long enough in this House as an MEP to remember the first association agreement agreed between the European Union and Chile, as long ago as 2002, it is rather fitting that in my final months as a Member I find myself proudly authoring the recommendation report ahead of the ongoing negotiations for its upgrade. As the European Union has emerged as one of the leading forces in the global free trade agenda, I welcome its attention to third-generation updated agreements such as we see today with Chile, rather than wholly pursuing new deals from scratch.  We are focused on the political operation aspects but let us not forget that these negotiations are also concerned with trade issues. Chile has re-emerged over the last three decades as a mature democracy with a strong internationalist outlook. As a member of the Pacific Alliance, the Organisation of American States and the Union of South American Nations, not to mention being a member of the OECD. Its links and areas of cooperation go well beyond its immediate region and are truly global. Although already cooperating in EU crisis management operations– this would include in fact things like the CSDP operations, Eurofor in Bosnia – since 2014, it is also hoped that the renewed association agreement will see further cooperation being developed in the coming years.  We proposed in our recommendation an ambitious level of commitment, one that is no less wide-ranging than the similar EU agreements recently concluded with Canada, New Zealand and Australia. This includes working together in the international arena to promote democracy and the rule of law to fight climate change, particularly critical in the Pacific region, combating terrorism and tackling organised crime and corruption.  In the area of education, the European Union seeks to continue cooperation via Erasmus+, but also to work towards full mutual recognition of academic and professional qualifications and diplomas. We have also highlighted the important role the parliamentary oversight and scrutiny has in monitoring such agreements, and so we have endorsed the continued role for the Joint Parliamentary Committee which met for its 25th occasion back in January of this year. As the negotiations progress we will hope to see continued engagement from the Commission as to the latest developments. Its decision to publish the negotiating mandate and directives in November of last year was an important precedent and one which we welcome and are very keen to see continued. Indeed, we have made reference to this in the recommendation. With the third round of negotiations concluded in Brussels on 1 June 2018, I am confident that the talks are progressing well. The bulk of discussions are now focusing on trade rather than the political aspects, which are in my recommendation. Chile is clearly a natural partner with common democratic interests and aspirations everywhere. This was further reflected by the positive dialogue concluded with members of European civil society groups that was arranged as part of the latest talks between the EU and Chilean negotiators.  I will conclude my remarks therefore now, although I look forward to making a brief intervention at the end of the debate when I will be happy to address any issues raised, and to make a few comments regarding the two key amendments I have tabled to the resolution for a vote.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, on behalf of the High Representative / Vice—President, I would like to thank the European Parliament, and in particular the rapporteur, Charles Tannock, for his recommendation. It shows how much we all value our relationship with Chile, and it proves that there is strong support within Parliament for the work done throughout the negotiations. Chile was the first country in Latin America to sign an association agreement with us. The new agreement we are now negotiating will once again be a model for other deals. This is not only about trade: it is about human rights; it is about the protection of the environment; it is about sustainable development and culture; it is about energy and workers’ rights.  Europe and Chile are very far apart geographically, but we see the world with the same eyes. Vemos el mundo con los mismos ojos. Pronunciation in Spanish! We both believe in the UN system and in the power of multilateralism. Chile has taken part in our CSDP mission in Bosnia, and it was the first Latin American country to sign a framework agreement for participation in our missions. We work together on scientific research, for instance under the Copernicus Programme, and when last year Chile was hit by a wave of wild fires, we sent our fire-fighting planes and our firefighters from many European countries to contain the emergency.  We both believe in solidarity as a driving force in international relations. Let me also thank Chile for having opened its doors to many Venezuelan refugees fleeing from their country. I saw the situation when I was in this region just two months ago. These negotiations show the potential for cooperation between like-minded partners like us. Our updated agreement will not only aim to strengthen our economies, it will also protect our workers, our trademark products, and our environment. It will demonstrate there is no better way to protect our interests than through strong cooperation with our partners.  This is international cooperation at its best. We want to show that globalisation can be governed together, with more rights, more protections, making international trade both free and fair. The negotiations are making good progress, and we have the ambition to conclude them as soon and possible, and certainly before the end of this Commission’s mandate. On the occasion of the next round of negotiations on the political and cooperation pillar on 21 June, we will also hold an EU-Chile Association Committee, with a focus not only on bilateral issues, but also on the regional and international situation. Once negotiations are concluded, we look forward to holding an EU-Chile Association Council, which the High Representative will co-chair with Foreign Minister Ampuero. Let me also stress that the work we are doing with Chile comes at a moment of strong engagement with the whole of Latin America and the Caribbean. Our negotiations with Mexico and Mercosur are also moving on, and by the end of the mandate we will present a new Strategy for even closer relations with Latin America and the Caribbean. I know we can count on Chile as a strong partner not only in our bilateral relations, but also in the larger context of relations between our two regions. Right now, we are working together to prepare the next EU-CELAC ministerial meeting, and we are also willing to expand our relations with the Pacific Alliance. We are currently working on a joint declaration with the four members of the Alliance, to identify precisely the fields where we could work together, in the interest of all our citizens. We live in a complex and confused moment in the history of the world, unfortunately, when nothing seems certain and even the most basic international rules are called into question. But our relationship with Latin America is here to stay, and will only get stronger. Our peoples and our economies are tied. We share the same principles and worldview. Europe and Latin America are closer than ever, and have the strongest interest in getting even closer. Together, we can be a force for good for the people of Europe, for the people of Latin America, and for our troubled and confused world.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam Chairman, Respected Commissioner, I thank you for the kind words and for the extremely inspiring speech you said about Chile as one of the most important links with Latin America and I must say that I am extremely proud to have had the opportunity to participate as a shadow reporter in the drafting of this report, and as a Croat, because of the role of the Croatian diaspora that built Chile, which after the war in Croatia helped build Croatia , and who has preserved peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina by participating in peacekeeping troops.  I would like to thank my colleague Tannock for a well-prepared report calling for further strengthening cooperation between the European Union and Chile, through a new modernised association agreement. Chile is a country that can only set an example for other countries through its successful democratic transition, and is one of the key partners of the European Union in terms of cooperation in the fields of economy, investment, protection of human rights and cultural diversity. This new comprehensive and modernised agreement aims to further strengthen multilateral cooperation in the fields of migration, security, defence (again I mention their troops in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which have been one of the bright examples), in the fight against terrorism, organised crime and climate change, as a promotion of regular dialogue regarding reducing socioeconomic differences, strengthening human and fundamental rights.  What I think is important and what I will mention again is the call to strengthen cultural cooperation and strengthen the role of the diaspora as a link between Latin America and Europe, and this was evident in these examples that I outlined at the beginning. So those who went to South America, who built one country, came back and successfully laid the groundwork for new developing countries as well. So I hope this report will serve as a good basis for completing the negotiations and will allow Chile to remain, as before, a European link on the continent.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group - Madam President, Commissioner, I would begin by greeting the rapporteur, Mr Tannock, for the quality of the work he presents to us here. Chile is now a very solid democracy, the most advanced country in various areas of Latin America and a key partner for the European Union. It is a country very open to the world in the most diverse dimensions. A country with a very strong presence in all regional alliances in which it is integrated and very open to the world at the political, diplomatic, economic, commercial level, a defender of multilateralism and, therefore, can and must be a very strong partner of a European Union that itself must open itself more and more to the world and must invest more and more in having an active participation in political regulation economic and commercial development of the world. This process which is now underway in negotiations with a view to modernising this association agreement between the European Union and Chile is fortunately going very well and, therefore, we are all convinced that it will have a happy ending. May it serve as an example for other ongoing negotiations, particularly the one that is currently taking place between the European Union and Mercosur with a view to concluding an association agreement between the two sides.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Charles. It's a great facility to be able to work with him. He is a person of simple treatment, open and who also knows the files well. It's easy and it's very useful to work with it. Chile is an example in Latin America. Chile is an example in democracy, in stability, in what its social inclusion, its economic openness and the reliability of its administrative and judicial institutions mean. It is, in that sense, an example for all other countries in America. It is also true — as the Commissioner, Mr Stylianides has said, that it is a country receiving tens of thousands of Venezuelans, in less intensity because of its geographical distance, but also in an open spirit of solidarity. Chile has made its geographical challenge—its American eccentricity—an extraordinarily successful solution. And, in that sense, there is one thing that is fundamental: the Alliance for the Pacific. We are being the subject of a continuous fracture, of a paradigm shift on the part of the American Administration. The last has been the contempt, via Twitter, of Mr Trump's Twitter thought, where he has olympeally despised his counterparts, both from the European Union and from other countries. Our projection has to be strategically with Ibero-America, and within Ibero-America, there is a fundamental part, which is the part that has the window to the Pacific. The Pacific Alliance is the most important and most effective partnership of all that exist in America. And, in that sense, it is important that Europe even has an observer presence there in the Alliance for the Pacific. I understand that our improvement project with Chile is a strategic project and we certainly support it.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the modernisation of an agreement is the right time to take stock of what has gone well and what has not and, in this case, try to remedy it. Let's not see modernization as just an opportunity to achieve more profit at all costs.  In the case of the 2003 European Union-Chile Association Agreement, while it has made progress in some areas, we see very clearly what the outstanding issues are. Issues that have perpetuated the classic north-south division and areas where the nefarious heritage of Pinochetism has not been left behind.  I want to mention some examples. The water code in force converts water into merchandise and establishes rights that can be sold. The consequence: water hoarding by large domestic and international investors for export agriculture. Small farmers, as well as entire communities, run out of this essential good and have to buy water from tankers. This happens, for example, in Petorca, near the capital, Santiago.  The report as it reaches the plenary reaffirms access to water as a human right. I ask you not to support the amendment which reduces content.  On the other hand, we must support those who receive threats in Chile for defending this right and ask the Union delegation in Santiago to publicly defend the Modatima organization and its President Mundaca.  Another fatal legacy of Pinochetism is discrimination against indigenous peoples: counter-terrorism justice applies only to Mapuche. It cannot be that their lands are stolen and native forests cut down to plant eucalyptus trees so that we have cheap paper; the modernization of the Agreement must contain very clear language in this regard. I ask you to vote against the amendment which trivializes the acute conflict that still exists. And finally, since the agreement came into force too little has happened in Chile to stop it from being basically a supplier of primary products, and this is not a side effect. This is the main effect of the agreement and we need to change this if we want more equitable Chile-European Union relations.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: "blue card" question. – In this Parliament we have been defending and defending and defending the right to regulate each party to any partnership agreement and to decide how each party organises and manages public services. And the question I ask you is: do you think it should be the European institutions, through an agreement with a third country, who tell you how to regulate and organize your services? Apart from me defending water as a public service, but that's not the point. I defend above all the right of the parties to decide and non-interference. And the way In which Chile has organized the provision of water is contained in its Constitution. Do you think this trade agreement should change Chile's Constitution?

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: "blue card" response. – Thank you, Madam President, for this question. What I believe is that water is an essential good that should be public, and I believe it for Europeans and also for non-Europeans.  Obviously, we will not decide for them, but we do have the right to defend our ideals, our principles everywhere. And just remember, as I have done in my speech, that the United Nations themselves says that the right to water is a basic and fundamental right, and I believe that it is the public management of an essential good that corresponds everywhere.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Madam President, Chile is undoubtedly one of the most advanced countries in Latin America, according to a number of indicators as well as the Human Development Index. Contacts at political and economic level between the EU and Chile are developing long-term and rapidly.  Chile contributes to the development of dialogue in the Colombian peace process. The long-term problem remains the relationship with the indigenous population, which in the recent past culminated in a conflict with the Mapuche tribe. The issue of negotiating Bolivia's access to the Pacific Ocean is similarly delicate. This one returns with varying intensity from the Chilean-Bolivian-Peruvian War of the 1880s. In its joint declarations, the EU-Chile Joint Parliamentary Committee expressed its support for the modernisation of the Association Agreement, most recently at its meeting on 22 January 2018. The pursuit of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms is essential. In Chile, a severely restrictive abortion law has been changed.  Mutual agreement on the need to combat climate change is also important. An important element is the promotion of the effort to ensure that people on the lowest incomes have unrestricted access to higher education in Chile, which is also desirable to promote in EU countries. The agreement supports the expansion of student and youth exchanges under various programmes, such as ERASMUS+.  Despite a number of positive elements, I have a reserved relationship to expand my involvement in economic and military cooperation between the two partners, and I will therefore abstain in the final vote.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, there is an urgent need to modernise this agreement, which dates back to 2003. During this time, a great deal has happened in Chile; a lot has generally happened in South America. But Chile already occupies a special position here. I think that we, as a Union, are far too inactive as far as South America is concerned. Chile has this special position, and we should not lose sight of that. In particular, the same applies to south America as a whole: wherever we go, the Chinese are often already there, and we must keep that in mind. My experience on the ground is that this development, especially in Chile, has once again been catalytic since the last election in 2017. I have already spoken to our Foreign Minister, for example, about the fact that we, as Austrians, will soon be going there to improve relations. Economically, there is a great deal going on in this country. This is not only because of the many natural resources, but this country is indeed a prosperous country. The people on the ground are very educated and I think it is only logical that we can be a special partner for Chile.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Tannock, on the excellent Recommendation he presents to the House today. Chile is a positive and active partner of the European Union. It is already bound by an Association Agreement, which has worked, in our view, excellently. I think we have to let every country that sets out how it exploits its natural resources. We have already had some experiences about public or private ownership of the means of production, and what we find in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe when lifting the carpet. I would like to say that Chile is a country actively participating in the region; is a prominent member of the Organization of American States; is a founding member of the Pacific Alliance; is a member of Unasur; it is the first Latin American country to have accessed the OECD and is also a member of the Lima Group. It is therefore a reliable partner for the European Union in addressing global and regional challenges. Of all the initiatives suggested by Mr Tannock to strengthen cooperation with this country, he has caught my attention particularly in the areas of security and defence and, in that regard, everything about crisis management and peacekeeping operations, on the basis of the already positive experience we have had with this country. Commissioner, I would like to send you a message to try to streamline these work a little: the next round with the Commission for market access is set in October; you have said that Chile has been the first country to conclude an association agreement with the European Union. We wouldn't want him to be the last to conclude it.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Madam President, I am in addition to the Commissioner's ideas that Latin America and Europe have much to do together. I totally agree. With Chile in particular, too. I would like to highlight two ideas that are key to this agreement.  Firstly, I think it is very important that Europe is able to consider the importance of Chile's platform to Asia. The European economic world and, of course, European companies have much to do in Asia through the Pacific Alliance, and the agreement with Chile is key in that direction.  Secondly, I am incorporating into the idea that agreements are good: trade and political agreements are good in themselves and must be encouraged; with partner countries like Chile, even more so. Now, we have to get them right. This negotiation must be used to make a better agreement; an agreement that lays down conditions on human rights, labour standards, etc., favourable, advanced, progressive and at the same time allowing us to make that agreement in favour of States, not investors. That is why good agreements have to be made and it must be done well in the case of Chile.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with this resolution on the modernisation and updating of the EU-Chile Association Agreement, the European Parliament rightly calls for improved cooperation in areas that we consider important, such as those related to human rights, the implementation of international agreements on climate change, the conventions of the International Labour Organisation, respect for the social rights of workers, women and LGBTQI people.  In the recent resolution adopted by the Committee on International Trade and Parliament on the trade side, the creation of a gender chapter is supported for the first time. However, these positive notes and, first and all, the confirmation of good relations with Chile cannot fail to point out other parts of the report with which we do not agree, such as the objectives of further liberalisation of the markets. It is certainly not the opening up to the ferocity of competition that defines the goodness and ambition of an agreement, the good relations between countries. In addition, there is a need for great transparency and involvement of civil society in the negotiations. Among other things, we find the report's call to make the EU an observer of the Pacific alliance to be very inappropriate. We do not believe that it is up to the European Union to decide what kind of integration the Latin American countries should follow, with which we have begun an important path within the framework of the EU-CELAC summits. For these reasons, we shall abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Madam President, the strengthening and modernisation of the European Union-Chile Association Agreement is a normal development of any bilateral relationship. Evolve with local, regional and, incidentally, regional and global trade and diplomatic data. In this case, we are offered a text dealing with fundamental areas, international relations that need to be tightened, but also on sometimes paltry data that interest only a minority of Chileans, such as considerations on sexual orientation. For the rest, the Chilean situation, even if it seems more stable despite a regular political alternation, reveals points of fragility, including the situation of students, still unresolved, the cost of raw materials, always very volatile, and the case of indigenous peoples who are waiting for their rights. Finally, Chile's accession to the Trans-Pacific Treaty, among others, should alert us to the multiplicity of regional agreements, which risks creating inconsistencies in the various international cooperations. This should prompt us to identify with great care the areas of action of the association with this country particularly close.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this report calls for a considerable strengthening of cooperation between two like-minded partners, on the basis of shared values and principles. We must not forget that it is of the utmost importance to ensure that the modernized Agreement with Chile is ambitious, comprehensive and balanced. Multilateral collaboration plays an important role in promoting international security and combating regional and global challenges effectively, so this Agreement should provide for security and defence cooperation, the fight against corruption, money laundering and tax evasion, among other issues, as it is an important part of our relations. Similarly, it should fully reflect the transformative nature of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the role of international development cooperation in achieving the sustainable development goals. We needed strategic objectives that mobilize the resources needed to achieve them. This modernized agreement must have the potential to significantly strengthen the existing relationship and must also be based on strong parliamentary participation. I take this opportunity to join the call for the negotiations on the Agreement to be accelerated, with the aim of allowing its ratification by Parliament before the end of the current European legislature, making it a key partner for Europe, a friendly country. This improved agreement is good for both parties.

name: Constanze KREHL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have the great honour of leading the European Parliament's Chile delegation and I have experienced one thing very intensively: Chile is a politically stable country, perhaps the most stable in Latin America. In recent years it has taken a very good development, not only economic, but also political-democratic development. President Bachelet has initiated many reforms, such as a new right to vote.B which will now allow women to participate more in active politics, tax reform, education reforms, she has begun pension reform and launched a new constitution according to Pinochet. I myself have seen that, in the course of the debate on the modernisation of the Association Agreement, gender, for example, has been introduced much more strongly by the Chileans, and that dialogue with civil society is much stronger and much better than ever before. We in the European Parliament should support precisely this development, and I really do support the demand that this European Parliament still be able to decide on this modernisation of the Association Agreement.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Madam President, Chile is a key player for the Union. His collaboration in colombia's peace process, his participation in the Santo Domingo talks and his involvement in the EUFOR Althea mission in Bosnia show his commitment to the international community.  Cooperation between the European Union and Chile in all fields needs to be strengthened: economy, trade, education and in the shared values of democracy and human rights. But it is necessary to insist on strengthening security cooperation, in the fight against narco, terror and organized crime; cooperation in security and defence with regard to conflict prevention; crisis management; maritime security, disarmament and non-proliferation are also much needed. The fight against corruption, money laundering and tax evasion are also an important part of our relationships.  Finally, when China and Russia are penetrating so much into Latin America, value-sharing partners need to strengthen their relationships and commitments.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Madam President, Chile is a small country but very politically and commercially relevant and from which we also have many things to learn, such as the exemplary process of handover of powers after an election. We share ties and are partners at the regional and global levels in defense of the same principles and values that are now precisely more necessary than ever. We have excellent bilateral relations, but the world has changed a lot since the current agreement came into force and we need to modernize it. But not any agreement, an agreement as this Parliament calls for, which is ambitious, comprehensive and balanced, that strengthens dialogue and cooperation in the face of the global challenges we share, in scientific, technical cooperation, in the face of climate change, in defence of human rights, in defence of the rights of indigenous peoples and, of course, gender equality. But I believe that the negotiation by the modernization of the political pillar and cooperation is vitiated by transparency. This Parliament must have access to all the texts of the negotiation, and the role of the Joint Parliamentary Committee in its follow-up is essential. And we must ensure the involvement and participation of society throughout the negotiation process and its implementation. We hope you will take these recommendations into account.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, Chile is an important country with strong democratic institutions and a thriving economy. The European Union's relations with Chile have only grown since the signing of the Association Agreement in 2002. Trade and investment increased. It is now a question of modernizing and extending the Agreement. I would like the negotiations to be completed in 2018, and the EU-Celac Ministerial Meeting in July in Brussels may be an opportunity to promote them.  If we add to the agreements with Mexico, Central America and Cuba and the Multiparts Agreement that of Chile and the possible agreement with Mercosur, we would have a vast network of agreements with the countries of Latin America that will strengthen relations between the two continents. Let us not forget that China's presence in Latin America is growing a lot.  We share with Ibero-America values and principles. We are natural allies, as Charles Tannock has rightly said. In conclusion, it would be appropriate that in the dynamic Alliance of the Pacific, where Chile is located, the European Union should be able to participate as an observer, as European countries already do, including Spain.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Madam President, the Recommendation on the negotiation of the modernized Association Agreement with Chile, as usual in such agreements, speaks of human rights cooperation and, in particular, encourages Chile to find a solution to the conflict with the Native Mapuche people. The Mapuche community in Chile is fighting for its claim as an original people and for the recognition of its ancestral lands, in the face of the Chilean Government's rejection of the fundamental right, protected by the United Nations, to decolonization. The Chilean government's crackdown on the original peoples is oversteened by the Araucanía Plan, that so-called National Agreement, which delves de further into the problem by criminalizing the fight and equateing it with terrorism. The European Union should modernise this agreement, but modernise it so that the rights of the Mapuche people are respected and to stop the abominable practices of some European multinationals, which contribute to the disforestation and polluting of Mapuche lands and which push their inhabitants into extreme poverty and marginalization.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Madam President, bilateral relations between Chile and Europe are very important. That is why we want to draw attention in these negotiations on the rights of the Mapuche people, who are entitled to their political, economic, social and cultural self-determination. We already told Mr Piñera when he was in this Parliament. We told him clearly and reminded him of his commitment to human rights, which was breached. We would like to remind you now of three issues as well. First, the Mapuche conflict cannot be associated with terrorism. This criminalizing measure has been evident in the extreme militarization of the Araucanía, in the creation of a special police force, in the continuity of the use of protected witnesses and, above all, in the lack of compliance with Chile's commitment to Convention No 169 on Indigenous and Tribal Peoples of the ILO.  Secondly, we also remind you that these communities in resistance require dialogue and respect, and do not garrote as in times of dictatorship.  And finally, where is the plan to combat child poverty and the fight against poverty in general and education commitments? In a bilateral agreement of course we have to take care of human rights commitments.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: – Madam President, fourteen years after its entry into force, the European Union is about to renew the Association Agreement with Chile, a friendly country with which we have always shared deep cultural roots and our oldest trading partner in Latin America. Renewing this Agreement today means strengthening Europe's role as a key partner in Latin America, at a time when America's global leadership is becoming increasingly uncertain and when other countries, such as China, are gaining increasing influence in the region. There are some critical points: human rights and the protection of indigenous peoples. I am pleased to see that both are addressed in the report. The European Union should encourage Chile to solve the Mapuche problem, the people of the Earth, the only ethnic group native to South America that has survived European colonization, whose lands have been seized since 1867 and arbitrarily occupied by the Chilean government, which is still englying a Pinochet-era anti-terrorism law. I therefore hope that the Agreement will be renewed on this basis, that a friendly hand will be extended to this friendly country and that a balanced relationship will be established, that it will bring tangible benefits to all citizens on both sides of the ocean. We defend the Mapuche and their freedom.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this has really been a very useful exchange and I thank so much the honourable Members for their interventions. I would also like to congratulate again Mr Tannock on his report. From this debate I conclude that we all share a common interest in ensuring we conclude an ambitious, comprehensive and progressive-oriented modernised association agreement with Chile. I also note a wide convergence of views between what the European Parliament wants to see in the modernised agreement and what we are currently negotiating. We will continue working with our services in the Member States to ensure all concerns expressed here today are conveniently addressed. I would like to clarify something about the rights of the indigenous people. I can indicate that the issue has been touched upon in the context of the regular annual discussions on human rights between Chile and the EU and will continue to be addressed if there are reasons for concern. May I close by signalling once again my appreciation for Parliament’s input in these negotiations, which will in turn contribute to a successful agreement.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I too would like to thank the Commissioner for his kind words and in particular the words from the shadow rapporteurs and the various interventions from colleagues. I too am proud that the European Union’s Member States sent firefighters to Chile to help fight fires, that Chile welcomes refugees from the Maduro Venezuelan dictatorial regime and that Chile does scientific research jointly with the European Union’s Member States’ scientists under the Copernicus programme. These show what kind of mature and advanced country Chile really is. The wider EU-Latin American cooperation project is also one which is a natural fit of like-minded continents with shared history, culture, and, largely, respect for democracy, with sad exceptions like Cuba and Venezuela. But Latin America, by and large, is a democratic continent; we need to respect that and we need to work closely with it. I would just like to briefly mention my two amendments: Amendment 1, which is to change the word ‘dispute’ to the word ‘matters’. In my view, there is no conflict with the Mapuche people. I wish to soften the text by doing that. I hope that colleagues will support that. In Amendment 2, I disagree with the intervention from my Green colleague. Access to water is, of course, a human right everywhere, but the economic model that is employed is a Chilean national sovereign matter, not for interference by the EU or by our report. Water companies are often privately owned within EU Member States, so it would be totally ridiculous for us to prescribe an economic model to Chile and interference in their domestic affairs. So please support Amendment 2. Finally, thank you very much colleagues. It has been an interesting debate, and I think that Chile-EU relations will go from strength to strength.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the presentation of the 2017 Annual Report on human rights and democracy in the world and the related EU policy (2018/2751(RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, human rights are about real people, each one with their own story to tell. In the last year we have constantly tried to show this: when we talk about principles and values we talk about human beings. When we work for human rights, we work to make a real difference to millions of lives around the world. This was the main focus of the campaign we launched to celebrate the 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and this is also the logic that drives the new annual report. We live in a difficult moment for human rights around the world. In too many countries the situation has become worse, not better. This moment tells us that progress can never be taken for granted, and this is why we should continue working for positive change. But the report also shows that our action can make a real difference. Progress can happen, and it is happening in many parts of the world – thanks also to our commitment. For every violation of human rights, there are many more good stories to tell. For every criminal, there are many more human rights defenders. In this fight for justice, we know where we stand. And the report I am presenting today on behalf of the High Representative shows what our commitment means in practice. It maps our work firstly to strengthen democracy. Secondly, to end the death penalty. And thirdly, to support the rights of minorities. These are just a few examples. Let me say a few words on the structure of the report. Last year you recommended making the report more readable and publishing it without delay. So this year we have decided to focus on thematic issues and use country-specific examples, rather than going through each country one by one. Country reports now feature on our website so that the process is still transparent but also much faster. With the report we do not only want to provide a picture of the activities we do, but also to show our impact and give concrete examples, once again to show that human rights are not only about international law – the strictly legalistic approach – they are about people’s lives and they are the foundation of more solid societies. The report, for instance, mentions the cases of violence against vulnerable children in Fortaleza, Brazil, that have been cut by two thirds thanks to our support. And Federica Mogherini has just come back from Jordan, where she took part in the graduation ceremony for over 100 Syrian refugees who were able to finish university thanks to our financial support. But let me also mention the first ever election observation mission that we deployed in The Gambia to accompany the country’s extraordinary path from dictatorship towards a truly inclusive democracy. I would like to thank in particular the EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, who has contributed to many of these ‘good human rights stories’ and for making them more visible. ‘Good human rights stories’ is the name of a new initiative to be launched at the UN General Assembly high level week in September. The aim is to show, together with a broad alliance of countries from across the globe, examples of where positive human rights practices have made fundamental changes to individual lives, communities and societies. In the coming year we will be celebrating these stories. They show where strong human rights protection frameworks have been put in place, where communities have been made stronger through the work of civil society organisations and where countries have shown that poverty reduction and sustainable development can be achieved hand-in-hand with making progress in human rights. Stavros Lambrinidis is also putting into practice one of the main ideas from our human rights action plan: the need to engage with all actors at all levels, because only through engagement can we improve the human rights’ situation around the world. Last year we published the mid-term review of the EU action plan. The review showed an encouraging trend concerning human rights dialogues, which are gaining in legitimacy and exerting a more positive impact on third countries. Again, this should only reinforce our commitment to engaging constantly with our interlocutors, particularly where and when human rights are not respected. In this respect our European Union delegations around the world are at the forefront of our daily work. Our staff in delegations monitor and follow up on cases of human rights violations. They meet with the lawyers of jailed human rights defenders and attend trials as observers. And they lead local dialogues on human rights with the national authorities. They are very often the face of the European Union in the world, and it is also thanks to their work that we are known as a credible and reliable force for democracy and human rights. This is not an easy moment for fundamental rights, democracy and human rights defenders. In a moment like this, it would be easy to fall into cynicism and despair. We must continue to critically assess our own approach and adjust, where necessary. The scrutiny of this Parliament is indispensable in this regard. But as we do this, we must also keep in mind all the progress we have achieved together, and all the lives that have improved thanks to the European Union’s commitment. There is always hope, even in difficult times like these. And precisely in difficult times like these we must redouble our efforts.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, I welcome the work done in 2017 to promote human rights and democracy in the four corners of the world by the institutions of the European Union. This work is summarized in the annual report adopted by the Council a few weeks ago. I also welcome the new format of the report, which is shorter and more concise. I was particularly pleased, on reading it, that the promotion of democracy is more important, as well as the work that the European institutions and our delegations in third countries do on a day-to-day basis. I have campaigned for this throughout this mandate and especially when I was Parliament's rapporteur on the annual report.  Indeed, I believe that we cannot imagine a situation where human rights would be respected in the absence of a well-established democratic framework. In 2017, we have seen how authoritarian regimes are violating the most basic rights of their citizens. I am thinking of Venezuelans, whose freedom of expression is called into question and whose economic and social rights simply no longer exist. In this same sense, I am thinking of Cuba, but also of North Korea, to which the eyes of the world are now turning, forgetting that it is one of the worst dictatorships in history. Moreover, in 2017, a number of leaders have turned to the mirage of authoritarianism, as in Turkey. In relation to all these cases, I believe that we must continue to act and redouble our efforts in concert with our Member States.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I also welcome the work and efforts made in the defence of human rights in the world by the institutions of the European Union; of course the work of the high representative and also of Mr Lambrinidis.  I'm not going to fall into the pessimism of saying that human rights go backwards. It is true that it depends heavily on the regions and that our efforts are always welcome outside the borders of the European Union. What I'm saying is that we have a coherence problem. The Commissioner said: it is not a good time, these are not good times for the defence of human rights, international law, fundamental rights. It is not; it is true that it is not and that there are entire regions of the world that are falling into questioning fundamental rights, the universality of human rights.  That is the case, and we have very important political leaders who defend this questioning of fundamental values. That is why the European Union needs to strengthen its work; but, of course, we too send very negative messages, aren't we, and I'm thinking of the Italian Government's last decision to keep out of its waters a ship laden with people who suffer and need help; or some of President Orban's actions and decisions. In other words, it is very difficult to give lessons to the rest of the world on human rights when we ourselves so blatantly breached the fundamental principles, as in the case of Italy yesterday.  And I don't think Salvini is solely responsible, nor Orban; I think we're all. And those who sit at the European Council with Salvini and Orban have a responsibility to point out the irresponsibility of these actions and the extent to which they question our role in the world, which is a fundamental role and which I believe the European Union is doing well.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR group. – Madam President, we are living a dark time for investigative journalism and the free press. There are abuses, violence, torture, pressure and murder has come to an end. Daphne and Jan were killed for fighting corruption, crime and the mafia. Just as an investigative journalist and digging up all the politicians' mess. The truth should not be paid with life. The truth must be applauded and rewarded. A danger against these investigative journalists are lawsuits opened in other countries, in other jurisdictions, against journalists, because that intimidates them, the costs are very high, they do not cope and they risk going bankrupt or giving up everything they have for such lawsuits. These lawsuits began to be practiced against the investigative journalist. The only solution is to amend and adopt modern anti-SLAPP legislation, as it is called in English, for these open trials in other jurisdictions at European Union level, and this as soon as possible.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, this year, while celebrating 70 years of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, we all must admit that justice and dignity across the globe are severely threatened. Therefore, I see this Commission report as a good stock-taking exercise, which is giving us an opportunity to identify the existing loopholes in our human rights policy and adjust it accordingly so that the situation can actually be improved. 2017 was marked by ongoing conflicts and humanitarian catastrophes, terrorism and radicalisation, as well as a tighter grip of authoritarian regimes on human rights defenders, civil society and populations in many parts of the world and even in European Union’s vicinity. In addition, in the EU itself, we have seen an unprecedented flow of fake news and propaganda, which have been used by governments and populists to spread anti—human—rights narratives, manipulate electoral processes and challenge liberal values. We urgently need to intensify our efforts to keep human rights at the centre of Europe’s Global Strategy and the EU’s external action. To foster civil society and stand up for human rights defenders around the world, it is crucial to build human rights alliances regionally and internationally with our United Nations partners. To resist the regimes and governments violating human rights, all tools at the European Union’s disposal must be applied with consistent resolve and determination. Real progress can only be achieved if human rights are never used as a bargaining chip in favour of EU or national economic and trade interests. Freedom and human rights are not for sale!

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The 2017 EU Human Rights Report is an impressive document with many sensible and necessary initiatives, especially at a time of growing backlash in human rights protection, the rule of law and the promotion of democracy. The ongoing and intensifying attacks on the independence and employability of civil society and human rights defenders require increased attention. The Protect Defenders program in particular should be continued and expanded. With regard to the current debate on the financing and merging of foreign policy instruments, I would like to stress the importance of the independence of the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights. Its effectiveness must not be jeopardised, especially in difficult political contexts. Expert voices from civil society report a creeping down on the EU's human rights protection. This is not the first time I have heard this criticism, and it must be taken seriously by the European External Action Service and the Commission. For example, it is unacceptable that the EU-Egypt Partnership Agreement was signed in 2017, even though the Egyptian President signed a tougher NGO law during the negotiation phase. This is just one example of many where the EU is losing credibility. In 2017, and also today, I see the EU's biggest shortcomings, not only in trade policy, but also in refugee policy, to deal with the double standards of its human rights policy and to consistently protect the lives and rights of refugees at our external borders. A very recent example is the refusal of a Member State to allow refugees in distress to come ashore. This shows the growing self-evidentness with which Member States and the EU are looking away when it comes to the human rights of refugees.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, reading this report is always a great moment as it illustrates 'satisfaction' and 'double standards'. Far be it from me to say that the European Union is doing nothing, but we all know here that overall human rights are going badly and that many of them are regressing, including, as has been said, in the European Union. A few examples, I think, are telling. Business and human rights: we know how much European companies are violating human rights around the world, how difficult it has been for the EU to participate in the work of the UN on the creation of a binding tool in this area, how much it is doing everything to minimise its scope.  Ditto for political dialogues on these issues with Asia and South America. These are the countries where European companies are on the front line of land grabbing and deforesting. Brazil is cited as an example, where a third of the Amazon rainforest has been destroyed, not to mention local populations displaced or even murdered.  How has the European Union made a difference? The same is true of efforts to support the ICC. A Statement by the High Representative of November 2017 on Mr. Al-Bashir's visit to Uganda, Russia and Chad is quoted. But the EU cooperates with Sudan and the legitimate internationally through the Khartoum process.  And what about the cynicism about migration policies: we welcome the human lives saved by forgetting the deaths in the Mediterranean, almost 15,000 in three years, in the desert but also on the soil of the European Union. People who are turned away, deported, including to dictatorships, such as Sudan. The same is true when we welcome a statement by Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi on the Rohingya and, more than I dare say, the dialogue on social rights with Cuba. All this lacks modesty, realism and at least a minimum of critical sense.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this commitment to democracy around the world is remarkable, but here in the European Parliament it seems to me to be a priority to be concerned about democracy in Europe and, for the most part, in France.  In Europe, too, freedoms are being violated. The democratically elected Hungarian and Polish governments defend the identity of their people, you threaten them.  The Italians bring to power two parties concerned with the interests of their people, the Eurocrats call for not respecting their will.  But is it quite surprising on the part of a Commission chaired by Mr Junker who, in order to make Greece bend, said that there could be no democratic choice against the European treaties? Under the pretext of combating fake news and hate speech, any dissenting expression is censored on social networks. In France, identity in particular made it the bitter experience, as did Tommy Robinson in England, for denouncing the evils of immigration. This serious decline in freedoms in Europe is deeply dangerous and yet you support and encourage it.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if we look at reality, we cannot fail to emphasise that the human rights movement is in crisis. After decades of conquest, many countries seem to have taken steps backwards. Many populist leaders and strongmen systematically express a total disregard for human rights and those who defend them. I have to say, however, that perhaps the human rights movement does not seem to be learning the right lessons from the difficulties. Today, in the year in which the 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration is celebrated, we must ask ourselves how to approach the issue, whether by intensifying the old strategies or whether we are broadening the field. Let's understand: there is no doubt that activism can move people, but if the things we say about moral obligations had made a difference the world today would be in better shape. Those of us who care about and care about human rights must ask ourselves what drives so many people to vote strong men in the world and in Europe. At the end of the day, the expansion of international human rights policies has been accompanied by the economic phenomenon that has led to the rise of radical populism and nationalism. It wasn't supposed to be like this. It was assumed that the Universal Declaration would take care of social protections and instead the fight for human rights left the social citizenship aspect too much in the background.  Well, if we want to point to a wider field today, then we must unify more and more human rights and social rights. While I welcome the report and the work done by Federica Mogherini and Stavros Lambrinidis, I believe that we should act for a more ambitious agenda that is capable of offering viable alternatives to the ills of our time.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, today is a good day to remember something very simple: that human rights are the rights of human beings and that half of human beings in the world are women.  Today is a good day to remember that many women, as in Saudi Arabia, claimed a right, such as driving, and that they are now in jail. Today is a good day to remember the repression suffered by Iranian women who have dared to take off their veils in public or to remember Egyptian Amal Fathy, arrested by her country's authorities for talking about sexual harassment on Facebook. Today we can remember that female genital mutilation continues to affect 30 countries and more than 200 million women and girls. Or remember that abortion is punished in El Salvador in all cases and that there are women in prison, including miscarriages. Let us remember all this today and every day, because it is our role to bring hope and guarantee rights to all women in the world.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, we all want to see the state of democracy and human rights improve throughout the world and would wish the European Union could play an even stronger role in its promotion when dealing with third countries. However, there is a great need for consistency between EU internal and external actions. If we don’t achieve coherence between what we do at home and what we would like others to do abroad, our capacity to achieve real change in the world is seriously hindered. Let me give you an example. Some of us will always remember that in 2017 a Member State of the European Union, Spain, used police violence to stop a vote – a democratic exercise in Catalonia and that, in the run—up to that vote and afterwards, the same Member State committed breaches of fundamental rights. And when that happened, the European Union basically looked the other way, instead of trying to defend EU’s citizens’ fundamental rights and Europe’s core values.  It is therefore imperative for the European Union, and for the credibility of its external action, not to use double standards when it comes to democracy and human rights, whether inside or outside our borders.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Madam President, in a debate on human rights in the world it is also important that we talk about what is happening in Europe. Because here austerity policies have affected the basic rights of the population, such as education, health, social security or housing.  In addition, we are witnessing how punitive populism is used with the excuse of terrorism and immigration to generate hate speech. In this way, the far right has managed to get its anti-immigration, anti-refugee and Islamophobic discourses adopted in many countries by the main parties and, above all and more worryingly, by governments such as Hungary or now also as Italy.  We also have European countries that continue to apply legislation that allows arrests without charge or trial and, with the excuse of security, normalize repression and restriction of the right to expression or freedom of expression. This is an authoritarian involution of our democracies, of which Valtonyc or Alsasua are clear examples.  Let us not be hypocrites, let us not demand from third countries what we do not comply with in our own. Let us strive to respect human rights and freedom of expression in Europe.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It was not long ago that human rights were at the heart of international politics, and no state dared to argue against it. Today it is very different: many see this as nice to have, some states even make fun of it openly. Human rights NGOs are being constrained in their freedom of movement and their activists are being persecuted – increasingly and increasingly brazenly. In such a world, it is important that not everyone yields to this zeitgeist. The European Union is now the main global player in the field of human rights; European foreign policy is centred on its observance. We have developed our own instruments and our delegations have become hotspots for human rights campaigners all over the world. None of this should lead us to complacency. We need to make even more effort, we need to improve our instruments, we need to involve the Member States more, and we need to look for allies. Above all, however, we need to strengthen self-healing forces around the world – and that is civil society.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, if not the EU, then who would lead on protecting and promoting universal human rights in the world? In this room, during this debate, I doubt anyone questions the need to uphold values and principles. But looking at the practice, a more troubling picture emerges: ‘migration management’ or ‘countering terrorism’ are increasingly blanket excuses to turn a blind eye to the rights of people. And privatised law enforcement, where private companies are filtering what people can and cannot see online without oversight, is another area to watch out for. I think it is essential that we don’t fall into the trap of the short-term populistic objectives, also with an eye on the new MFF. For Europe, interests such as security and values such as human rights protection should never be traded off because they overlap. So I urge for more political leadership that is unequivocal and that is not traded away at difficult moments.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, respect for human rights in the world in the last year has seen a lot of setbacks. Unfortunately, they have also contributed to contradictions, dysfunctions and perverse policies of the European Union, which discredit us. In countries large and small where the Union has influence, such as Ethiopia or Bahrain, because it has been shut up in the face of systematic abuses, including torture, arbitrary arrests, massacres. Or as in Sudan, or Myanmar, because it has financed and cooperated with governments that live on violating human rights. Because it has let the conflicts in Syria, and elsewhere, even, is the case in Syria, unknowingly or wanting to finance military equipment from the Erdogan regime, which cruelly persecutes Kurds, journalists and any opponents inside and outside the country, the regime with which the European Union has made an immoral deal on refugees. Or in Palestine, where the Union resigns itself to the Israeli occupation, which, in addition to making the two-state solution unfeasible, means repression and humiliation of an entire people who already count hundreds of peaceful demonstrators murdered in Gaza this year alone. In these and other cases, our credibility is at stake. How can we be credible in promoting human rights in the world if we do not look inside the European Union either?

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – Mr President, 2017 was a reference year for the european Union's overall work in the field of children's rights, by updating the guidelines on the promotion and protection of children's rights, which date back to 2007. Too often, children are exposed to specific abuse and therefore need greater protection. Child labour, recruitment into armed conflicts and early and forced marriages remain critical issues in some countries. A significant number also need help, especially in the area of health and access to education, water and sanitation. I believe that it is essential that, at European level, we develop an action plan for the coming years to prioritise children's rights in the European Union's external policies. The European Union has a moral obligation to continue its efforts to protect children from violence, abuse and exploitation.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this report is a useful x-ray of the situation of human rights and democracy in the world. Progress achieved, but also of the setbacks. We have seen, for example, an increase in the repression of human rights defenders with an increase in the number of homicides of these activists in several countries; unfortunately, unfortunately with great concern, we have also noted, with great concern, a growing hostility of civil society by different governments, through laws that hinder the activities of their organizations or even criminalize them on the basis of abusive interpretations of the very concept of terrorism. The international context is demanding and the European institutions must be up to their responsibilities. The European Union must be increasingly active and must strengthen the exemplary ity of its behaviour. For example, the European Union should increase the level of demand for its extraterritorial responsibilities when European companies or investors whose operations neglect human rights in third countries are concerned. The truth is that millions of people, whose human rights are disrespected in various parts of the world, often still see in the European Union a last hope of achieving some support and some protection. Our responsibility is to live up to the expectations of these people.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, human rights also remained at the heart of the European Union's external action in 2017. We have worked for the affirmation on a global scale of the same principles that inspired the creation of the Union: democracy, the rule of law, respect for human and fundamental rights, the principles of equality and solidarity. We have worked to ensure that these principles find their place within all policies, especially those with a strong external dimension. I am thinking in particular of development, trade and migration policies.
