Threats to the current way NATO works are a political reality. Discussions between the European Union and NATO include even trade preferences. Likewise, with the exit of the United Kingdom, as much as 80% of NATO's fiscal capacity will be outside the European Union.  The European Union was created to keep the peace. It needs to be its core function globally as well. However, the European Union must embrace geopolitical change and be prepared to contribute to globan security with adequate capacity of its own. Strengthening the European Union's defence capabilities needs to develop a more effective response to crises, strengthen transathlanic ties and contribute to NATO. Colleague Paşcu's report well compresses Parliament's position on this important issue and contributes well to discussions on the future of defence and security cooperation at a globan level.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, there’s much in the Paşcu report on which we can agree, in particular the final paragraph which recognises the need for the EU to ensure a close security and defence partnership with the United Kingdom after Brexit. The UK is, after all, and will remain, the pre—eminent European military power. As referred to by Ms Mogherini, it is also right that due attention be given to the ease of mobility of allied forces across Europe, not just in times of tension but also for exercise purposes when necessary. Particularly at a time when there is some friction in transatlantic relations, and as we approach July’s NATO summit, it is doubly important that European nations signal to the United States our willingness to bear more of the defence burden. The Americans, after all, have increased their European Reassurance Initiative, which further confirms US resolve to defend Europe, by some 40% to USD 4.8 billion. Just this local increase by the United States is more than the total defence spending of at least 10 European countries.  I suggest that European burden sharing is not improved by the creation of separate defence structures, by the exclusion of major third countries from defence industrial projects or from pursuit of an elusive and ill—defined EU strategic autonomy. This is all about European political integration, not defence, and is the central weakness – I’m sorry to say – of the report.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the report has a permanent reference to NATO's fundamental strategic role, and it is true. Occasionally some timid references appear to mean the need for a defence and a concept of autonomous European security, which is evident.  If we take into account even the references made to the CEP and that the CEP has now just indicated that non-European companies will not participate in THE CEP investment plans, that is, The US, it is clear that the paradigm has changed, and the paradigm has changed because Trump has ceased to be an anecdote to be a categorical anecdote. And the categorical anecdote is called: the expulsion of the Atlantic Trade Treaty, which we were negotiating; the breakdown of the Iran Agreement; the breakdown of the Climate Change Agreement... and the last have been intolerable contempt in the G-7, which even reach personal offense.  This is Mr Trump's "twitter thinking," which is critical because it's the main power right now in the world. And what this means is that the United States is no longer the permanent reliable partner we had in the European Union — and these are mrs Merkel's words, which gives me the impression that it is not a defining extremist. In this regard we have to respond and be able to respond with our own challenges.  In the face of 'American first' we have to determine that NATO is a fundamental pillar in European defence and security, but certainly not the only one; because one day we will wake up when Mr. Trump reaches an agreement with Mr Putin and we will be like that joke we say in Spain that there is a painter painting the ceiling, someone arrives, he removes the ladder and says "hold on to the brush, mate": that's how we'll look.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Thank you, Madam President. This is certainly not the first time, and much less the last, that we have the chance to talk about the relationship between the European Union and NATO. And I fully agree with the rapporteur that this has been an important report: it offered the chance to clarify this rather complicated relationship. However, I regret to say that we feel that at some crucial points the report itself has been more of a missed opportunity. Instead of clarifying, at some points it has indeed further complicated this relationship that was otherwise not very easy. Despite the laudable work that went into the file on behalf of the rapporteur and the shadows, we are not able to support it, on many grounds. Let me start with the simplest, and the easiest one. The report makes reference and emphasises, rightly, the security, defence and political challenge that Russia poses for the European Union. However at almost all points of the text this sounds as if it is an exclusively eastern problem. We seriously disagree with that. Just witness the political meddling in the Brexit process or a number of European general elections, so indeed this is not just an issue for the east to consider, and this is not an issue for NATO’s eastern flank. This is a larger concern to that we need to deal with. The second and, probably much more important, point is that the report claims that Article 42, paragraph 7 of the Treaty contributes to a stronger NATO. I don’t think I need to remind my honourable colleagues that this particular article is not traditionally understood as an obligation for collective response. This is an obligation for a bilateral, individual response between Member States. And considered in such a way, actually many analysts think that this this further complicates the issue rather than clarifying it. Much as I would like to avoid this, we cannot simply support this file as it stands now. Thank you very much.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, High Representative, we are facing another ode to European submission, a true panegyric to NATO's militaristic, aggressive and expansionist chains. This report on European Union-NATO relations clearly shows a foreign and defence policy within an American strategy organized through NATO that is not only alien, but contrary to the interests of Europe itself.  It is a shot in the foot to any participation as an autonomous subject in the transit to the multipolarity that lives the world. It is the consolidation of a European Union that, without its own foreign policy, sounds like a tow-detuned orchestra from the United States.  Tensions are discussed in the east or southern neighborhood, but many of its causes are hidden. And NATO's involvement, of course, as in the attack on the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia— outside international law — that blew the Helsinki agreements. Either NATO's expansion into Russian borders—which also grounded the Paris Charter—or Western interventions in Iraq or NATO, particularly in Libya.  The European Union-NATO Partnership is not fundamental to the common security and defence policy, it is just the opposite: it denies an autonomous policy and mimics nato's worst policy.  In the face of this proposal for militaristic submission, in the face of rearmament and intervention, a truly independent defence policy is needed and that advocates for détente and peace.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the report on European Union-NATO relations is revealing and very dangerous, as it sets out the war preparations of the two imperialist alliances. Mrs Mogherini, you spoke of the achievements of NATO and the European Union. But the European Union and NATO are forces of insecurity for the people and destabilisation in the Balkans and the wider region. They have torn Yugoslavia apart and, among many others, are responsible for border changes and the break-up of states, for the changing of peoples. The European Union and NATO are strengthening their military readiness in the context of competition with Russia and China, strengthening military missions and exercises with a generalisation of so-called military mobility. What does that mean? Remove the last obstacles so that NATO and the European Union can grind unhindered with their troops across Europe. PESCO, evaluation mechanisms, defence fund shield the autonomous interests of European groups in competition with the United States, which the report meaningfully christens as misunderstandings of the United States. The peoples with their struggle must be vigilant about any border change and disengagement from these wolf alliances. With the people in power, it's the only way!

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to thank Mr Pacu warmly for his very timely report. I think we are looking at how we can optimise cooperation between the EU and NATO. There are things that NATO can do better and must do better, but there are things that we can do better at EU level. That is why it is now important that we realise that, with better work within the EU, we are also strengthening the European pillar of NATO. If we carry out CARD, the Defence Review, every year, then we know what we need. If we then go further in the field of defence research and capability development, if we set up the Defence Fund and then make our contributions better in the EU budget for cooperation in our defence industries, then we will be better together and also better within the NATO framework. But it is also important that we develop strategic autonomy for this when other NATO partners do not want us to act. I believe that we, as the European Union, must also be able to act independently of NATO if necessary.

name: Soraya POST
text: – Madam President, I say ‘no’ to NATO. The EU does not need to strengthen relations with NATO, but rather the opposite. I cannot accept the continuation of old-school militaristic thinking, with priority afforded to military alliances and increased spending on defence budgets and militaries globally, leading to tensions between countries. As a feminist and a pacifist, I call for a transformation towards a feminist security policy that puts human security, personal integrity and safety from interpersonal violence at the centre of our defence and security agenda. For a safer world we need to invest in conflict-prevention and mediation. The EU is meant to be a peace project, not a military project.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, we hope for added value arising from cooperation between the EU and NATO. There are challenges, though, and in order to avoid them we have to fulfil certain preconditions – first to avoid duplication, and therefore well—defined modalities of cooperation that are needed. Secondly, the key importance of transatlantic cooperation, despite tensions in other areas, and cooperation with the UK after Brexit. Otherwise without these modalities we cannot fulfil the strategic autonomy of the EU. We do not have enough potential to bring greater security to the region, and therefore I am very cautious about the stressing of strategic autonomy in this report. We look forward to cooperation in areas like cybersecurity, military mobility and tackling hybrid threats.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This is a report that is very contradictory, on the one hand it claims that the EU and NATO have different tasks, but then everything points towards a total confusion, with counter-terrorism, the fight against irregular migration, etc. Despite the title, a more concrete partnership, most of it is very fuzzy.  I myself come from a country that is not a NATO member and see the issue also from that perspective. Paragraph 33 mentions that Non-NATO Member States should have different obligations within the framework of the European Defence Union. Please tell us what obligations are meant. Paragraph 9 states that cooperation should also be deepened in the event of crises, not war, on the European continent. What kind of crises? Are storms and floods, refugee flows or terrorist attacks meant? The report presents the possibility of joint EU and NATO action on EU territory, but does not say how and under what circumstances this can happen. In practice, this could mean Turkish soldiers in Greece or NATO forces in neutral EU countries. Who decides who will do what, and what to do? The text also opens up the voluntary permanent structured cooperation for NATO before it has even started, and it is also very problematic both strategically and politically for us, but perhaps also legally.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This is yet another embarrassing report. For the most part, it is reasonable. Although it may not bring anything significant, it speaks to the awareness of the growing threats, for example from Russia, and the need to increase defence spending, as opposed to completely irresponsible voices like the one we have just heard from the Post. But it also includes a wildly dangerous paragraph 33, which stresses that EU member states should be able to conduct independent military missions even when NATO does not want to take action or when EU action is more appropriate. This is an attempt to turn upside down the NATO-based security order. The Union's attempt to counter NATO's actions and to give itself the freedom of manoeuvre of European powers, which are trying to become independent from America. For this reason, I cannot support the report.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Madam President, as my colleagues have already done, I would like to welcome the opening of this new era in cooperation between the Union and NATO since the Warsaw Declaration of 2016. Complementarity, operational cooperation, more effective coordination, these are key words, and as my colleague Danjean has pointed out, we must always have in mind this collective defence couple assumed by NATO and the union's strategic autonomy. I think that is a good plan to follow. This is how Europe will be a credible partner, especially under the current conditions, namely a resurgence of Russian aggression at the Baltic borders and in the countries of Eastern Europe, including the Western Balkans. I could not finish without congratulating Mr Paecu on his report. I would also suggest that he pass this report on to his party leader in Bucharest, he has much more to say about the Union and NATO than Mr Dragnea, who has just said that the Union and NATO have financed what they call the 'parallel state'.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is important for the European Parliament to look at EU-NATO relations, especially in view of the fact that the EU is redefining itself precisely in its own defence. I support a common European security and defence policy based on the principle of the pooling and sharing of arms. At the same time, I support a policy of conversion and European-coordinated arms exports as an instrument of a common foreign policy. However, as a member of the Euro-SPD, I call for a revision of NATO's 2% target towards an adequate defence budget for the EU Member States. Simply increasing expenditure alone is not the right step to ensure the safety of European citizens. We need a more efficient Europeanisation of the defence industries of all The Member States, which goes hand in hand with a common strategy. That is why I have asked for the relevant paragraph in this text to be voted on separately. There will be no support for NATO's 2% target with us Social Democrats in the European Parliament.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Madam High Representative, i would like to thank you for your excellent work The planned defence cooperation of the European Union will serve either the security of our countries – and then we must remember that three quarters of our countries are allied in the Atlantic Alliance – or solely the independence of the defence dimension from real policy, that is to say, the delivery of another instrument to the authorities of the European Union and the gradual building of supremacy towards our countries. I asked today, High Representative, Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Timmermans, about Nord Stream 2, and he has talked for a long time about the current challenges facing the European Union. Not only did he not answer the question, but he refused to take a position when he was brought to his attention. We have all known since clausewitz that the defensive dimension must serve politics. If it does not serve, it serves only power.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Madam President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. With the European Defence Fund, Permanent Structured Cooperation and the Coordinated Annual Defence Review, the European Union has probably achieved more in the last two years in the common defence than in previous decades. Both the European Union and NATO as a whole will benefit from this. I would like to give a very specific example in this debate. Earlier this year, I visited NATO Battle Group Lithuania in Rukla. There I was told how much logistical and administrative effort is involved in transporting equipment and vehicles to the Baltics. Permits must be obtained weeks in advance and dozens of different forms, which in turn differ in each country, must be filled in. I therefore warmly welcome the PESCO project to improve military mobility. We cannot afford to see military transport, when it comes down to it, being slowed down by bureaucratic hurdles and inadequate transport networks. This is a successful example of cooperation between the European Union and NATO. We should continue to do so.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, NATO is facing unprecedented challenges. It is forced to expand its operations for the first time since the Cold War, to extend its actions into domains of counter-terrorism and cybersecurity. Transatlantic unity is vital to NATO, but it’s crumbling, as we evidenced at G7 earlier this week. That’s why next month’s NATO summit has to sustain the momentum in the creation of the European Defence Union. We cannot waste over EUR 25 billion a year on inefficiencies. My questions to the High Representative are: whilst Russia is clearly a top priority, what about the world’s second largest defence spender, increasingly aggressive in the South and East China Sea and spectacularly growing its military footprint in Africa – China? I do recognise that there have been talks at staff level with China that have resumed, but the EU and NATO need to engage more actively in this part of the world to avoid being behind the curve. Secondly, regardless of Brexit, UK and EU security will remain closely entwined. What is the architecture of our future cooperation? How do we ensure unity remains the watchword for our security?

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Allow me to express my condolences at the beginning to the families of two Bulgarian military pilots who died in a military helicopter crash yesterday evening while performing a training task.  This catastrophe shows how much our countries need closer cooperation with each other, the purchase of new combat equipment that is compatible and that meets NATO standards. There is no doubt that any defence alliance, including US, must have a clear command line.  Yes, a partnership between the European Union and US is needed. Yes, European countries need to have enhanced synergies in arms purchases, putting 2% of their gross domestic product into renewing their weapons systems and being adequate, and be prepared to respond to any external threat. This is even more important for countries such as Bulgaria and Romania, which are located in the Black Sea region, a region with extremely high uncertainty.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – And I want to join in the condolences for the relatives of the fallen pilots in Bulgaria.  This shows once again the importance of having a reliable technique that is compatible in THE EU.  First, I want to state that OUR ALLIANCE is our defense alliance. It is up to us how effective and strong EU is, and that is why the European Union must be the effective and strong pillar of EUROPE. The European defence structure cannot be duplicating, but must be complementary to THE EU. The challenges we face are immense, both terrorism, extremism and cyberterrorism, an uncertain neighbourhood, both from the south and from the east. Our common goal is to ensure security for European citizens. No one has the right to divide the world into spheres, especially without asking those who will be divided. That's the kind of thing we've seen since World War II, and that should never be allowed again. After Brexit, 80% of NATO's defence spending will come from outside the European Union and three of the four battalions in the east will be led by non-Member States of the European Union. In this regard, indeed, we here in the European Union need to invest much more in the defence field, both in purchasing and in the cost of innovative activities and technologies.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, the European Union and NATO are the two major international organizations that have ensured peace and prosperity in Europe after World War II. Obviously, cooperation between the two, which has been increasingly dynamic since 2014, is very beneficial, and I would like to congratulate Mr Paécu on his report. Moreover, at the current stage of European construction, one of the main objectives is the strengthening of the Union in the field of security and defence. This development will also be very useful for cooperation with NATO and will reinforce the so-called European pillar. In addition, the European Union and NATO complement each other. This is appropriate, for example, for new threats, such as hybrids, cybersecurity attacks, humanitarian crises and also in the face of terrorism itself. These challenges and others cannot be faced only by military means. The european Union's variety of resources can be very suitable for dealing with them. Let's be pragmatic. We are in a complex, interconnected, increasingly multipolar world. That is why it is necessary to strengthen our alliances, even if it is difficult, and also to strengthen relations between the two major organizations. I hope that this will contribute to the joint declaration scheduled for next month on the occasion of the next NATO summit in Brussels.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Madam President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Madam President, thank you very much for the opportunity to speak again. I would like to say that, despite all the crises we have, NATO is a highly successful defence community that we need for Europe's collective security. We should not mix this up with anger at a particular American president. But we should also make it clear that we want to be a pillar, an equal pillar of NATO and not vassals. But that means we have to be stronger. That is why we should not just get involved in this 2% discussion, but we should make it clear that the European Union must create the synergy effects that were hinted at in the Defence Union of December. If we create these synergy effects, we will become stronger militarily with a tolerable amount of money and can play a major role. That is why the question of the Europeanisation of our defence policy is also a crucial starting point for credible strengthening of NATO.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, the world around us is changing. In order to ensure the security of our citizens, the Union must cooperate significantly more with NATO. Moreover, the EU must increase its own responsibility for its security and defence. Permanent cooperation in the field of PESCO defence should only be a first step.  NATO and the EU currently have more than 40 measures in which they develop mutual cooperation. For example, we must learn together how to counter hybrid threats or cooperate in cyber defence. I see another possibility of cooperation in diversifying the arms industry. Simply put, the EU produces weapons, NATO uses weapons when necessary.  At present, the state actor most at risk of international peaceful coexistence is the Russian Federation. I therefore welcome the strengthening of NATO's forward presence on the alliance's eastern border and the deployment of four transnational battle groups in Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland. I am glad that the report says that the common strategic approach of both organisations towards Russia needs to be strengthened.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Madam President, with developing instability around the world, EU cooperation on defence and security is a necessity. With this in mind, we should welcome increased European cohesion on research and development. Projects like Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) and the European Defence Fund are really significant. At the same time, some EU representatives consider this the first step towards a common EU army. Therefore, let me stress that the EU is not a military alliance. The relevant and credible military structure of Europe is NATO. Since 1949 NATO has been an effective, powerful instrument for security, stability and peace. So let’s spend our time and our resources efficiently. Let’s not contribute to a parallel military structure in Europe.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: - Madam Chair, High Commissioner, my congratulations to the rapporteur on a well-prepared report aimed at highlighting the importance of a strategic partnership between the European Union and NATO in countering common threats and challenges on the global stage. Hybrid threats, terrorism, the migratory pressures we see today through the Balkan route, cyberattacks and disinformation hostile campaigns are just some of the challenges facing the Member States of the European Union and NATO, and accordingly they require a common response with a view to eliminating them.  Likewise, the European Union's cooperation with NATO is an integral pillar of European stability and security, and as part of the European Union's global strategy, this cooperation contributes to achieving peace and stability globally. However, I must stress the importance of adopting further steps towards the creation of the European Union's own forces with a view to maintaining peace, stability and security at its own borders and in the neighbourhood. If we take into account the fact that some NATO member states have serious problems in respecting fundamental human rights, then I think that the next logical step would be to create European capacities that would be a guarantee of peace and stability in the region, and especially in the Western Balkans, while respecting the fundamental human rights that are being trampled so easily in some of our partner states today.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Madam President, in the past years, the EU and NATO have achieved a remarkable degree of cooperation. With many shared members, common interests and challenges, we were working in close cooperation and have stepped up in such areas as hybrid and cyber threats, military operations and exercises, and the fight against terrorism. Especially we, the EU, have lately shown extensive efforts on defence, with concrete steps: for example, additional investments and better capabilities to share the burden of peace, security and defence equally. The launch of PESCO shows further the potential of how we can strengthen the European contribution within NATO. EU-NATO cooperation should be further enhanced against hybrid and conventional threats in the East and South of the EU, with NATO remaining the keystone of collective defence in Europe. I welcome these steps brought forward and included in this report. They are timely and aimed in the right direction.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I sympathize with colleague Paşcu. At the same time, it is conducting two important reports on PESCO and on today's debate, and I must say that the 360 amendments tabled to this report, many, many amendments tabled to this second document and the emerging elements of sabotage in the extreme parts of this House are not sabotage of our colleague's work, but the security conditions of Europe in difficult circumstances, in difficult financial and economic contexts. , economic, political. On the one hand, I would like to thank you for these compromises, not in terms of optimal security solutions, but for the compromises, above all, for some political agreement, in order to regard in this House the relations between the European Union and NATO as important, demanding work, requiring modification, needing to be strengthened. I am, of course, in favour of this report and thank you for the work that has been done.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I very much welcome this report and i am ready to vote in favour of it.  I am very happy that we are talking here about NATO-EU cooperation and that we are not trying to talk here about alternative military structures that we would create and which should be competitive with NATO. This is extremely important for us in the Czech Republic. We, the EU, are not a military defence association. We have some different rules, and so we need that defense component, the defense part, to be primarily NATO-level.  This does not prevent us, the EU Member States, from cooperating more in the field of military research, in the field of military procurement, so that there may be another form of cooperation, but there should not be a European army. I think that is very important and the report is going in the right direction. NATO is a partner, not a competitor, and I strongly support it.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, NATO is a key framework for European security. While there is a need for reform to respond more effectively to new security challenges, it is important that both the European Union and the United States remain committed to this alliance. It is a legitimate wish of the Member States of the Union to achieve European specifics in responding to security challenges. It is natural that everyone wants to hold their destiny primarily in their own hands and tailor the system to defend according to their needs. Cooperation with global partners within NATO is not an obstacle to this. In fact, US President Trump's call for greater spending of European states for defence opens up an opportunity to strengthen European political influence and our defence capabilities within the alliance.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, NATO is, and will remain for years to come, the most vital security partnership framework. In this phase of multifaceted security challenges coming both from east and south, the EU and NATO have been deepening their cooperation during recent years. I’m very glad to see that many European Union countries, including my home country – Lithuania – have met and even exceeded their obligation to allocate 2% of GDP for national defence this year. I believe we have to ensure even better coordination of our capabilities and resources, as well as coordination at the strategic level. However, despite these achievements of deeper integration, we still lack today tools at our disposal to guarantee the most efficient, collective defence of European citizens and NATO allies. EU budget spending on the Union’s and its partners’ security must be regarded positively and will lead to an increase in public confidence.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Madam President, in my view, if the European Union really wanted to become a pole of peace, independent and different from other military axes, it would have to develop its tendency towards peace and human rights, away from military equipment. At the same time, there is supposed to be solidarity between nato-integrated states. But I would like to read you a statement by Mr Bahceli, a key supporter of Erdogan, towards Greece. The statement states: "Greece plays games with the Aegean islands and must be aware of its limits. Don't forget what their grandparents went through at the bottom of the Aegean Sea. The will of the people of Turkey, thank God, still exists and the Aegean will be a tomb of the Greeks." Shouldn't this toxic statement be denounced? Asked why he presents Cyprus in a campaign spot as Turkish, he said: "Yes. It is and will remain Turkish." So I tell him that Cyprus is the home of Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots and, if Today Cyprus is a prisoner of Turkey, at some point Turkey's policy will become a prisoner of Cyprus.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, an important report on cooperation and complementarity between the EU and NATO should be expressed realistically and pragmatically rather than by ideological or dogmatic approaches. A NATO that looks almost exclusively to the East, forgetting the Balkan side where it has operated for twenty years, is a NATO that is certainly short-sighted. A report which welcomes the continuing tendency to increase defence spending among NATO members does not go in a positive direction, quite the contrary. Excessive insistence on the eastern flank rather than on the Mediterranean is wrong, since it is precisely in this area that there are several potentially destabilising players for many Member States, not forgetting turkey's obvious critical issues that have in no way been highlighted.  Having a balanced approach to EU-NATO relations means demanding that in future bilateral relations be in favour of certain common objectives and not necessarily directed against third parties. We need a balanced approach, we need an approach that enhances the security needs of the various Member States of the two organisations, an approach that seems to be lacking in this report and we will abstain.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, NATO and the European Union are the two major Organisations of the West which have the common characteristic that many Member States of one are also members of the other. This fact suggests cooperation between them, but in those areas where such cooperation is justified. NATO is a military alliance and has the task of conducting collective defence and so it must remain. The European Union has to deal with threats from terrorism, cyber attacks and hybrid attacks and tackling these problems is mainly the responsibility of the Member States, in cooperation with the European Union in general.  At the moment no State of the European Union is at risk of threat and attack by a third force, with the exception of Greece and Cyprus which are directly threatened by Turkey. There is therefore no reason to turn the European Union into a military alliance. If this happens, relations with NATO will be conflicting, but it will have to be explained against whom this alliance will turn.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, we are discussing relations between the European Union and NATO, but I have heard nothing from either the rapporteur or Mrs Mogherini about Turkey's aggression towards Greece. Because it is well known that Turkey is constantly threatening my country. We have statements by Turkish officials that they will also wage war against Greece, we have constant violations of Greek airspace and our territorial waters by Turkey and above all we have two Greek military personnel, who have completed over 100 days imprisoned illegally in Turkish maximum security prisons. And Turkey continues this policy. We must demand the immediate release of the two Greek military and turkey must be denounced for this. I call on you, Mrs Mogherini, to make a statement on this subject on the immediate release of the two military personnel.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Madam President, as Commission Vice-President Federica Mogherini did, I would like to announce to the European Parliament an important agreement that was made a few hours ago. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and Former Yugoslav Prime Minister Zoran Zaev with realism, insight and boldness have made an agreement that opens up positive paths for both Greece and FYLOM and the Balkans and the whole of Europe. And I am sure that both the Council and the Commission and the European Parliament, the vast majority of all the political groups, will welcome and support the agreement, not only with positive statements, as Vice-President Federica Mogherini has already done, but also with the practical support of the two peoples. An important positive step has been taken today.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – NATO and the European Union remain the two cornerstones of Europe's security architecture. We fully support closer cooperation between the EU and NATO. By better aligning our defence efforts internationally, we are developing a more efficient and effective defence. Today's hybrid threats, cyber attacks, terrorism and so on are just some of the challenges we face. My delegation was also won for the development of a European defence community. Specific partnerships between certain EU Member States are a first step towards this. For example, Belgium and the Netherlands work closely together in joint purchases and maintenance of frigates and mine hunters or in air surveillance missions. Permanent structured cooperation in the field of defence (PESCO) must play a central role in this. However, we would like to leave the further details to the Member States, which are exclusively competent in this area.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, first of all, let me thank Mr Paşcu for an excellent report and all of you for the good support that you have provided to the work we have done in these years. Many of you reminded us of the crucial steps we’ve made, both in strengthening the European Union defence but also in cooperation with NATO. I would like to use these few minutes just to reassure you on the fact that, first, we will continue having a pragmatic, realistic approach as Mr Danjean mentioned. I believe we are beyond the ideological debate and we are focusing on the practical things we can and we have an interest in doing, and that the work will continue on the European way to defence and security, which is a particular one and which sometimes implies a military component but is never exclusively military. We will continue doing this, obviously, in the Council. Just in a couple of weeks from now, we will have another session of the Foreign and Defence Ministers together in the Council to prepare the European Council at the end of June, with further progress, especially on the Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) but also on the EU-NATO partnership. That, I believe, will contribute also to the good preparation of the NATO summit for what concerns NATO issues. Then there might be other issues coming up on the agenda that do not relate to defence and security, strictly speaking. I would also like to say that I believe that work will continue also in strong cooperation with other European institutions. I am thinking of the European Commission that is supporting this work for the first time ever, with especially the European Defence Fund and the proposed Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), but also with the European Defence Agency, which is doing a fantastic job in supporting technically all this work. So, thank you for the support. Thank you also for the indications. Last point: some of you mentioned the future relations with the UK. Let me say very clearly this will have nothing to do with relations between the European Union and NATO; clearly so. It has something to do with our work in the Permanent Structured Cooperation. Member States will come to that point later this year to define ways in which third countries might be invited to join some PESCO projects, but is not for now and it is not for NATO. I believe that, including our strong EU-NATO cooperation, we will find ways to have constructive work between the European Union and the UK after Brexit happens, because we share the same security objectives, and I believe that in this field we will manage to build strong cooperation in the future.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking the High Representative, Ms Mogherini, because she gave us a lot of extra information in the beginning, so we now know more about the collaboration, but also because she responded to some of the problems raised by my colleagues here and makes my task easier from this point of view. Our debate has been another example of the classical paradigm in which a bunch of blindfolded men are touching an elephant, and everyone is touching one part of that elephant and is describing a totally different animal. So although we have the same report in front of us, you saw how differently we present it. To Mr Van Orden and I would say that, instead of still using the old the image of a half-empty and a half-full glass, I would say that we have a glass which we fill from the two faucets at the same time. This probably better indicates the reality. I did not know that I have to bring something new in this report, because I did not know that this should be considered a PhD thesis. Some colleagues would like to see the novelty and when they don’t, they don’t like it. I am not a good Samaritan. My life experience up until now indicated to me that practically turning the cheek for another slap is not always the right thing to do, and that’s why I support the EU’s efforts in the field of security and defence. I would also say thank you to Mr Preda for his congratulations, but I’m also regretting the fact that he could not isolate himself from bringing internal politics into our discussion today. I would like to conclude by saying thanks to all the rapporteurs. Indeed we worked very, very well. There were many amendments. We found the compromises, which are reflected in the report. At the same time I’m thanking everybody who has said good words about the report but also the critics, because it indicates that they took the effort to read the report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 June 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – The values of democracy, peace, human rights, freedoms and respect for the sovereignty and independence of the Member States of both entities must remain at the heart of EU-NATO cooperation in the future. However, the cooperation and coordination of the components concerned, the strengthening of tactical and operational cooperation in the field of security, defence and protection against military attacks, together with the development of appropriate military technology and new technologies, must also take into account new forms of threats and attacks linked in particular to digitalisation and cyber-attacks. Care must be taken that this support is not misused, for example, to support terrorism or to conflict-inducing activities and attacks. Moreover, it should not be forgotten that increasing arms expenditure and coordinating expenditure alone is not enough. We need to call on our partners, especially the US, to direct more resources towards development aid. Without funding education, we cannot tackle poverty and unemployment in Africa, for example, or the huge demographic boom on this continent, which, coupled with poverty, is a risk not only for Africa, but for all of us.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union's cooperation with other international organisations is an important aspect of its foreign policy. On the sidelines of the NATO Summit held in Warsaw in 2016, an EU-NATO Joint Declaration was signed. The report analyses in detail the similarities and differences between the two organisations, as well as the extent to which they are adapted to a new and still challenging geopolitical environment. The report highlights a wide range of tools (hard and soft) that can be implemented when needed to strengthen the complementarity between the two organisations.  More effective and efficient cooperation between the EU and NATO is not an end in itself, but means achieving common security priorities as well as strengthening mutual values such as liberal democracy, multilateralism, the protection of human rights and the rule of law. Cooperation between the two organisations must be complementary and respect each other's specificity, role and decision-making autonomy.  The report also summarises the progress achieved in bilateral cooperation between the EU and NATO since 2016. It should be stressed, however, that this is a continuous process that is still ongoing. The main areas of cooperation include: security and protection of cyberspace, expanding development opportunities for industry and research, efforts to build a more robust mutual partnership, analysis and countering hybrid threats, maritime security issues, the fight against terrorism, military mobility, assistance to conflict-affected areas, peacekeeping and security of Member States and associated countries.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Jarosław Wałęsa, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to Ukraine (COM(2018)0127 – C8-0108/2018 – 2018/0058(COD)) (A8—0183/2018).

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Madam President, I am speaking on behalf of rapporteur Jarosław Wałęsa, who is not able to be here due to family reasons (he is about to become a father, which is always I suppose a very happy thing). Macrofinancial assistance is an exceptional emergency mechanism aimed at addressing severe balance of payment difficulties in third countries. In other words, it is a financial instrument and its purpose is economic stabilisation.  This is the fourth time that the Commission proposes macrofinancial assistance (MFA) for Ukraine since the beginning of the war in 2014. This time, the Commission proposes EUR 1 billion to be dispersed as medium- and long-term loans. The assistance is also intended to trigger reforms in Ukraine, which is done by agreeing with the Ukrainian authorities a Memorandum of Understanding. This Memorandum sets out the supporting policy measures which are conditional for the disbursements of the funds. In that context, I would like to highlight three key elements. First, the worsening conflict and casualties in the east of Ukraine and all the many socio-economic consequences of this aggression. Second, the economic recovery, which remains fragile. Third, the reform process, which has been important but is not really steady until now. Hence, the need for support for these reforms in the context where many interests can play against, especially in pre-election years. That being said, to address any doubts that may arise during this debate, the MFA is not an unconditional support. There are firm conditions to ensure that this money will serve economic stabilisation and support the reforms.  It is very important to remind that the Commission cancelled the last tranche of the third MFA programme when some of Ukraine’s commitments were not fulfilled. Therefore, it is crucial that the two unfulfilled anti-corruption measures will be part of the new conditions. If corruption is not addressed drastically, MFA funds should not be delivered to Ukraine.  A step in the right direction is the adoption of the law on the high anti-corruption court this last week. In addition, the newly adopted law was signed yesterday by the President of Ukraine. The rapporteur welcomes this news with great satisfaction: it means that Ukrainians take the commitment seriously.  I believe that our common goal is to help Ukraine, but it is true that we need to closely follow the situation. If we are serious about our goal, we cannot slow down the procedures. This means that the rapporteur does not support any amendments tabled to the plenary and recommends closing the file at first reading. To end, I would like to underline once again that this report is just a legal base for the Commission to disburse the money, but they will do so only when Ukrainians manage to fulfil all the agreed and outstanding conditions. The rapporteur is very sure that the Commission will take this role actively and will pay great attention to political evolutions in Ukraine.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first thank the rapporteur, Mr Wałęsa, and the Committee on International Trade (INTA) for their work on this report. I would also like to thank the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) for its valuable contribution to this debate.  The partnership between Ukraine and the EU has grown deeper and stronger. Today I am seeking your support to maintain this momentum through the adoption of a further proposal for macro-financial assistance (MFA). A look at the past MFA operation from 2014 shows how important this support is for Ukraine.  First, back in 2014, the MFA was a key EU instrument to provide immediate financial assistance to Ukraine in order to stabilise its economic and financial situation. Ukraine returned to economic recovery and growth in 2016 and 2017, after two years of steep recession. It is an important success story, not only for Ukraine, but also for the EU.  Second, the MFA has played a major role in supporting reforms in Ukraine and, in particular, in stabilising Ukraine’s economy in the medium term. Through this programme, the EU has supported a broad range of anti-corruption reforms, including the establishment of the anti—corruption infrastructure, spearheaded by the National Anti-Corruption Bureau. Reforms to its energy and public procurement markets also helped to eliminate major sources of corruption. It has also helped Ukraine to improve its public finance management, to clean up its banking sector and to improve its business environment, for example, by automating VAT returns and reducing red tape.  However, despite its recovery, Ukraine’s economic situation remains fragile. Russia’s destabilising actions in eastern Ukraine continue, and the security situation remains tense. Ukraine is paying a high price. For example, its defence spending reached 5% of GDP last year, which otherwise could be used for the development of Ukraine. Ukraine’s debt repayment obligations will increase substantially in 2018 and 2019, putting a very heavy burden on the state budget. We cannot afford to let Ukraine fail. Therefore, the new MFA operation is necessary, along with other international support, in particular from the International Monetary Fund.  Having stressed the importance of this MFA proposal, let me add a clear message on the reforms in Ukraine. As always, this MFA proposal is strictly linked to reform conditions. Due to delays with the implementation of agreed anti—corruption reforms, the Commission cancelled the last disbursement under MFA III in January 2018. In order to give a clear political signal to the Ukrainian authorities that the newly proposed MFA operation will also be subject to state conditionality, Parliament, the Council and the Commission have agreed – on Parliament’s initiative – to attach a joint statement to the legislative decision. I am convinced that this joint statement adequately addresses the key concerns of MEPs voiced in the committee process.  First, the joint statement recalls that the political preconditions of the MFA require Ukraine to respect democratic mechanisms, including a multi-party system, the rule of law and human rights under the scrutiny of the Commission and the European External Action Service. Second, the statement makes clear that the fight against corruption will be at the heart of the policy conditions of the memorandum of understanding to be agreed between EU and Ukraine for this MFA operation. Related issues, like money laundering and tax evasion, will also be taken into account for the conditionality of this operation. Specifically, the unmet anti—corruption conditions from the previous MFA operation should be implemented. These conditions were the establishment of the verification system for asset declarations and verification of companies’ beneficial ownership data.  Further MFA assistance will be conditional on progress in setting up a well—functioning anti-corruption court. Importantly, last week the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the law on the high anti—corruption court by 315 votes. That is 88 votes more than needed for a majority. Yesterday, the law was signed by the President of Ukraine. Let me also say that, behind that, Commissioner Hahn and I have raised the issue of abolishing the obligation of e—declarations on anti-corruption activists. This remains an urgent issue to be addressed, just like the reform of the Central Election Commission. We are at a crucial point in time in Ukraine, with the expiry of the IMF programme in March 2019 and presidential and parliamentary elections also looming next year. The window of opportunity for reforms may be closing as the election approaches, so it is important to get this MFA programme up and running in the shortest possible time. If we delay or turn our backs on Ukraine, the risk of reform reversals would be high. So I hope that we will have your full support going forward.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Thank you very much, Madam President, dear Commissioner and dear rapporteur. I am very grateful that we are where we are now. Indeed, Ukraine needs this support and it deserves this support, and it is very appropriate to have this next programme now. As the Commissioner and the rapporteur outlined, we have attached conditions to it, and rightly so, because it is about the people in the country that expect their politicians to deliver, in particular as regards the fight against corruption. This endemic, systemic problem needs to be addressed, and I hope that, by the end of this legislature in March next year, we will see the Court working to address major violations of the rule of law in the area of corruption. As Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), we were perhaps more ambitious than the Committee on International Trade (INTA). We wanted to attach real political conditions, namely the court, the abolition of e—declarations for NGO activists and the reform of the central and the other election commissions. I am grateful to the Commissioner that you – although it is not included in the joint declaration – explicitly referred to that, because that is what it is also about. We need to be very clear in this regard.  I was grateful that the President of the Parliament, when I was in Kyiv on Saturday and we were sitting together on the panel, showed me his fresh signature on this very law. He promised that he would go to the President and see to it that the President initiated the implementing law, which is still required. The Verkhovna Rada should then vote on the implementing law in the following week. We are looking forward to seeing that, and that is what we can expect.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, our decision on the macro-financial assistance to Ukraine is a message of strong continued support for a democratic and European Ukraine. It is a message to the people of Ukraine, to its government and also to Russia. I admire the Ukrainian civil society that has been the driving force behind many reforms in Ukraine. I commend the women and men in Ukraine’s public service who work hard on implementing these reforms. I encourage all the Ukrainian politicians to follow through on their promises to fight and prevent corruption. The Ukrainian people expect it and their patience is wearing thin. Work hard not to repeat the mistakes of the past. I would also like to send a message to Russia that building a democratic, strong and independent Ukraine remains our strategic objective.

name: Aleksander GABELIC
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner Dombrovskis, I would like to thank you for your support. Firstly, I would like to thank my colleagues who have worked on this proposal. Ukraine is an important neighbour. It is therefore of the utmost importance that the EU continues to support its development in the right direction. Especially in times of concern, it is particularly important that we do not give up. We cannot abandon the reformist forces and the important civil society in Ukraine.  Ever since we started working in the European Parliament's Trade Committee, I have been very clear that the Commission cannot expect us to automatically approve its proposal. We must be given time to examine and debate the proposal. We need to do our job as co-legislators. We therefore want to be equally clear today to both the Commission and Ukraine about what is needed for this macro-financial assistance to make a real difference for the better for society as a whole and not just a few.  The agreed conditions for combating corruption must be comprehensive and clear. A special anti-corruption court has just been approved by the Ukrainian Parliament, but now it must be put in place and actually work in practice. The agreed conditions must also promote sustainable and socially responsible development, which creates employment, contributes to greater equality and reduces poverty.  After much discussion in both the Trade and Foreign Affairs Committee, we believe that we have managed to find a good compromise and a strengthened position through a clear and strong joint statement from all three institutions. We now expect the Commission and the Council to continue to fully support our joint statement. We expect the Commission to report on the macro-financial assistance and compliance with the conditions on an ongoing basis. We also expect the Commission to present the Memorandum of Understanding as soon as possible.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I certainly welcome today’s deliberations and the good speed with which we are moving towards the adoption of a new package of macrofinancial assistance to Ukraine. Let me say from the outset: the proposal on the table, as adopted by the leading committee (Committee on International Trade, INTA), is a very balanced step forward. Just to look back a little bit: in my view, the conditions set for the previous MFA package – 21 policy measures in total – were far too many and too complicated. In all fairness, it was also the EU’s mistake that the last MFA instalment to Ukraine was refused even though 17 conditions had been fulfilled. This time we are given proof: Ukraine is able to deliver once it receives clear-cut signals and expectations from our side. Establishment of the High Anti-Corruption Court is with no doubt a very meaningful step in the creation of a future and European Ukraine. I would like to stress very clearly that, even though we are right to expect many more things to be accomplished by Ukraine on its European path, we cannot deny the truth. And the truth is that it is precisely Ukraine which is setting an example for the whole world on how a country which is in a state of war is able to progress with reforms and great transformation. Yes, implementation is that important, but there is always a stage of adoption beforehand. Let me mention just a few more acts of legislation recently approved by the Verkhovna Rada: the law on pension reform, the law on healthcare and the law on education. These are the facts. I wish to conclude by saying that clear-cut responsibilities also remain with us, the EU: the EU’s policies and conditions must be tailored in such a way that eventually help to protect Ukraine’s independence and do not jeopardise the socio-economic life of its people.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In this debate, I would like to thank my colleagues, Mr Rosati, Mr Gahler and Mr Austreviius. We have met again and again over the past year – in Kiev and in Brussels. We met the representatives of the anti-corruption initiatives AntAC and Transparency Ukraine. We have met our colleagues Hrojsman, Klympusch, Maria Ionova, Mr Parubij and many other colleagues from the Verkhovna Rada and have wrestled with steps to combat corruption in Ukraine. The decision to create an anti-corruption court is a decision taken in an actively fought battle for a better future for Ukraine. And I think that this vote in the Verkhovna Rada was really a moment that we should celebrate together. I wish I could raise a glass of champagne here. I know that not everything has been won by this decision. I know that this dispute continues. Mr Dombrovskis' statement and the active commitment of all European ambassadors and the EU embassy and IMF to reform Ukraine together with the Ukrainians – this is promising for a successful reform in Ukraine. That will not end tomorrow. I think we are talking about a process that will go on for an entire generation. The money we are releasing now is not so much compared to other sums that we give to other countries, including within the EU, and that will help the Ukrainians.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Our requests to impose clear conditions on macro-financial assistance to Ukraine directly in the law were rejected by the Commission, the Council and the rapporteur on the grounds that time was running out. However, deciding on such large sums in an urgent procedure does not do justice to the cause or to democracy. It is probably not only my group that suspects that this urgent decision is also a very expensive act of campaign ingenuation for the Poroshenko government at this very moment. I respect, however, that in this situation you were even prepared to accept important demands, including from the left, Mr Dombrovskis. They have made a written commitment that the conditions attached to the payment do not jeopardise social cohesion in Ukrainian society. In addition to economic and fiscal constraints, poverty reduction has now been made a goal for the first time. The European Commission will have to report on the social impact of policies and, I add, on the implementation of these policies and the many laws that have already been mentioned. At the latest here it becomes clear: we are also talking about a political step that goes far beyond the importance of a pre-election situation in Ukraine – even if we are talking about the overdue installation of the anti-corruption court and the fight against endemic corruption. Prove it now in practice! The IMF is calling for energy prices to now be left entirely to market mechanisms. For all households, heating would become forty percent more expensive. Ask Commissioner Hahn: a cold winter is looming and the government fears social unrest. Give the IMF this demand!

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, to start off with, let’s address corruption in Ukraine. The finance minister for Ukraine was dismissed last week. The stated reason for the dismissal was disseminating false information. One has to ask: what was this? Very simply, the now ex—finance minister revealed, exposed, spilt the beans on corruption in Ukraine.  Hopefully, everyone here will agree that we must not condone – let alone be fellow travellers to – corruption. Indeed, we must actively oppose it. Transparency International is a globally respected organisation, especially on anti-corruption. On its criteria, Ukraine is categorised as the second most corrupt country on the entire European continent. To put it another way: Ukraine rates even worse for corruption than the gangster—influenced regimes of Albania and Kosovo. Ukraine has delayed and delayed over and over again the establishment of an anti-corruption court. Vote or no vote, let us see how long it is before the president implements that vote. Worse, campaigners against corruption have been intimidated and, in some cases, imprisoned. To provide an example: on 15 March this year, one Nadia Savchenko testified on the corruption in the office of the President of Ukraine. One week later, Ms Savchenko was placed under arrest and charged with terrorism offenses. The same president had previously awarded Ms Savchenko Ukraine’s highest honour for bravery against terrorists.  These practices must be deemed to be unacceptable. Every informed person – and that has to include the EU embassy in Ukraine, and therefore the Commissioner – knows about the appalling level of corruption in Ukraine. The sacking of the finance minister last week for opposing corruption should have caused the alarm bells to ring. Instead, the considered response of the Ukraine groupies in the Commission and, regrettably, in this Parliament (and there are many honourable exceptions) is simply to hand out to Ukraine – without question, without adequate audits, and without enough consideration – these very large sums of money, all paid for by the taxpayer. What we are discussing this evening with such rapidity is over EUR 1 billion. By comparison, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is holding back on its assistance programmes to Ukraine, precisely because of well—founded concerns on corruption. On the objective criteria of the IMF, Ukraine does not pass muster as a worthy recipient of large—scale funds. The EU should follow the same course as the IMF: these payments should not be made. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: blue-card question. – Could you name one other single country which gets macrofinancial assistance, is fighting corruption and has created independent institutions such as a national anti—corruption office and is preparing its own high anti—corruption court? And could you please also tell me what, in London, you are supporting as measures in the city against the international money—laundering systems?

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card answer. – I’ll just deal with Ukraine, and not the City of London. What Ukraine is doing is too little, too late – it’s not enough. These funds should be held back. I would point you again – if I may presume to do so – to the example of the IMF: that is the view that the IMF has taken. I strongly recommend that the EU and the Commission do the self—same thing. And thank you very much for your interruption.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, yes, you are right Mr Dartmouth! The situation in Ukraine, ladies and gentlemen, is getting worse by the day. The Donbass war, corruption - Ukraine ranks 131st out of 176 countries in the world in terms of corruption - denial of democracy, press freedom flouted, crime on the rise, including up to the top of the state; and let us remember the Babchenko case. No, the Kiev regime, Ma'am, is making no effort and you know it! We see this umpteenth macro-financial assistance as an expression of a fierce desire on the part of Brussels to maintain tensions with Russia. But beyond this form of Commission interventionism towards Ukraine, I denounce here the Commission's intention to take advantage of the situation to increase its powers and thus reduce the role of our Parliament to that of a mere registration chamber. Finally, Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, these large sums of money would be much better used to support our farmers who have been held hostage since 2014 as a result of the sanctions against Russia, which are now paying the high price for ubuesque and disastrous political choices to which we are firmly opposed.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would call on this House to approve the macrofinancial assistance for Ukraine tomorrow. Ukraine has made a lot of effort and has taken a lot of important steps in order to fight corruption. I very much share the concerns that have been raised by a number of colleagues here. This is not work which has been completed; this is a work in progress. But the progress has been substantial. Just a few days ago, Ukraine established an independent anti-corruption court, which had been the key pre-condition for the release of macrofinancial assistance.  Of course, there is still a lot to be done. We want Ukraine to exempt NGOs from the e—declaration obligation, and this has been promised and is under execution. We want anti—corruption court legislation to be implemented by the president, and we have had a promise that it will be done as soon as possible – within the next few days. If we don’t take the decision right now, the whole thing may be postponed by several months. So I would kindly request colleagues to support this motion and open this possibility of financing to Ukraine.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Madam Chairman, I thank the rapporteurs for their positions presented and for all those who negotiated the text of the joint declaration. In the spring of 2014, Ukraine began implementing a reform programme to stabilise the economy and improve the living conditions of citizens. Ukraine and the Union have jointly set out a reform programme, data on previous payments are known, as well as problems with the disbursement of the last round of aid due to non-compliance with all criteria. This includes anti-corruption reforms and transparent spending of allocated money. These conditions are justified, but it is necessary to welcome the results achieved in the unchanged difficult political situation in Ukraine, which seems to be sinking on the list of foreign policy priorities due to the emergence of some new crises. I welcome the adoption of the Law on Anti-Corruption Court as an important step forward in the required reforms for the benefit of the citizens of Ukraine, so tomorrow we should vote without the need to upgrade the adopted text with additional elements, which would open interinstitutional processes and further delay the payment. However, I also support the continued monitoring of the implementation of reforms, in particular when it comes to meeting the conditions related to past and future macro-financial assistance programmes. It is about strengthening an independent judiciary, capable of effectively fighting corruption and ensuring respect for human rights, which should be the content of a special memorandum of understanding with Ukraine.  Macro-financial assistance would help economic stabilisation and structural reforms in Ukraine, our important neighbour, which is why I support the new payment.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am an international terrorist. Of course I am not really, I am for the Poroshenko regime, which accused me of international terrorism for going to Donbass together with the anti-fascist caravan to bring solidarity and basic necessities to the populations who are suffering a war.  I was really surprised that this Parliament is considering supporting this fourth tranche, because we are talking about a not only corrupt government, a government supported by neo-Nazi forces, a government that denies the most basic human rights, that kills journalists, and we are supporting a coup d'état, like that of Euromaidan, simply because it is pro-European Union. We are supporting a government that violates human rights, violates the Minsk agreements.  I believe that, if we really want to build an anti-fascist Europe, we should stop funding regimes such as Poroshenko's and instead support political works and actions such as those of the anti-fascist caravans, which I personally thank.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, I support macroeconomic assistance, and I am glad that we are going to extend our help to Ukraine. This assistance should help Ukraine to balance part of its external financing needs for late 2018 and early 2019. It is therefore important that we could agree on sending the assistance at the right time. This, however, does not mean that Ukraine has already finished with the reform agenda. We should closely follow developments and, if necessary, put pressure on the Ukraine authorities to timely implement the agreed reforms.  I think that Ukraine has made progress in its transition from an oligarchic to a more Western, liberal, democratic system. Those of us who come from behind the Iron Curtain know that there is no easy way to do it. Ukraine has enormous potential to modernise and become a leader in the reforms. It is in our interests to support it in this difficult transition.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Despite Russia's continued aggression against Ukraine, last week a difficult phase was reached. The Ukrainian Parliament has adopted a law establishing an anti-corruption Court. This is a very important and long-awaited solution. The Ukrainian State fulfils its obligations, and it has to act in very difficult conditions, with almost daily deaths of soldiers and civilians, when part of the territory of the state, Crimea is occupied. We can welcome the fact that we and Ukraine have association and free trade agreements and visa-free travel. On the other hand, there are many necessary reforms that Ukraine must implement. The situation is complex and our assessments must be extremely objective. I therefore support the Commission's proposal to provide new macro-financial assistance of one billion euro to Ukraine. This financial support will help Ukraine to move forward, carry out the necessary reforms, stabilise the economy and carry out structural reforms.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Eastern Partnership countries expect us, firstly, to be interested, secondly, in the financial means of support, but thirdly, of sharing their own experiences, their practice. It is a good idea to set the conditions for Ukraine, first of all, so that the funds – in short – are not wasted. However, if we set conditions, set certain thresholds, make suggestions for specific solutions, then the measures that we have promised, in the end, should go to this Ukraine. We should remember that the eastern border of the European Parliament of the European Union is Ukraine, Belarus, and Moldova. It is also the interest of these countries in their economic condition, their political condition, their socio-political situation. Let us be patient all the time, on the one hand, and consistent on the other, but let us remember that without this assistance Ukraine will only be condemned to contacts with the East.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, macrofinancial assistance (MFA) is important for Ukraine, not only to cover its additional financial needs, but also to provide incentives for speeding up the nation’s reform efforts. We now look forward to the signing of the Memorandum of Understanding next month. The EU is standing, and continues to stand, with the Ukrainian nation and Government. By adopting last Thursday the benchmark law on a special independent court for addressing corruption, a significant step was made. However, the eternally crucial issue remains: that of the implementation. We expect an informal but radical and determined effort by the rule of law establishment to enter into the space of shady business and to take accountability of all those who distort law and justice in their own or in their group’s interests. At the same time, Putin’s regime will do everything to compromise the newly opened path to transparency justice. Only by taking real control of corruption can Russian aggression and intervention be credibly depleted.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, EU macrofinancial assistance should, of course, support Ukraine’s commitment to values shared with the Union, including democracy, the rule of law, good governance, respect for human rights, sustainable development and poverty reduction. As we know, this step change requires a strong civil society. So, as a long-standing friend of Ukraine, I wish to put on record that one of the things we must do is to guard against the continuation of an old boys’ club. The women and youth of Ukraine are immensely talented: full of ideas and energy, and ready to step up to make the changes that are required in a 21st—century modern democracy. But such a transformation requires men to step aside and to understand that, when women take a seat at the table, everyone wins.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – It was like the procession of Echternach, but after two years of resistance, Ukraine finally gets an anti-corruption court. This is the necessary capstone in the fight against the endemic scourge of corruption and a necessary condition for new European macro-financial assistance, which we fully support. The people and civil society in Ukraine support this fight against corruption. The Ukrainian people made very heavy sacrifices during the Euromaidan revolution. That is why I am still surprised that Kiev, with the current leaders at the wheel, so often is the accelerator and pulls the handbrake at the same time. In this way, reforms too often falter, water them down and the fight against corruption has so far failed to convince. The establishment of the anti-corruption court, with independent judges, is a step in the right direction. We must follow up on the implementation of the implementation, as well as the whole reform agenda. It will also, for example, lead to a more modern and democratic electoral law and an operational rule of law.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! We are debating macroeconomic assistance to Ukraine today. And there is no doubt that without the support of the Union, this country will not be able to cope with the reforms. However, as Chairman of the Committee on Agriculture, I cannot help but address the ukrainian abuses that occur under the fta, as I have been alerted to by EU poultry producers. These are imports of certain parts of the chicken which do not fall within the terms set out in the trade agreement. As a result, Ukrainian importers circumvent the provisions of the Agreement and the quotas established there for sensitive and duty-free products import large quantities of non-standard poultry products into the Union which, after minor processing within the Union, are sold as traditional products.
