Given the much lower production costs, lower standards in Ukraine, this import seriously threatens the EU poultry industry. The European Commission has recently informed us that it is aware of the case and is trying to remedy it, but we have concerns about whether EU producers will survive until this issue is settled.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to start by saying that Ukraine is a bit of our black conscience. Let us recall the Budapest Memorandum concluded in 1994, which guaranteed, under the auspices of, for example, great Britain, the USA, territorial sovereignty and the independence of Ukraine. Since we could not help Ukraine militarily, we must at least help ukraine with financial instruments and other assistance.  The independent anti-corruption court, which was set up a few days ago, is proof that Ukraine is advancing reforms after all, although the process should undoubtedly be more vigorous. Everything needs to be done, it is not only about reforms, of course, but also about the issues of people who play a role.  I see progress in Ukraine, although I, too, would welcome a more vigorous approach. I think that Ukraine needs our help and I am happy to support this motion for a resolution.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank you for the rich debate and for the support expressed to the Commission’s proposal to grant further macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. The Commission shares many of the concerns expressed here today about Ukraine and its reform path. Ukraine has made a lot of progress, but progress has also been uneven across areas, and a lot remains to be done in order to make reforms irreversible. This is precisely why the MFA is so important. It is an instrument for the EU to support reform-minded forces in Ukraine and to continue to exercise EU leverage so that the still strong vested interests can be overcome.  As I said during my opening remarks, if we turn our back on Ukraine, the risk of reform reversals could be high, and a lot of the achievements that Ukraine has without doubt made since 2014 would be at risk. Our message to Ukraine through this decision and the joint statement is crystal clear: solidarity goes hand in hand with a call for taking forward the reform drive with renewed vigour. One cannot go without the other. The EU committed to stand with the people of Ukraine. We cannot let Ukraine down and we cannot allow Ukraine to fail. Therefore, I count on your support tomorrow for the decision to grant further macro-financial assistance to Ukraine without further amendments.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Madam President, on behalf of our rapporteur, Jarosław Wałęsa, who is absent today for family reasons, I would like to thank all colleagues who participated in the debate tonight and also to thank Commissioner Dombrovskis for his statement on behalf of the Commission and for his work.  We will be voting on this file tomorrow, and I hope that Parliament will express its strong support and will give its consent to further macro-financial assistance to Ukraine.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 March 2008. Adopted on 16 June 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Artis PABRIKS
text: Writing. – I believe that the European Commission's proposal to grant Ukraine macro-financial assistance to reduce Ukraine's current financial vulnerability is unequivocally welcome. Moreover, this loan of EUR 1 billion is granted under strict conditional conditions and is directly dependent on the implementation of reforms in Ukraine, which includes, inter alia, the reduction of corruption and the creation of a special anti-corruption court, thereby providing Ukraine with irreplaceable support towards the country's economic and democratic stability. Latvia has always supported Ukraine, because the stabilisation of south-east Europe also contributes to Latvia's security, so it is also in our country's strategic interest. Unfortunately, yesterday, the talks of the Normandy Group in Berlin, attended by the Ministers of Germany, France, Russia and Ukraine, to talk about a possible peace process in Ukraine, did not make 100 000 000 000 000 000 000 000 000 000 000 000 000 000 000 000 000 00 00 00 00 00 00 0 However, even if the Minsk Agreement were to be respected, it would not bring immediate stability. The European Union must therefore continue to support Ukraine not only financially, but also , which is no less important, politically. Under no circumstances can we give up, and we must be aware that there is still a long way to go before the situation is resolved.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the debate on the report on cyber defence 2018/2004(INI) (A8-0189/2018) by Urmas Paet, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, dear colleagues, cybersecurity has fast become an indivisible part of global affairs. Cybersecurity threats are real, they can be very damaging and may bring about lethal consequences. One can only imagine the effects of a successful cyber-attack on a nuclear plant, on an air traffic control facility or on a hospital. EU Member States are often subject to cyber—attacks by either state or non-state actors for political, economic or security purposes, including attacks on critical infrastructure, cyber—espionage and disinformation campaigns. Therefore, urgent reinforcement and development of European offensive and defensive capabilities is needed. We need to build up and improve our cyber—deterrents and defence if we are to truly modernise European defence. While cyber—defence remains the core competence of the Member States, nevertheless, due to the borderless nature of cyberspace, it is not possible for any one state alone to tackle the threats and challenges. Member States must cooperate closely and this is where the EU can be of help. The EU can provide a platform for European cooperation and ensure that the new endeavours are closely coordinated at an international level and within the transatlantic security architecture. As we have all seen, with the development of the European defence policy over the last few years, so too has the cyber—defence domain been developing. PESCO and the European Defence Fund are the latest initiatives with the necessary scope to facilitate co-operative projects in the cyber domain.  We have a huge deficit of cyber—defence specialists. While there are already some initiatives in this field that need continued support, like the Military Erasmus programme and some others, we see the need to do more.  It is important to increase the availability of virtual cyber—defence training. We need to create wide-ranging technical platforms and establish a community of EU experts to develop a platform to facilitate the pooling and sharing of training and exercises.  In 2016, at the NATO Summit cyberspace was recognised as an operational domain, together with land, air and sea. This was a big step at the time. We need to broaden cooperation with NATO in cyber—defence by increasing operational cooperation and coordination and expanding capacity-building efforts, intensifying joint training for staff, building trust and conducting joint exercises. Like-minded strategic partners should also be taken into account.  As regards international norms and rules, I am glad that the UN Group of Governmental Experts would agree on some of the concepts concerning cyberspace. It was agreed that international law applies and should be enforced in cyberspace. However, it is necessary for the EU to assume a leading role in the ongoing and future debates on international norms in cyberspace.  On civilian-military cooperation, again trust is a key issue. This needs to be developed further between companies and defence and civilian end-users. Also, private companies have a great role in preventing, detecting, containing and responding to cyber—security incidents, as well as in stimulating innovation. It is therefore also imperative that there is more cooperation with the private sector.  So in conclusion, we need to continuously update European cyber—defence capabilities. We need more cooperation at the level of Member States, the EU, NATO and other like-minded countries by building trust, training more experts, having more joint exercises and improving accountability. The next attack might create far more damage than we have seen so far.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you on behalf of the Commission and the High Representative. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Paet, for today’s report and the light he is shining on this very important subject. In recent years, as he said, the cyber—threat landscape has changed dramatically, underlining the need for a strategic approach to cyber—threats and challenges. That includes the need to look at the defence dimension.  The best way we have to face such a rapidly evolving series of challenges is to join forces and to mobilise all the resources we have. To protect our cyberspace we need better capabilities, more research, more training and exercises on how to respond to eventual attacks, and in the last few months and years I’m glad to say we have joined forces across the institutions – the European Commission and Member States, the External Action Service and the European Defence Agency – all in close coordination with our partners at NATO.  The report we are discussing today provides an excellent strategic vision and puts forward a series of very realistic recommendations. The report will help further reinforce our ongoing efforts to support Member States’ capability development for cyber—defence and deterrence. Cyber—defence of CSDP missions and operations, cyber—defence education and training, international norms applicable to cyberspace, civil military cooperation, public—private partnerships and EU NATO cyber—cooperation.  We are working to build the EU’s resilience to cyber—attacks, provide for better defence capabilities and to build a credible cyber—deterrence. Indeed, these were the key elements of the Commission’s cyber package brought forward in September last year.  In taking this work forward, we need to remember that most cyber—infrastructure is in civilian hands, so an important part of strengthening our cyber—resilience – making ourselves harder to attack – involves strengthening civil cooperation, which is why we proposed transforming ENISA into an EU cybersecurity agency and developing an EU—wide certification framework for cybersecurity. We also need to send a clear message to those who wish to cause us harm, and in this regard we welcome the reference in the report to Europol’s role in coordinating the law enforcement response to cyber—threats. I’d also like to draw your attention to the recent Commission proposals for facilitating access to e—evidence.  But we also identified the need to further invest in the development of dual use cyber—technologies and cyber—skills. Earlier this year, the European Defence Agency, led by the High Representative, set up an EU cyber—defence, education and training exercise evaluation platform. It will help advance training and educational opportunities within the Member States to cover the full range of cyber—defence training. This initiative will also bring together civilian and military training needs. The EAS and the European Defence Agency have in fact been engaged with Member States for some years now to develop capabilities for cyber—defence. In March this year, they conducted a survey of the Member States on their cyber—defence requirements in order to update the EU cyber—defence policy framework. That survey showed that some Member States are already very advanced in terms of structures and doctrine and that all of our Member States have at least minimum cyber—protection capabilities in place and are building their national cyber—defence systems.  We’ve identified several areas where the EU could support these efforts further, such as investment in research and technology, providing training and education opportunities and facilitating civil—military cooperation. The funding through the European Defence Fund should be focused on delivering these capability priorities. Some Member States, as has been mentioned, have also agreed to invest together in cybersecurity through the new permanent structured cooperation on defence. Member States have set up to cyber—related PESCO projects. One of them focuses on the sharing of cyber—threat intelligence through a network platform with the objective to strengthen national cyber—defence capabilities, the second aims to set up cyber rapid response teams to respond together to cyber—attacks. In order to strengthen cyber—deterrence, we continue to step up EU response to malicious cyber—activities and incursive cyber—operations in the framework for a joint EU diplomatic response to malicious cyber—activities. This sets out several EU measures to prevent and respond to cyber—attacks by state and non—state actors. Mr Paet’s report also highlights the role of international law and cyber norms in cyberspace. In this respect, we work closely with Member States to develop a strategic framework for conflict prevention and cyber—stability, promoting adherence to existing international law and implementation of cyber—norms and confidence—building measures are, and will remain, a centrepiece of our efforts.  Finally, we are working to deepen EU—NATO cooperation on cyber—defence, including against hybrid threats. You were talking about EU—NATO cooperation earlier today. We will continue to foster interoperability through coherent cyber—defence requirements and standards, to strengthen cooperation on training exercises, to harmonise training requirements and to mainstream cyber aspects into crisis management.  The report also makes some recommendations on institutional reinforcement, such as developing cyber aspects further in a white book for security and defence, to invest more in cyber—defence in the next MFF, to strengthen the EU Intelligence and Situation Centre and set up a new cyber—defence council.  I want to assure the rapporteur that we will consider all of these ideas very closely. Further investment in cyber—defence has already been highlighted in the current discussions on the next MFF. In conclusion, we’ve made considerable progress in the past few years on this range of issues connected to cyber—defence. We will continue to work to strengthen Member States’ capabilities and reinforce civ—mil synergies. We will continue to strengthen deterrence by bolstering our resilience and stepping up diplomatic responses to cyber—attacks. Thank you again for focusing on this issue and I look forward to our discussion.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Urmas Paet, who has done some wonderful work.  Let's be clear, today's world is very different from yesterday's, it's more dynamic, it has an accelerated pace. So are threats, which are multiple and constantly changing. We can't be naive. The citizens of the Union demand that the Union protect them; a Union that strives to maintain an open, free and secure cyberspace.  It is clear that with the digitisation of our economies and societies we are exposed to many more threats, and these attacks have the potential to alter the daily lives of European citizens, as we have already seen too often.  Strengthening cooperation and coordination in the so-called "fifth domain of war" – cyberspace – is of paramount importance. Cyber defense can and should be cooperative, as its operational scope has no borders, national or organizational, and joint work resolves inefficiencies and confers credibility. I am proud that, over the past twenty-five years, my party, the European People's Party, has been a leader in security and defence policies. I am glad that the other political forces are now joining our concerns.  I am grateful for the support for this viable and realistic institutional effort which I have proposed, which is reflected in the figure of a european Union cyber authority, an authority that will coordinate operations, build trust between States, serve as a liaison point between member states' cyber authorities and working closely with NATO.  I stress that we European citizens demand a Union to protect us, and this report, which we will adopt tomorrow, is a response to this demand with real and tangible proposals that will help to achieve a safer Europe.

name: Clare MOODY
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I wish to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report. It has been a pleasure to work with him and the other shadows on this serious issue. The report recognises that cybersecurity and the defence of Europe’s cyberspace is one of the most important challenges that we face now. It also emphasises that there needs to be an integrated policy response with cooperation between civilian, security and military stakeholders.  The threats we face are multiple, coming from individuals, criminal gangs and states. In the UK last year our health service was severely affected by a cyber—attack launched by North Korea. That was not the only state—sponsored attack which the EU has suffered. It is essential that Europe stand united against attacks such as WannaCry and NotPetya.  Cyber—attacks, whatever their source, do not respect national boundaries, making it all the more important to work together at an EU level. In the same week that the new European Defence Fund is launched, we want to see more invested in Europe’s ability to defend itself. As the report makes clear, there needs to be more investment in cyber—expertise, emphasising the need for more experts in the cyber—defence domain and the facilitation of cooperation between existing experts. We also need to develop our capabilities to ensure better attribution of cyber—attacks, enabling a stronger coordinated response to those specific attacks that impact all of us across Europe. The EU should also fulfil the role it plays so well in other areas: namely, leading the development of international laws and standards in this field. Our job as parliamentarians is to build a safer, more secure, EU. I believe the recommendations in this report are fundamental to delivering that safety and security to our citizens.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, in the rapidly-growing digital world, Urmas Paet’s report helps us in understanding the complexity of cyber-threats in peace and war and the somewhat blurred border between both at a time of hybrid threats, because ‘cyber’ is part of this – also in the division between civilians and the military and between private and public. We have to understand that many times, the targets of cyber-attacks are civilian institutions and civilian infrastructure. Therefore we need an international legal system tackling ‘cyber’ and also an international humanitarian system referring to ‘cyber’ if we consider the cyber-domain as an operational domain, as defined by NATO. I welcome this report, but I stress once more the necessity to cooperate between like—minded countries and societies, because the problem is so complex. I welcome cooperation between the EU and NATO. Quite rightly, cyber is the flagship of this cooperation, starting from the Declaration at the Warsaw NATO Summit.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the challenge to ensure safety and security involves more and more technological components. We see attacks on critical infrastructure, electoral systems, and really matters of democracy and peace at stake. With this global phenomenon, it only makes sense that we engage in the defence of the global open internet and all its users at EU level, as an integral part of our foreign and defence policies. We must certainly avoid fragmentation of steps taken between Member States. We need resilience of our networks, safety of devices, but also ways to attribute attacks when they do take place. This does not happen often enough, and if the rule of law should have meaning online there must be consequences to attacks.  Let’s also look at ourselves. The cybersecurity of the internet of things, the use of software vulnerabilities, and the Commissioner mentioned the development of dual use technologies, but we are still exporting harmful ones to dictatorships and that cannot help our cybersecurity. The EU should lead on the basis of values and aspire to achieve global norms here too.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, new communication technologies have shown their dark side, using hackers who are able to enter the systems of competitors, companies or institutions to spy on or sabotage them. It has also revealed the vulnerability of users of communication networks and social networks by powerful intelligence companies or that transform our data into business. Recent examples include Facebook cases or intelligence agencies, such as the NSA, that steal and accumulate zero-day vulnerabilities, keeping them secret. This report does not protect vulnerable citizens, network users, powerful companies or intelligence agencies that steal our data for control or business. The GUE/NGL Group will vote against this report because it supports a single market for cybersecurity, promoting synergies between civilian and military markets; because it urges Member States to use the framework provided for by permanent structured cooperation or the European Defence Fund; because it supports the cooperation of the European Union and NATO for computer defence; because it supports security policies and restrictions on the rights and freedoms of citizens of the Member States of the European Union, or because it advocates, for cyber defence, the use of some instruments of the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, Commissioner King’s presence here is very much welcomed. Essentially, cyberspace comes down to trust and cooperation. Since the very beginning of debates on cyber issues we have been calling for deeper and wider cooperation among Member States and among the EU Institutions. Furthermore, cybersecurity and cyber—defence have been mainstreamed into common foreign and security policy. We have been calling on this continuously and we call on it again. EU—NATO cyber—cooperation is crucial. A prime practical example of that cooperation was last year’s strategic high—level exercise in Estonia with the participation of the NATO Secretary—General. Lastly, may I make a personal call on cyber—hygiene. Everything comes down to the individual user. Cyber—hygiene is essential in every domain by people who deal with critical infrastructure and information, yet we do not even have cybersecurity training for European Parliament staff, not to mention students in schools.  Let me congratulate colleague Paet for continuing this work and for proving himself a true liberal by accepting practically all the amendments to this report.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The citizens of the Union expect the Union to take much greater responsibility for common security. And this is reflected in the whole series of actions that have been undertaken in recent times. It is worth recalling here the creation of PESCO. It is worth recalling the establishment of the Defence Fund, but also of the fact that the 2021-2027 plans foresee as much as €32 billion for common security. This is an increase of 28%. It seems to me that it is in these higher amounts that we also have the opportunity to find much more resources for cyber defence, because today these are the threats we face every day. But after all, it is easy to predict that there will be more and more of these threats. Therefore, more money must also be spent on cybersecurity.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In some ways, cyberwar is already underway. I would like to draw attention to this because, also looking at these amendments – 338, as far as I can remember – there are also proposals for records that are not very favourable to the fight against cyber-attacks. The discussion also shows how much different interests are inscribed in this IT space, so that cybersecurity is not fully ensured in the legislative processes as well. It worries me. But I would like to stress that all the elements that have been included in the Commissioner's speech are so well built that I will be happy to sign them. It is important not to waste time. It is important not to waste money. It is also important not to underestimate the signals that are currently coming primarily from private business regarding surveillance, data security threats, as well as an imminent military threat.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the President-in-House for the work she has done Cybersecurity cannot be tackled successfully nationally, but only at European level. If we want to make cyberspace safe for our citizens, the Member States must show even more willingness to cooperate. I therefore welcome the recently extended mandate for the European Network and Information Security Agency (ENISA). Especially when it comes to cybersecurity, the line between military and civilian is often fluid. It affects not only public institutions such as ministries and parliaments, as well as the military, but also civilian institutions such as municipal utilities and the private sector. We therefore need a broader, cross-departmental discussion on cybersecurity beyond this report. This issue can not only be covered in the field of defence policy, but also, above all, in internal, economic and judicial policy. The EU's foreign policy discourse and agenda must also be more closely anchored in cyber diplomacy. The EU should be a driving force for the development of international standards for cyberspace.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, the Warsaw Declaration of the 2016 NATO Summit recognised cyberspace as an operational area in which NATO must defend itself as effectively as it defends itself in the air, on land and at sea.  Cyberspace knows no borders, hostile attacks can be political, security or economic. These are attacks on vital infrastructure, cyber espionage, mass surveillance of EU citizens, disinformation campaigns, the spread of malicious software, restrictions on internet access and the functioning of the IT system.  In its 2017 report, the European Cybersecurity Agency says there is unwavering evidence of attacks on democracy and cyber warfare. These activities threaten our security, public order, democracy and our strategic autonomy. The response to serious incidents should always be a joint EU response, including restrictive measures.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the digital revolution has made our lives easier but has exposed us to new threats, such as cybercrime, cyber terrorism and cyberattacks, sometimes even from states. In view of the serious risks associated with potential cyberspace attacks, although Member States remain responsible for national security, the European Union must develop a common and comprehensive cyber defence policy.  With this in mind, Europol's Cybercrime Centre will have to be strengthened to become a focal point for the exchange of information between government cybercrime agencies, as well as for providing assistance to Member States. The Commission will also have to work to strengthen public-private partnerships, to create synergies and innovative solutions between civil and military markets and to strengthen cyber defence through international cooperation and with NATO for more effective defence against our countries.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Madam President, while the powers in cyber defence fall within the Member States, there needs to be cooperation and coordination between them all. Progress must be recognised through the European Defence Agency and the new permanent structured cooperation (ECE). However, cooperation between partners is still far from organised. European structures, from Europol's EC3 to the Computer Emergency Response Team, to ENISA, which is still weak, lack a robust cooperation system and need significant improvements. European Union-NATO cooperation is essential. Shared efforts and knowledge are needed to neutralize attacks—4,000 daily in 2016. A substantial improvement in cyberdefensing capabilities would have an impact on the Union's autonomy, which is fundamental to the 2016 Global Security Strategy. In addition, it would reduce reliance on our international partners, as is the case in the United States.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, both the Commission and other EU bodies and Parliament have done a very good job and plans to improve cybersecurity, but – I am afraid – more than today and yesterday' s threats. Considering that information technology develops exponentially, i.e. by about five or ten odds, and actually comes to all aspects of our lives, information society management, big data, people's personal data, health information, self-driving cars and other transport, etc. it is a question of how we can anticipate potential future threats without, however, combating this technology, and how we can also be better prepared, both by means of double systems – parallel systems – and also by security programmes. To this end, I believe that the European Union would need a very large and good cybersecurity centre with both research and foresight.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the internet should be a force for good: a common space that promotes quality education and inspired learning, better communication, creativity and intercultural dialogue. The internet should support fair and sustainable trade and uphold human rights, and it should most definitely not be prey to those wishing to hijack democracy, such as was evidenced by the Cambridge Analytica, AIG and Facebook scandals that were behind the Trump and Brexit campaigns and the Kenyan presidential election in August 2017, which was subsequently annulled by the Supreme Court. One way to improve cyber—defence is to improve internet governance, and the annual Internet Governance Forum (IGF) is an excellent example of multi—stakeholder engagement in a pressing issue that concerns us all. I’d like to particularly commend the work of the Youth IGF, a network of young people in developed and less—developed countries who are active in their local communities and in the online space.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, defence against cyber attacks is indeed a major challenge in modern times. I would like to bring to the attention of the Commission and Mr King the cyber attacks that are currently being carried out by Turkish hackers on various websites of Greek public services as well as companies.  Between 30 April and 2 May there were cyberattacks by Turkish hackers first of all on the Athens News Agency, in addition to a newspaper in Crete, also in the Handball Federation, attacks accompanied by threats, in which Turkish hackers say, among other things: "Greece quickly forgets. We threw your ancestors into the sea. We'll do it again!" This is an unacceptable situation and I would like him to be condemned by you, Mr King.

name: Nadja HIRSCH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Last week there were massive disruptions at Hamburg Airport due to a power outage. It was not a cyber-attack, but just a normal short circuit. But I think such an incident shows very clearly how vulnerable our critical infrastructure is. In recent years, we have seen more and more cyber attacks from Russia, China, North Korea or even from transnational actors. Cyber espionage, disinformation campaigns or even extortion software, ransomware, have become part of our everyday life. The open borders of the Internet make it impossible for states to separate themselves. That is why it is all the more important for the Member States of the European Union to work together. That is why we now need to set up an EU cyber response service and bring coordination much closer together. Cyberdefence must play a very central role in the construction of the European Defence Union from the outset. This is extremely important for us.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Madam President, I am very happy that the EU is working to strengthen its cybersecurity rules in order to address the growing threats. 86% of Europeans believe that the risk of cybercrime is increasing, which is why it is necessary to address this issue and bring solutions.  We need to have an operational plan to respond to large-scale cyber attacks, to defend European societies and, above all, our citizens. In this context, we must also not forget about the education of the population. Risk reduction through sufficient threat awareness is a prevention method that pays off for all Member States. Only an educated population will also have a better understanding of the challenges associated with the cyber threat.  Here, too, if we do not solve the problem comprehensively, it can have a negative impact on our security.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, cyber attacks are one of the greatest modern threats even against the very support of a state. This issue must therefore be treated with particular attention. Every state must be able to protect its cyberspace and, in order to achieve this, it must have the necessary capabilities. It must first create appropriate infrastructure and invest in high and modern technology. In addition, there must be cooperation at the level of the State, the European Union and NATO. Experts should also be set up, information exchanged, joint exercises carried out and ongoing research carried out. For cyber defence, due to its military and civilian nature, cooperation between the military and the private body must be achieved. Finally, the European Union must play a coordinating role in all this effort.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank honourable Members for this report and this debate. I agree that this is a very important subject and it is timely that we review the steps that we have taken and the work that is still required. We will continue our work to build our cyber—resilience and cyber—deterrence, as well as to reinforce international cooperation and defence cooperation. The EU institutions together will work with the Member States, with partners and with international organisations, notably NATO, as many of you have underlined. We will work to bring together the civilian and the military dimensions of this challenge and the public and the private dimensions of this challenge. We need to develop our capabilities, and we need to continue to drive and focus our research and development to reinforce our cyber—security. A number of you mentioned other detailed points that we can look at. Overall, I want to say how much we share the thrust of this report. We need to be ready. We need to meet the cyber and cyber—enabled threats that we face because that is indeed what our citizens expect.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I wish to thank everyone for all the comments and feedback we have heard and, of course, I especially thank all the shadow rapporteurs for the very efficient and effective cooperation we had preparing this report.  We have a responsibility at all levels to increase the security of our citizens, and this means also increasing cyber—defence at Member State level, as well as that of the EU, NATO and like—minded countries. I want to stress that I believe it is imperative that top—level exercises are also held every now and then to bring the matter closer to the leaders of our countries to make them realise the problem is not going away. Each and every country must do their utmost, each on their own, but of course also together.  Thank you very much, and I really hope that tomorrow during the vote we can have the result which is long awaited by our citizens from our Member States.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 March 2008. Adopted on 16 June 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. – In our globally networked world, we enjoy many advantages thanks to modern technical possibilities, and many things are made easier for us. Unfortunately, the shift to a digital society also involves dangers and threats. Finding these appropriate answers and developing appropriate responses is part of our political responsibility. Cyber threats are a threat and are becoming more and more present. For me, the protection of critical energy infrastructure from attacks from the Internet is particularly important – an area that has only recently received more attention and in whose protection one cannot invest enough. Energy infrastructure provides an essential service, because it is only through it that the functioning of a flawless modern society and economy is ensured. It is precisely in this area that a cyberattack can have particularly devastating and frightening effects. If there were a cyber attack on our energy supply, we would not be in this room, we would not be in Strasbourg, we would probably be locked up in our homes. Lamps, mobile phones, refrigerators, our water supply, petrol stations and much more – nothing would work anymore. That is why the debate on an EU response to so-called cyberthreats is also an important one. It should be conducted in detail, with the appropriate seriousness and the necessary pragmatism.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I want to congratulate Mr Paet on the report. This report clearly shows that cyber security has to be the top priority in the EU because it covers many areas like trade, services, and most importantly security and defence matters of the Member States. The report acknowledges the importance of coordination between Member States, which has been already emphasised in the NIS Directive. Cyber security is a cross—border matter and alone we cannot protect ourselves to the maximum level. That is also why the role of the European Defence Agency, European Union Agency for Network and Information Security (ENISA) is important. The EU agencies have to enhance Member States to help them not only to fight cyber-attacks, but most importantly to increase cyber resilience.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted on 12Thrably 2018 on a motion for a resolution on cyber defence: a good initiative (in theory...) that is legally in line with the European Union's cyber defence policy framework of 18 November 2014 and the resolution on combating cybercrime on 3 October 2017.  We welcomed the fact that Brussels takes seriously the threat of cyber attacks, the number of incidents and threats both economic and terrorist. Unfortunately, cyber defence is like a lock whose keys should not be distributed. If each Member State has its own system, it is all the more complicated to attack. On the other hand, the uniformity or coordination of systems makes them vulnerable: it is enough to find a key to bring down the whole system.  In the same vein, the constant evolution of these techniques requires a great reactivity, impossible to implement in 27 Member States: we are witnessing this... Moreover, as this cyber defence, incorporating military dimensions and cyberspace, is increasingly regarded as the "fifth domain of war", France must maintain its independence in this particularly sensitive sector.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. Cyberdefense. One of the most current issues on the political agenda of security and defence, put on the agenda by the European Union, conniving and subservient to NATO's strategy and its war and aggression agenda. Now they seek to legitimize and regulate another front of war that completes the Digital Single Market. It is, strictly speaking, of increasing and expanding the capacity for scrutiny, control and criminalisation in cyberspace, outside judicial scrutiny, on the pretext of alleged threats, but creating capacities to intervene also on third countries, complementing the internal destabilisation strategy that they already play in several countries.  The report is another contribution to strengthening the EU's militaristic pillar, with more budget and war capabilities. The Europe we stand for is, on the contrary, a Europe of peace and cooperation between sovereign states equal to rights, based on respect and firm defence of citizens' rights, freedoms and guarantees.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is report 2017/2211(INI) (A8-0184/2018) by Davor Škrlec, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Rapporteur. – Madam Chairman, dear colleagues and colleagues, first of all let me thank all the shadow rapporteurs and their teams who have been valuable and indispensable partners in the creation of this report. Also, thank you very much to my colleagues and colleagues from the ENVI Committee for their contributions through their opinion. We regret that Mrs Crețu is not with us today, but we believe that our messages today will reach her and that we can count on her in the fight for a stronger circular economy in European funds.  The cohesion policy and circular economy report comes at the right time with concrete proposals and strong support from the Regional Development Committee. The Commission presented us with draft Multiannual Financial Frameworks, as well as draft Common Provisions and Structural and Investment Funds. On a positive note, the circular economy is recognised as one of the European Union's leading public policies, and I also welcome the Commission's proposal that the disposal of unsorted waste, mechanical biological treatment of waste and incineration of non-recovery waste will no longer be funded by European funds. We are currently in a challenging position to achieve the objectives of the Waste Directive because we have not been guided by the waste management hierarchy and long-term planning. This report warns of these bad practices and offers solutions to change negative trends through European public policies. The circular economy must not be imposed on Brussels policy, but a policy considered at local, regional and national level, which is why we propose an ex-ante condition in the form of a circular economy strategy as a precondition for us to rethink at local and national level what a circular economy is for our communities, how best we can achieve it, create new green jobs and achieve European goals for the benefit of the local community. As Parliament, it is of utmost importance to us how European public money is spent, which is why it is necessary to develop methodology and indicators for monitoring the consumption of money for the circular economy, so that they can evaluate spending well and react in time.  The potentials for our regions and local environments are great, waste to most is a big political problem, but we see it as a solution in a circular economy. The development of secondary raw material markets, the use of green and circular public procurement, the promotion of investments in the bio-economy, investment in renewable energy sources as well as advanced networks, and the encouragement of small and medium-sized entrepreneurship to innovate and develop business models in accordance with the principles of the circular economy are just some tools before countries, regions and local authorities. Through cohesion policy and the circular economy, we are strengthening a solidarity, long-term sustainable and economically resilient European Union.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Ms Crețu sends her apologies as she cannot be with you this evening, but rest assured that she will take a close interest in the results of this work, and indeed this debate. On behalf of the Commission, I would like to welcome this debate and the opportunity to discuss cohesion policy’s contribution to the circular economy. As you know well, the Commission’s Circular Economy Action Plan was adopted in 2015 when the framework for the 2014—2020 cohesion policy was already in place. Nevertheless, many priorities and principles have been key components of our cohesion policy, acting as a stimulus to local and regional development: waste prevention, recycling, eco—design and similar measures create savings, increase turnover and create local jobs in various sectors.  In the 2014—2020 period, cohesion policy invests in improved waste management with more than EUR 5.5 billion. Furthermore, we invest in resource efficiency, SME support and close—to—market innovation. Beyond funding, cohesion policy provides possibilities for capacity building,  technical assistance, promoting green public procurement and cooperation across borders. To avoid lock—ins, the system of ex-ante conditionalities was introduced, as mentioned. For waste, this means that the investments are made based on waste management and prevention plans, and for innovation, on smart specialisation strategies. All of this will go forward and continue in the next MFF. In addition, we will place more emphasis on the transition towards a circular economy. This is a broad challenge, profoundly changing our economies, which requires innovation, behavioural change, improved waste prevention and management, know—how, skills and administrative capacity, among other things. With its integrated policy framework, cohesion policy is well placed to help regions to face this challenge.  Among the priorities included in the Commission’s proposal is an increased focus on the upper strategies of the waste hierarchy, excluding landfilling and the least desirable treatment operations from the scope of the funds, to adapt regional waste management systems to the new long-term targets. We also increase the focus on smart specialisation, which helps regions to promote emerging industries and new value chains and business models – leading, we hope, to breakthroughs for the circular economy transition. That is our objective. We welcome this discussion.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: rapporteur for the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Madam President, in today's speech, I would like to express myself as a concrete, consistent advocate of cohesion policy and congratulate the rapporteur on a very good report.  Cohesion policy is not only important for regions, because it eliminates disadvantages, but also by helping specifically and also by coming from below. We do not have to pretend that cohesion policy is a Cinderella, on the contrary, it can use the latest scientific procedures. It is precisely by how cohesion policy really helps that it is also focused on new technologies and innovations.  In cohesion policy we can find a lot of good projects, waste prevention, recycling, re-circulation, efficiency gains, reductions in consumption, e.g. in energy recovery. The role of municipalities and cities in the use of new technologies, bio-waste in agriculture is also important. We do not have to pretend that cohesion policy is a static quantity, on the contrary, it is very lively and there are a number of good proposals, concrete measures, in this report. I therefore fully support it.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – First of all, congratulations to the rapporteur, The Scarlet, and also to the excellent cooperation and consideration of the proposals made by the shadow rapporteurs. The Circular Economy Action Plan continues the activities that have already been implemented in previous years under cohesion policy and other policies in this area in the European Union. In any case, these 150 billion, roughly foreseen in the 2014-2020 perspective, are very important for the transition to this area. Policies are both within cohesion policy, agricultural policy, and in other areas such as Horizon. In particular, I welcome the so-called Bio-based Industries Joint Undertaking, which devotes a billion euros to the bio-economy. With this area of circular economy and in conjunction with all European funds, we are greatly promoting environmental objectives, resource use and, at the same time, green jobs. These jobs are usually in rural areas, where it is also more difficult to create new jobs. I hope, and certainly, that this is our common task, to ensure sufficient resources within cohesion policy, even in the new post-2020 financial perspective, because the funds allocated to the circular economy are the means for our future. I look forward to participating in cohesion policy and also by helping regions, municipalities across Europe through new measures.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: For the S&D Group. For most people, the idea of a circular economy remains an abstract, if not entirely distant, concept. This is evidenced by a statistical data showing that more than 60% of waste is not recycled. It ends up in landfills. We easily adopted the "do, consume, throw away" model. The circular economy is a model of production and consumption in which things are not wastly thrown away, but are shared, lent, reused, repaired and recycled as long as possible. Today, we dispose of waste products made of wood, textiles, glass, plastics, but also building material, iron, practically everything that we no longer need for our own use for any reason. For this reason, it is of the utmost importance that future cohesion policy also has an incentive aspect for the circular economy, where it will also be actually applied. This means that local and local authorities must be integrated into this transition. Today, we already know a number of bright examples, where it was small municipalities that created their own local circular economy strategy and became energy independent. I would like to underline the fact that municipalities or local councils have the knowledge, the know-how, that really works. They must therefore be directly involved in the development of sustainable and regional development strategies and, on the other hand, must have sufficient space and financial opportunities to develop their own development strategies for the circular economy. The circular economy is not an end in itself. It brings benefits in the form of environmental quality, increases security of supply of raw materials, increases competitiveness, brings innovation, growth and the creation of new jobs. It offers consumers more durable and high-quality products that save their money and improve their quality of life. All this should be borne in mind if we approve the post-2020 budget, so that cohesion policy and the circular economy go hand in hand to complement each other.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Madam Chair, environmental protection and sustainability are an important part of all European policies, and a circular economy is a key model for achieving our ambitions in this area. That is why I would like to congratulate my colleague Škrlec for his quality report and contribution to the discussion on the future of this management model. What we must bear in mind are the high costs that often accompany the transition to sustainable resource management and in this context there is indeed great potential to use cohesion funds to facilitate the transition for public and private stakeholders. The report rightly points out that the circular economy includes not only waste management, but also resource efficiency, renewable energy, water management and improving air quality. These are some of the most important issues that are tormenting croatian citizens. Contaminated air in Slavonski Brod, the problem of waste management in Zagreb, Split and other larger areas and plastic waste in the sea can be well addressed precisely by stronger implementation of the measures proposed in this Report. That is why I must stress once again that the envisaged cuts in cohesion policy funds after 2020 for Croatia are unacceptable because, among other things, it will make it more difficult for it to transform towards a sustainable economy.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam Chairman, I want to emphasize right from the outset that cohesion policy and the circular economy are the best examples of how some policies go hand in hand, that some of the policies we are advocating here, which we are talking about in the European Parliament, are in fact two sides of the same coin. I'd say gold medals here. Because what cohesion policy is and what the circular economy really deserves, in Olympic terms, a gold medal. That is why I want to take the opportunity to thank and congratulate my colleague Škrlec for his report and all of us who worked on this report, because I believe that it really reflects what is not the future of the European Union, but what is the present of the European Union.  The necessary need to create green jobs is something that is the need of today, not tomorrow. Waste management, everything that really happens in our environment, tells us how much it is necessary to invest and money from cohesion policy in the circular economy. We have a lot of examples on our continent, great examples, but unfortunately we also have a lot of those other examples and we need to talk about them.  I want to highlight one relevant fact - there is no success in waste disposal, no success in the circular economy, no opening of green seats, if local and regional self-governments are not strongly involved. There is a lot of evidence for this and my personal experience speaks very clearly in this direction and that is why I invite the Commission to also talk about what were the failures when we talk about investing in waste management, because we have that too, and what we will do to repair these failures.  A lot of topics are open to this report and that is why I believe that this report was made at exactly the right moment and I expect the Commission to find the means to be able to finance this report as well.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – I congratulate my colleague Davor Škrlec on his good report and, somewhat, the strange report prepared by my group colleague to start commenting on negative epithets. However, it is bad that we are considering prospects for the development of the circular economy. The bad thing is that the circular economy still remains something exotic or something that can be done without it. The bad thing is that it needs to be proven that the circular economy, the reduction of the scale of waste, the recycling of raw materials can be beneficial. I believe that these thesis must be axiom. The principles of austerity, recycling, a responsible approach to raw materials and the future of the planet have not, and for a long time, it has long been to become part of not only public policy, but also part of the educational system or human consciousness. We only have one planet. It is good that Europe adopted the waste package a few years ago. It is great that we are looking for ways to use waste, and it is great that colleagues in the Davor Skrlec report are increasingly focused on making as many players as possible in the circular economy. Not only individual citizens or businesses, but also local self-government, regional self-government, communities. And that would make recycling motivating.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, when we talk about a circular economy, we mean finding ways, using modern technology, innovation, not only to protect the environment, but also to create new businesses and jobs. We need to change the way we deal with waste. Instead of burying 60% of waste in the European Union, use it to save resources, to save money and to create millions of jobs. That is why we need a boost from the Commission, support from governments, but also a stronger role for municipalities and regions, which can create green entrepreneurship and help us move into the new era. A week ago we celebrated World Environment Day. We must celebrate it 365 days a year by promoting the circular economy in practice. And in order to achieve this objective, albeit late, we must run using this positive report.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I should like to begin by thanking all my fellow Members for their work. The report on the circular economy that we are about to vote on is very ambitious and meaningful, especially for those who, like me, come from Campania who, it should be remembered, has been battered for decades by criminal associations that, in contempt of any rule, including ethics, have caused the pollution and destruction of one of the most beautiful territories in Italy. Reducing waste that ends up in landfills and putting legal and illegal landfills in safety and reclamation is a top priority of the text we are approving. I believe that this is the right direction. The Commission is now being asked to take extraordinary action and efforts to clean up areas used for the illegal spillage and burial of hazardous waste, which undermines the health and economic and social well-being of the populations involved. As I have said, what has happened in the Land of Fires is a phenomenon that goes beyond national borders and therefore also deserves attention from the European Union. I think that an explicit reference to such phenomena is a positive sign. This is an important message from the European institutions to the citizens who live in those areas whose lives have been completely turned upside down. I therefore hope that this request will not remain a dead letter and that the Commission will act as soon as possible to protect the health and rights of citizens. Every time, when I leave and take the plane and see Vesuvius, I think I'm really admiring one of the most beautiful landscapes I've ever seen. Yet man manages to destroy what nature creates in a magnificent way. The task of politics is to provide answers and solutions to people's problems and to ensure that the right to live in a healthy environment is respected. In this regard, I would like to thank the carabinieri and all the police forces who fight in this territory on a daily basis. But it is also time for Europe to act.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the 21st century sees the emergence of a new economy, that of the management of our consumer products after use. A full-fledged economy, it is based not only on an economic principle of value, profits and job creation, but also on a new vision of consumption, because it is of course the object itself of consumption, from our daily food to motor vehicles, through our homes or our auxiliaries and robots, but also their packaging as well as their waste. The new idea is to take into account all these parameters before consumption, in advance, and no longer after the fact. Radical change that can prevent us from disappearing under our own objects and waste.  Therefore, globalized funding may be acceptable, especially if there are big savings.  The fact that the jobs created are often low-skilled and local is an unparalleled opportunity to combat unemployment that affects the most insecure.  So yes, recycling must be as close as possible to their place of consumption.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: Mr President, rapporteur and Commissioner, thank you. It is good that we are looking again at this issue from the regional funds, because the big gains for people, growth and jobs are indeed in regions and cities, close to the people. That's where you can organize that circular economy. I was rapporteur for the bio-based industry. The Horizon 2020 framework programme aims to drive this development. (The president interrupts the speaker because there is no Finnish rendition) What I would particularly like to insist on is this: start with nature in the circular economy and not with the fossil sources. That is why I would like to advocate the creation of many more products, such as plastics, from biomaterials. Secondly. For years I have organized exhibitions with new materials for the public. People often wonder: Where can you buy something like that? Moreover, Commissioner, there is no European label for this. In the Netherlands, for example, you have "Biobased content", in Germany "DIN-geprüft" or in France "Biobased Vinçotte". But there is no European label that allows citizens to know that products are bio-based. Would you like to answer that? Is it not the case that we need to work on clarity for consumers so that they know where to buy, but also what exactly they are buying? That's circular. There is no point in talking about what is being thrown away in Italy. We need to prevent waste from the agricultural industry, and that is a good thing. We'll leave a chance there. I would like your opinion on that. Thank you.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the 2014-2020 programming, the circular economy was not included among the European Union's priorities. Today we know how this can be one of the main points for the sustainable development of a region and how it offers answers to the challenges of local communities. While there is no doubt that coordination and greater cooperation between regions, small and medium-sized enterprises and other public and private actors are desirable, it is also true that, in accordance with the very principles of cohesion, those regions that are not yet able to comply with good practice must be accompanied and followed more closely.  I therefore believe that the possibility of introducing a new provision on ex-ante conditionality in order to achieve the circular economy within the framework of cohesion policy can sometimes become an insurmountable constraint, while monitoring the contribution of cohesion policy to the realisation of the circular economy, also in the light of the increase in expenditure, is more than appropriate.  It is absolutely necessary, as the excellent report states, to take extraordinary action to clean up the areas used for the illegal spillage and burial of hazardous waste, which undermines the health and economic and social well-being of the populations involved. It is precisely the most difficult territories that have the greatest presence. It is precisely through greater cooperation between all the actors involved in the circular economy processes that the objectives set by the European Union can be achieved.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Despite the peans, the report on the circular economy submitted under cohesion policy is controversial. This applies to recycling and to a wider extent than before. In the beginning, recital A states that local and regional authorities are key to the success of the proposed change. If so, the question arises whether this has been consulted with those authorities before? It is said that it is not possible to achieve the objectives of the waste package without the financial support of cohesion policy, for which the European Commission now wants to drastically reduce resources. So why is there no mention of this in the report? Paragraph 12 of the document states that the base raw materials, i.e. natural raw materials – mr van Nistelrooij spoke of them – cost less than recycled products. This means that it is going to be more expensive, because the Union will increase the prices of products traditionally produced. All this proves that the European Union is going further by trying artificial regulation and market control from Brussels level.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: – Thank you, Mr President, also to the rapporteur. The big question for Europe and for the planet as a whole is how to make economic growth sustainable and curb the consumption of non-renewable resources. Looking at the circular economy from cohesion policy is a fresh and very topical perspective. It will enable us to encourage local actors to develop new green solutions and innovations, technologies and jobs. At the same time, we also support the vitality of the countryside in a sustainable way. Regional development has already significantly boosted the circular economy. Local regional development success stories relate, among other things, to industrial symbiosis projects that have utilised resources among different actors. At the same time, new entrepreneurship has been created. The second main objective, a greener, carbon-free Europe, is a fine opening and creates a framework for the stronger integration of the circular economy into European regional policy, but we need to look further. The next Commission's agenda must therefore include circular economy 2.0, where sustainable forestry bioeconomy, biocirtour farming and the transition away from plastics polluting our seas, among other things, are being taken more seriously.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, the European Union is 2.5 billion tonnes of waste a year, of which 25 million tonnes of plastic waste. The circular economy has therefore become an urgent imperative. But make no mistake: the implementation of a circular economy in cohesion policy will not be enough. It is all the policies of the Union that must be put in the footsteps of ecology and this implies a Copernican revolution of minds, it implies getting out of consumerism, the economy of disposables, the society of waste. And my colleague Lambert van Nistelrooij is right: we must also support research to promote technological innovations in order to achieve this goal.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I am addressing you mainly because, if the objective of cohesion policies is to reduce the social gap, the economic gap and also in terms of development between the different areas of the European Union, and this objective is rightly to be pursued, it is also intended to reflect the key principles of the circular economy. , so I wonder whether the instrument of infringement procedure, as it has been conceived up to now, is a useful tool for achieving these objectives.  I'm from Italy. Italy, through the previous governments, has been ordered to pay penalties for 68 illegal landfillsites. We have been condemned for the waste emergency in Campania – it was mentioned earlier – and for the pollution of urban waste water. We have recently been referred to the European Court of Justice for a further 44 irregular landfills, for the failure to secure radioactive waste and for the overrun of pm10 and DN.02 emission limits. We are therefore a long way from those virtuous principles of the circular economy that we are talking about and will instead pay very high fines for a total amount of more than one billion euros.  So I ask how you intend to reduce the economic and social gap, if these second-class citizens repeatedly see their fundamental right to health and environmental protection prevail and in the end they also have to pay the very high fines that you dump on them. We say that, if these fines are to be paid, then the economic amount must not end up in the Eu ropean Union budget, but must be spent in the same Member State that pays them to deal with the very causes that led to the fine.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The circular economy gives the European Union the opportunity to grow faster and to be more competitive and productive. That is why it is so important to fully and effectively implement solutions in this field. There is no doubt that further intensive efforts are needed to improve waste management and a stronger focus on increasing productivity and reusing products.  The use of cohesion policy instruments for this purpose can bring excellent results. However, we must remember that it is important to meet several conditions. Firstly, it is necessary to ensure greater independence for regional and local authorities, which are best able to identify problems appropriately for the area concerned and to propose effective solutions. Secondly, the proposed objectives must be realistic and timed. Thirdly, the role of small and medium-sized enterprises in creating new solutions and models based on circular ity should be appreciated and actively supported through various incentives and attractive financing. And add to that the question of funding to support research in this area.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: – Madam President, to talk about a circular economy is to talk about taking advantage of what we have, a regenerative concept that saves and also advances environmental protection. Therefore, the transition to a circular economy model must increasingly be a priority. It is positive that funds to boost the circular economy are integrated into cohesion policy, as waste management is municipal and regional competence. In addition, this will help European money better reach SMEs and businesses in the social economy. The Europe 2020 Strategy has helped to advance this area by promoting smart specialization, innovation aid and measures to protect the environment. There's a lot to do, but there's a lot to do. Consider, for example, the potential of bioeconomy or green public procurement. In this way more funds will be allocated to sustainability, managed much better and, thanks to the European Union, our towns and cities will be able to make the transition to a circular economy model a reality. However, Member States have to do their part. A national circular economy strategy should be developed to complement the European strategy with these axes: agri-food, tourism, industry and construction. Because to make the key sectors of our economy more sustainable is to invest in the future or, equally, to leave a better world for generations to come.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Madam President, in the 2014-2020 programming period the circular economy was not recognised as a priority area of action in the European Union. In the proposal for the next multiannual framework this objective has been included and I congratulate the Commission on this decision.  It is the recognition that the inefficient use of resources leads to environmental, social and economic damage. In 2014 the European Union produced 2.5 trillion tonnes of waste. We need to reduce, recycle and reuse. It is therefore urgent to combat waste. If we want a more sustainable Europe, the circular economy must be a commitment made not only in the long term, but as a permanent goal. The circular economy faces challenges that involve the change of the entire production system and which in fact needs the financial assistance of cohesion policy.  We must therefore provide local and regional authorities, as well as small and medium-sized enterprises, investors, educational and research institutions, with adequate functional and financial autonomy, enabling them to prepare and implement strategies they believe to be the best for their regions, including community-based local development and integrated territorial investments.  It is also essential to combine different funding, including those of research, and it will not be too much to recall the privileged use of the environmental fund, which, for example, will fully support the agenda for the circular economy of one of the European outermost regions, the Autonomous Region of Madeira.  In circular business, development and progress models are no longer based so not only on profit, but on environmental protection. To do this, we must strengthen and rehabilitate landfills, it has already been said, throughout Europe. All direct or indirect investments in the circular economy are no longer an option, as the rapporteur says, they are a necessity for the good of our species and of all that is alive in this world.

name: Nuno MELO
text: – Madam President, we realise that the reduction of the European Union budget because of Brexit means cuts, but what we do not accept is that when cohesion exists to bring the poorest countries closer to the richest, some of the richest have an increase in cohesion funds and some of the poorest suffer cuts.  The Commission said at a press conference with Commissioner Katainen present that it is intended to continue to direct resources to the regions that need to recover most from the rest of the European Union and ensure fair treatment for all. I must say that the statement is, at the very least, exotic. Portugal has a GDP per capita of 77% of the EUROPEAN Union average, Finland of Commissioner Katainen's home a GDP per capita of 109% of the EU average, therefore has a GDP higher than the EUROPEAN Union average, Finland will have increases of 5% and Portugal will have cuts of 7%. Worse, countries such as Luxembourg, with a GDP per capita of 258% of the European Union average, or Austria, the Netherlands, Belgium, Sweden, or Denmark, all above the European Union average, do not suffer cuts, but Portugal, until recently intervened by the Troika, will have cuts of 7%. Worse, countries such as Spain or Italy, much richer than Portugal, will have increases of 5 and 6%, but Portugal will have 7% cuts in cohesion funds. I would like to go by saying, Madam President, that the cuts that the Commission wants to impose on Portugal are absolutely unfair, inexplicable and, to the extent that I have mentioned, even arbitrary. Have the notion of this because decisions like this and with decisions like this is the whole nature of the European project that is called into question.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, I welcome the report and I support the development of the circular economy as one of the five cohesion policy goals post—2020. Even though I would treat some of the figures that are thrown around on job creation with caution, the potential for the creation of new jobs from circular markets is clear – as are, indeed, the sustainability benefits of moving from new materials in an extractive economy: they’re also self-evident. But I have two observations. If viable circular markets are to develop, then a strategy for supporting those markets has to emerge, otherwise they will not be able to compete effectively against existing linear markets. Secondly, central and local government will be vital, within that strategy, in underpinning the development of mature circular markets through sustainable procurement, as it will in sustainable waste management processes on which the circular economy will depend.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, without question, cohesion policy is one of the fundamental European policies, and it provides the best tools for implementing the circular economy. Sustainable economic growth requires the use of resources of any kind, as efficiently and responsibly as possible, as they are limited. The involvement of local and regional authorities as well as other partners in the processes of developing strategies for the circular economy is essential and must consider strengthening horizontal partnerships. At the same time, it should be borne in mind that less developed regions generally face problems related to lack of administrative capacity. In this respect, I appreciate that funding programmes need to be adapted more to the profile of regions aimed at exploiting their sustainable potential, and support must be geared towards a smooth transition to the principles of the circular economy. Therefore, there is a need for an increase in expenditure on the circular economy in cohesion policy after 2020.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt, today there is a new awareness, that the crisis has not only contributed to making shared heritage, the awareness that the figure of innovation must be consolidated in order to support another idea of development. A real revolution, therefore, that of the circular economy and innovation, which restores dignity to the environment and human capital and which cannot be experienced only as industrial innovation of process and product, but which must involve and enhance territories, urban communities, rural communities and human capital, also to defeat any resistance to change.  In short, a new reading key for cohesion policies. Building within the vision of success of these years a new connection between policies, research at the service of sustainability, active policies for work, oriented to the processes of promoting the business system, an increasingly inclusive vision of the community.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, I believe that we all have to defend cohesion policy and the policy of the circular economy. These are policies that go together and must be the highest priority of all of us. That is why I fully agree with my dear colleague Nuno Melo, who stressed that there can be no cuts in cohesion policy, because this is essentially an attack on the region, on the poor countries in need of cohesion policy. This policy that has proved successful for so long cannot today be threatened by anyone. Support for these policies means supporting rural areas, it means supporting the regions, it means green economy, it means green growth, it means jobs. We must defend these policies and it is time to do so in order to bring out the European Union itself. Small and isolated countries, such as my home country Cyprus, need these policies, because they are in a dire position, particularly the agricultural sector, the region and the countryside. That is why we support these policies and will shield them with all our might.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I want to congratulate the European Commission, and I want you to convey to Mrs Cretu, in particular to congratulate her, because the circular economy for cohesion policy has also passed among the top five priorities. It is very important because, when we talk about the circular economy, we are talking about a radical change from the way we think, realize and use the products in our daily lives. Europe bears the burden of responsibility to become a global leader in this area, especially with regard to decisions of strategic partners of ours. We can no longer continue according to current principles, as resources become less and less, being more costly and harmful to the environment. Research and innovation today offer us alternatives to harmful processes, developed in the past but used today.
