Why don't we use best technology, Commissioner, when it comes to cohesion funds, when it comes to countries that today do not have effective collection systems. Let's invest in the right thing!

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, in this Cohesion Fund period, the circular economy was indeed not embedded among the finance priorities, and because of that we have used quite a lot of the money on the wrong courses with good intentions, namely, funding the construction of landfill and incineration while we already have an overcapacity of waste incineration in Europe. Indeed, we are still financing waste incineration, which should be brought to an end as soon as possible.  We are creating a double benefit when we remove subsidies from the wrong courses that work against the circular economy and put those resources to work for the circular economy. The Cohesion Policy and the Committee of the Regions have a great role to play here because they gather together SME groups. They can develop the kind of hubs that serve as platforms for the development of new business models and new types of public procurement.  In the future, only the projects that support the circular economy, sustainability and social inclusion should be financed from the Cohesion Fund. Hopefully, with the Committee of the Regions, a sharing mechanism can be created where the best practices can be shared between different regions.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Cohesion policy has always played an important development role. It has been and is an innovative policy, creating modern forms of economic activity, as well as new technological solutions that promote the good of the environment and combat climate change and social exclusion. Cohesion policy has always faced important, strategic, but also difficult challenges. These include the circular economy. Recycling of waste leads to a reduction in environmental pollution and a reduction in the consumption of natural resources. Although it costs more today, it pays off in the long term. These bioeconomy-related activities are particularly evident in rural areas, as well as in agriculture, where renewable energy sources, for example, are developing well for rural development and agriculture.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Cumbria Recycling in my North West constituency is an excellent best practice example of the circular economy. It operates in a deprived peripheral region that has benefited hugely from EU cohesion policy and financial support. Working within the parameters of EU waste directives and operating as a successful social enterprise, Cumbria Recycling diverts electronic waste away from landfill through the collection and sustainable reuse of electronics: waste that others may deem as useless. Cumbria Recycling processes over 2000 tons annually of waste and electrical and electronic equipment for the reuse and sorting for recycling of raw materials. In the post—Brexit world, it will be hugely important for the UK to maintain its commitment to the highest environmental standards and also to continue to provide support for enterprises like Cumbria Recycling, who fundamentally understand the social return on investment that comes with the circular economy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the circular economy is essentially a new model which contributes to the creation of millions of jobs and aims to protect the environment. It is therefore an operational model which can create green jobs, particularly in the field of recycling and reuse of materials, and even more so in the area of waste management, where local government can play an important role at all levels, both at municipal and regional level. I believe that incentives should be given and the small and medium-sized enterprises sector should also play an important role. Municipalities can also play a decisive role and must also support innovation. But that is why they must also receive the appropriate funds.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Madam President, cohesion policy is the key to ensuring that the circular economy also become a reality in countries that are lagging behind on waste infrastructure. If we want to achieve the ban on landfilling municipal waste, as we have recently approved here, we need to give poorer countries a way to do so. In countries such as the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Poland, we have been lagging behind in building infrastructure for sorting and recycling for a long time, and energy use is still in its early days. Although things are slowly changing here, too. We know that abolishing landfill and meeting the recycling target will not be easy. I am therefore very happy that the European Commission has decided to financially support the circular economy not only within this programme period, which is already ending, but also in the new programming period, the thus enabling them to make a smoother transition to a low-carbon and circular economy. This support is thus an exemplary fulfilment of the very essence of cohesion policy, which is based on the requirement to reduce the gap between the levels of development of different Member States.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you again for this report and for the debate that we’ve had this evening. I think we’re all agreed that, if we get it right, the circular economy has the potential to support economic growth and regional development, while at the same time boosting environmental protection. We’ve discussed, this evening, a number of the potential gains and, from the Commission side, we agree with many of the points that have been made in the debate.  We have sought to target support during the current period, but, as many of you have stressed, it’s also important that we integrate these objectives in our proposals for the next period – the post-2020 period.  The transition to a circular economy is now included in the policy objectives that we are earmarking. Although the circular economy strategies are not yet implemented widely enough to be a new enabling condition, we are excluding the least desirable waste management options from the scope of funding.  Again, the monitoring framework includes new indicators more closely linked to the circular economy and the objectives we’ve been discussing, such as the use of recycled waste as raw materials. Now we’ll also have a tracking methodology that supports environmental objectives next to the tracking of climate objectives.  A number of other points have come up in discussion and, as we undertook at the beginning, we will make a careful report on all of those to Ms Creţu and her team.  The circular economy requires considerable changes to the way we live our lives and run our economies, and that requires the effort, support and engagement of a wide range of stakeholders who are trying to make the circular economy happen in all regions, local authorities and cities, but it is worth the effort. That is the main message that I take away from tonight’s debate.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: The Rapporteur. – Madam Chairman, I thank all my colleagues and commissioner for their contributions to today's discussion. I will look back at just a few details that I think are important that we might highlight and explain them even more strongly to our citizens.  First, it is very important to strengthen the capacities of our local and regional self-government. As a fact, I give the fact that in last year's competition of the European Commission for consultative assistance to regional self-government units, it was in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe that there was a very low turnout. Thus, this part of the European Union did not recognise the circular economy in time as a potential for the development of its economy. Also, investing in the entrepreneurship sector is very important in order to enable it to transition to a circular economy. Here again I will give one example - the other day in a European retail chain I bought wooden spoons, forks, knives, as a substitute for the disposable plastic products that we use today, but what surprised me was that it was made in China, not in the European Union. So, China has recognized the European Union's policy in the circular economy and has actually applied the biomaterials it sells to us on the market today. So we need to make our entrepreneurship work to become competitive on a global scale. There was a mention of "smart specialization", this is very important in order for our regions to recognize their local potential. It is precisely as I would say that through the new Horizon Europe in the research and development of new materials using biomaterials, they would actually develop products, that is, those based today on disposable plastics. That is why I support the Commission's initiative to propose a directive on the limited use of single-use plastics and, of course, the proposal for a directive amending the Drinking Water Directive. And finally, I would just like to highlight what our most important messages really are, which our colleague Pietikäinen has already pointed out, which is that in this programming period we have projects, we have money from European funds that is poorly used. So, ex ante conditions that respect the hierarchy of waste management are actually the conditions for financing the circular economy, i.e. these projects. Development of national strategies that will, in fact, be in line with european circular economy policy and, what the Commissioner pointed out, that we have a clear methodology for monitoring indicators of investment in circular economy projects.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 March 2008. Adopted on 16 June 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The circular economy offers an environmentally friendly alternative to the currently widespread "Buy! Use it. - Throw it away!" and support for cohesion policy is also needed to strengthen it. The demand for products and services in the circular economy is insufficient, often due to the fact that they are more expensive than linear products and services, but the negative consequences of which and their impact on climate change are not taken into account. The circular economy is much more comprehensive than waste management; it areas of renewable energy, resource efficiency, bioeconomy, agricultural and fisheries policies, food waste, air quality, research and development and innovation. The circular economy effectively supports sustainable development and the fight against climate change, so exploring and exploiting its potential is therefore an important task.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The structure of plastics used in tangible products is subject to irreversible changes during their operation as a result of the increase in internal entropy. A return to baseline, i.e. the distribution of secondary raw materials into starting components, although theoretically possible, would be subject to a higher energy input than that which occurred when primary raw materials were used.  Starting from the exergetic balance sheet, we can see that "simple recycling" has its own energy constraints. Repeated recycling of thermoplastic plastics leads to a shortening of polymer chains, i.e. a sharp decrease in their mechanical properties. The same is true of recycling in the case of the production of steel based on scrap iron alloys. The more melt cycles, the more likely it is that low-melt, nobler than iron components, such as copper, will appear in the steel structure. Such constants are fragile and not very malleable. They are not suitable for car body work.  The circular economy should take into account the exergetic constraints of secondary raw materials when developing new technologies for their use. A classic example of this approach could be the use of worn car tyres for the production of various types of rubber-polyurethane fittings (polyurethane as a binder), which have beneficial vibration damping properties. It is not difficult to predict that "simple recycling" would be extremely complex and energy-intensive in this case.
